ARTICLE VIII Final Provisions The present Agreement will take effect as of the date of its signing and will have a term of three (3) years, which can be extended for periods of equal duration upon execution of a written agreement by the Parties. Either Party may terminate this Agreement upon one-hundred eighty (180) days' written notice to the other Party. The present Agreement may be modified by means of the written consent of both I Parties. These modifications will take effect on the date of their signing. The termination of the present Agreement will not affect the conclusion of the joint actions that will have been formalized during the term of this Agreement. -7-

ARTICLE IV Expenses and Costs The financial contributions that are required for the execution of the activities that the present Agreement will be subject to the budgetary availability of both Parties. At the arrival of the Mexican teachers, neither the State of Utah nor the Utah State Office of Education is obligated to cover any costs of transportation for the participating teachers, nor expenses relative to lodging, food, local transportation, utilities and other personal expenses. At the arrival of the Mexican teachers, they are responsible for their expenses related to airfare, housing, utilities, meals, and other personal expenses. ARTICLE V Medical Insurance The Parties will ensure that the visiting teachers are informed that they must obtain their own medical insurance, at their own expense, until the teachers are covered by the insurance offered by the Utah public school district employing the teacher. ARTICLE VI Entry of Personnel The Utah State Office of Education will work with participating Utah school districts to facilitate reasonable activities for the arrival, residence, and departure of participants in joint projects, which are part of the present Agreement Visiting teachers will adhere to the applicable laws and rules of the U.S. Home Land Security. MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING To Establish a Partnership between the following Federal States The State of California, United States of America AND the Land Baden-Wurttemberg, Federal Republic of Germany. Preamble In 2015, the Minister Prasident Winfried Kretschmann of Baden-Wurtteberg and Governor Jerry Brown of California shared thoughts on the occasion of a delegation visit to California on a potential collaboration between Baden-Wurttemberg and California in the economic, environmental and climate field as well as in science, literature, and art. During a visit to Stuttgart in 2017, Minister President Kretschmann and Governor Brown discussed the expansion of the collaboration between technology and science centers and how to enhance the exchange and friendship between Baden- Wurttemberg and California. In May of 2018, the California State Senate passed a Resolution that supports expanding the bilateral relationship that exists between Baden- Wurttemberg and California and encouraged the efforts to establish a sister state relationship. Memorandum of Understanding The State of California in the United States of America and the Land Baden- Wurttemberg in the Federal Republic of Germany (in the following referred to as "the partners") are leading in the sector of innovation and climate protection. They both hereby express the intent to share as partners the vision of sustainable change by combining economic prosperity with the indispensable protection and preservation of our natural heritages. They are both convinced that concrete action locally and close cooperation between each other will contribute substantially to sustainable change. In 2015, Baden-Warttemberg and California jointly launched the Under2 Coalition as an initiative for climate protection. It has now developed into a worldwide movement of subnational governments that fight climate change by implementing concrete policies and measures. At present, more than 200 countries, regions and municipalities are members of the initiative. Both Baden-Warttemberg and California are establishing ambitious policies and programs to achieve their climate protection goals by 2030. These include the promotion of smart and environmentally-fiendly mobility, energy efficiency and the comprehensive utililization of renewable energy. Other important contributions are made by industry, the academic community and research with innovative technologies and sustainable solutions. The Ministry for Science, Research and the Arts of Baden-Wurttemberg and the California State

University have enjoyed a cooperation since 1995 as well as an exchange program that was renewed in 2015. The Partners have come to the following understanding: 1. The Land Baden-Warttemberg and the State of California express their intention of cooperating in the future in the following areas within the scope of respective competences, functions and means: CLIMATE, ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL POLICIES, including measures to improve resilience in the face of climate change and consequent natural events TRAFFIC TRANSFORMATION, including initiatives and measures for sustainable and modern mobility URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE ECONOMIC COOPERATION, specifically in the field of digital transformation and in collaboration with start-ups from Silicon Valley INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY IN RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AND THE BUSINESS SECTOR SCIENCE, RESEARCH, ARTS AND CULTURE 2. The following activities should be specifically conducted within the scope of the State Partnership: Exchange of information on energy storage, utilization of renewable energy and measures for energy efficiency Exchange of experience and information for the promotion of sustainable mobility and the creation of required infrastructure (Strategy Dialogue Automotive Industry) Exchange of experts and information on best practices in cybersecurity, Exchange of experts and job shadowing in science, research, arts and culture as well as in the state agencies for energy (KEA and California Energy Commission), mobility (e-mobil BW and California Air Resources Board) and environment (LUBW and California Enivronmentaly Protection Agency) Establishment of joint, innovative research approaches on climate change (as a partnership among government, academia, industry, and civil society) Exchange of expert knowledge in the film and media industry in partnership with the California Film Commission and the Media and Film Society Baden Wurttemberg Collaboration in the field of literature and intellectual history such as provenance research, starting with a workshop in California (June 2018) on the subject "Thomas Mann's American Library" Exchange of experts and cooperation in the field of digital transformation, specifically within the scope of the project "Innovation Camp BW Silicon Valley" (www.innovationcampbw.de)

Exchange and collaboration regarding start-ups and networking of start-up ecosystems, specifically through partnership with the California Innovation Hub (iHub) Networ Sharing and transfer of know-how and potential project concerning comprehensive, publically accessible electric charging infrastructure Expansion and optimization of public transport and consequently the necessity of a marked increase in transport capacity in public transport Exchange of experience, specifically for the rapid installation of infrastructure, procurement of vehicles, funding and new forms of public transport with autonomous vehicles, connectivity of transport modes and carriers, new mobility services providers, sharing concepts (ride sharing, car sharing, bike sharing) to achieve zero emissions in inner cities and livable urban quarters as well as promoting pedestrian and bicycle transport in order to increase their share significantly and systematically on all routes. Exchange of information on respective urban and traffic planning. 3. None of the provisions contained in this Memorandum of Understanding should entail any legally binding or financial obligations for any one of the Partners. The Partners can withdraw from this MoU at any time and should provide 60 days notice prior to doing SO. This Memorandum of Understanding was signed at San Francisco on September 15th, 2018 in two copies of the same content in the English and German language. woody biomass, hydropower, wind power and clean coal technologies; (ix) The State of Alaska regularly engages with public entities and companies, both domestic and foreign, interested in Alaska's resources to provide information that will attract international investment and enhance cross-border commerce; (x) The State of Alaska has expressed interest in providing American and Japanese companies with business opportunities; and (xi) Cooperation with JBIC enables DNR to gain a better understanding of the rapidly changing Japanese and Asian markets and the interests of investors for LNG. 3. JBIC's mission is to contribute to the sound development of the Japanese and international economy by conducting international finance operation in the following four fields: (i) Promoting overseas development and acquisition of strategically important natural resources to Japan; (ii) Maintaining and improving the international competitiveness of Japanese industries; (ili) Promoting overseas projects for conserving the global environment, such as mitigating global warming; and (iv) Responding to disruption in the financial order in the international economy. 4. JBIC has expressed interest in contributing and supporting the organizing from an early stage of projects to be implemented by Japanese companies in the State of Alaska that meet JBIC's financial policy and requirement. In light of recognitions mentioned above, the Parties have agreed to the following: ARTICLE 1: AGENDA FOR DISCUSSION The Parties may, at their respective sole discretion, exchange information or views with respect to the following subjects: (i) Potential resource development projects that the State of Alaska wishes to advance -in particular a large-volume natural gas pipeline and export facilities; other projects could include areas such as: oil, strategic and critical minerals (including rare earth elements), iron ore, coal, clean coal technologies, alumina, woodchip, infrastructure, power (including hydropower), environmental technologies, water and waste management, and other renewable energy technologies; (ii) Potential projects in Alaska that the State of Alaska would like JBIC to evaluate for possible international financial investment; (iii) The operations and policies of JBIC as they relate to potential Alaska projects; and (iv) Other items the Parties may wish to discuss in relation to potential opportunities for cooperation. ARTICLE 2: MEETINGS The Parties will meet from time to time in order to discuss the agenda set forth in Article 1 of this Memorandum of Understanding and mutual collaboration in organizing mission and events by the Parties.

implementing solidarity between the people and in joining efforts of the public and private sector in order to prevent, mitigate, and redress adverse effects from emergencies and disasters. THEREFORE, THE PARTNERS PLEDGE THEIR INTENTION TO: 1. Design cooperative projects, and conduct joint studies and research that aim to enhance emergency response and recovery efforts, and develop disaster prevention and mitigation procedures and techniques, in coordination with the relevant authorities of each territory and in accordance with applicable domestic laws. 2. Provide training opportunities, best practices and expertise in areas of disaster risk management to develop expeditious communication strategies to apply in the event of emergencies and disasters in accordance with applicable domestic laws. 3. Exchange information on disaster risk management during disasters as mutually determined by the Partners. 4. Explore, develop and promote future activities and collaborations in disaster risk management. The Partners acknowledge that this Memorandum of Understanding is only intended to provide for cooperation between the participants and does not create any legally binding rights or obligations. To the extent that any other provision of this Memorandum of Understanding is inconsistent with this paragraph, this paragraph shall prevail. The Partners commit themselves in good faith to implement this Memorandum of Understanding to the fullest extent possible, subject to any changes in policy that they may adopt and will be effective on the date appearing below and will remain in effect for four years from that date. Any ongoing cooperative activity approved or initiated and not yet concluded would continue to completion, unless otherwise decided by the Participants. The Participants declare in good faith their intent to implement this Memorandum of Understanding to the fullest extent practicable and feasible as determined by each Participant in its sole discretion.

SECTION VI Availability of Personnel and Resources This Memorandum of Understanding, once in effect upon signature, does not create any legally binding rights or obligations for either Participant. This Memorandum of Understanding does not involve the exchange of funds, nor does it represent any obligation of funds by either Participant. All costs that may arise from activities covered by, mentioned in, or pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding will be assumed by the Participant who incurs them, unless otherwise stipulated and decided pursuant to a future written arrangement. All activities undertaken pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding are subject to the availability of funds, personnel and other resources of each Participant. The personnel designated by the Participants for the execution of this Memorandum of Understanding will work under the orders and responsibility of the organization or institution to which they belong, at all times maintaining their employment relationship with that organization or institution. Their work will not create an employer-employee relationship with any other organization or institution, so in no case will that other organization or institution be considered as a substitute or joint employer off the designated personnel. SECTION VII Compliance with Applicable Laws All activities undertaken pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding, and all personnel designated by the Participants for the execution of those activities undertaken pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding are subject to the applicable laws of the receiving country. Such personnel, if visiting the other Participant to participate in an activity pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding, will not engage in any activity detrimental to this Memorandum of Understanding.

ARTICLE 7 TRADE OF COMPLIANCE INSTRUMENTS In order to achieve harmonization and integration of the Parties' cap-and-trade programs, trading of compliance instruments among registered participants in the Parties' respective programs shall occur as provided for under their respective cap-and-trade program regulations. The Parties shall keep each other informed of any investigation, pertaining to but not limited to acts or omissions on the part of any of its registered participants or other persons regulated under the programs and any violation, penalty or fine, or decision rendered following such investigations. ARTICLE 8 ACCOUNTING MECHANISM AND TREATMENT OF EMISSION REDUCTIONS In order to ensure clarity and transparency in how greenhouse gas reductions from cap-and-trade programs are counted toward each Party's emission reduction target, the Parties agree to develop and implement an accounting mechanism that provides a transparent and data-driven calculation that attributes to each Party its portion of the total greenhouse gas emission reduction achieved jointly by the Parties' linked cap-and-trade programs. The agreed upon accounting mechanism should achieve a high level of transparency and careful and secure management of confidential and market sensitive information in the Parties' cap-and-trade programs. The Parties will build on international principles and criteria, namely those pertaining to environmental integrity and robust accounting, with an emphasis on transparency and on avoiding double counting. The Parties recognize that to avoid double claiming of emission reductions, only the Party to which an emission reduction is attributed by the accounting mechanism can use that reduction when assessing its progress toward meeting its emission reduction target, and other Parties will appropriately recognize a corresponding opposite emission impact when assessing their progress toward meeting their respective emission reduction targets. The Parties acknowledge that when developing and implementing the accounting mechanism, each Party's applicable statutory and regulatory requirements will be respected. The Parties agree to periodic review of the accounting mechanism in response to the development of laws applicable to each Party or relevant national and international principles and criteria.

I. Coordinate efforts to ensure complete coverage A. The British Columbia. Ministry ofl Environment and California Air Resources Board may share resources to support the consistent application of vehicle emission standards to vehicle models available to citizens in California and British Columbia, including cooperation on vehicle test data and determination of carbon dioxide equivalent values for vehicle models available to the market in either jurisdiction. B. The California. Air Resources Board agrees in principle to support the Ministry of Environment, British Columbia, in the implementation of its Vehicle Emission Standards Regulation by providing technical and policy guidance to assist British Columbia Ministry of Environment in making determinations for vehicle models or systems delivered for sale in British Columbia. II. Information Sharing A. California Air Resources Board and the British Columbia Ministry of Environment will work to implement information sharing processes to ensure the timely communication of proposed and enacted regulatory amendments by the California Air Resources Board, policy determinations and approvals as part of the implementation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 13 by the Executive Officer; and, B. Wherever possible, the rationale for said policy determinations and approvals by the Executive Officer that may impact the application ofthe California Code of Regulations, Title 13, in BC, be made available to British Columbia Ministry of Environment; and, C. The categorization of manufacturers as large volume, intermediate volume, independent low volume and small volume manufacturers under the California Code of Regulations, Title 13, will be periodically determined and made public by California Air Resources Board; and, D. The constituent values that determine carbon dioxide equivalent values for emissions from specific vehicle test groups be made available to British Columbia Ministry of Environment in such a: manner as can be shared with regulated entities in British Columbia. III.Referencing Regulations made under British Columbia's Greenhouse Gas Reductions (Vehicle Emissions Standards) Act may specifically reference and make use, in whole or part, of determinations oft the California. Air Resources Board, including California Air Resources Board Executive Orders under the California Code of Regulations, Title 13, that determine the carbon dioxide equivalent values for emissions from specific vehicle test groups. 3

Exerutiue Bepartment State nf California Joint Statement/Declaration on Friendship, Economic Development and Climate Change by State of California ("California") and the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries ("China") California and China share a long history of successful collaboration, in a range of topics including trade and investment, climate change, energy and environment; and continued subnational collaboration between the United States and China is instrumental to a stable, sustainable and mutually beneficial bilateral relationship. To enhance the bilateral relationship and foster collaboration, California and China agree to establish the California-China Program, coordinated by the California Governor's Office and the Chinese Friendship Association, to be affiliated with the U.S.-China Governors Forum, aiming to build regular dialogue between California and Chinese subnational counterparts to discuss the critical issues of mutual interest outlined above. The California-China Program will facilitate a yearly US-China Subnational Climate Dialogue, jointly established, on September 12 of 2018, at the Global Climate Action Summit. Mour Edmund G. Brown Jr. Madame Li Xiaolin Governor of the State President of the Chinese People's of California Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries

Purpose The purpose of this Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is to support the efforts of each Participant to address the global issue of climate change and to achieve its low-carbon development goals. The Participants agree to communicate and cooperate on matters of research, innovation, and commercialization. The cooperation based on this MOU will also provide a mechanism through which the Participants' governments, researchers, key stakeholders, and industrial collaborators may exchange views, express concerns, and arrange to carry out joint actions. It will also provide a mechanism to promote scientific, technological, and industrial research and commercialization cooperation between California and Shenzhen and will provide a platform for promoting mutually beneficial endeavors between the Participants, including developing markets for science and technology-based products. This MOU establishes a fundamental framework for the cooperation between the Participants based on principles of equality and mutual benefits and does not provide the Participants or third parties with any legal rights, nor does it incur legal obligations by the Participants or any third parties. 3. General understanding 1. Duration of Lol: This Lol shall be operational upon signing by both parties, will be deemed to commence on the Commencement Date stated above, and will have an initial duration of 12 months. All activities conducted throughout this term, and within the scope of the joint collaboration will be deemed to fall under this Lol. A general evaluation of this cooperation and its future will be conducted and reported upon completing 12 months from the date of signing the Lol. 2. Termination of Lol: The cooperation covered by this Lol shall terminate upon completion of the agreed upon tasks or automatically after completing 12 months from the date of signing, whichever comes first. The Lol may also be terminated with a one month's written notice from either party. 3. Extension of Lol: The Lol will not: automatically be extended. Upon completion both parties will evaluate the mutual benefits of the Lol.. A positive evaluation of the Lol leads to the intention of both parties to conclude a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). 4. Coordination: In order to carry out and fulfil the aims of this Lol, each party will appoint an (the) appropriate person(s) to represent its organization and to coordinate the implementation of activities. RDW and DMV representatives will maintain contact at regular intervals to discuss progress and plan activities. RDW Contact Person: Mr. Gerard Doll - Director' Vehicle Regulation and Admission Division DMV Contact Person: Dr. Bernard C. Soriano I Deputy Director, Registration Operations Division 5. RDW and DMV will pay the costs and expenses incurred by it in connection with the negotiation, entering into and completion of this Letter of Intent and any further agreements, including the costs of own advisors and consultants. 6. This Lol does not create any rights or obligations under international law. Signed by Mr. B. RDW DRIVING CHANGE. Letter of Intent This Letter of Intend ("Lol") is made and signed in duplicate on the 12th of November 2019 (Commencement Date), by and between: The Netherlands Vehicle and Driving Licence Registration Authority, hereafter referred to as RDW, office address, Europaweg 205, 2711 ER, Zoetermeer, The Netherlands and the Californial Department ofMotor Vehicles, hereafter referredi to as DMV, office address, 2415 First Avenue, Sacramento, CA 95818, United States of America RDW and DMVI have come to the following understanding; 1. Purpose The purpose of this Letter of Intenti is to express the mutual intention to utilize the knowledge and experience of the two Parties in the areas related to the automotive industry and (smart)mobility. The subjects of mutual interesti are innovation related to electric vehicles, autonomous vehicles, vehicle type-approval Vs. self certification and enforcement, guidelines experimentation, registration benchmarking, vehicle identification, data and data sharing and innovations related to self-driving functionalities and the infrastructures needed to provide sustainable and quality support. By exchanging knowledge and best practices, a mutually beneficial cooperation can arise. However, nothing in this Lol obliges any party to adopt any law or standard of, or proposed by, the other party. 2. Areas of interest and proposals 1. Areas of Interest RDW and DMV investigate the possibilities to extend cooperation by the exchange of knowledge/experiences, for example the possibility of al RDW 'foothold', / presence in California. RDW and DMV deliver a joined effort to investigate and facilitate California based automotive manufacturers that want to obtain (European) Type Approvals/Certification fort the European market. 2. Areas of Cooperation Exchange of knowledge/experiences can take place in any of the following fields of common interest: a. Innovative developments in the automotive on safety and security and the RDW's Vehicle Safety and Security Framework (VSSF) b. Emissions C. Enforcement d. Data use and data sharing e. Cybersecurity

(vi) collaborate on ways to engage other entities to bring further support to the activities pursued under this Memorandum; (vii) collaborate on the dissemination of model policies and programs through publications, seminars, workshops, conferences and other easily accessible means; and (b) The Collaborative Activities will be delivered through various initiatives, including the Global Platform for Sustainable Cities (GPSC), a knowledge sharing program that will provide access to cutting-edge tools and promote an integrated approach to sustainable urban planning and financing coordinated by the World Bank, for which the California will act as a technical partner. Initial Collaborate Activities may include: (i) Carbon inventory methodology, including establishment of a database and development of related templates; (ii) Decarbonization pathway to 2050, including cataloging of cross sector methods and consideration of policy interactions across sectors; guidance on technical and political processes for emission target setting; identification and sharing of resources for implementation, including market and non-market means; tracking and analysis of indicators for progress towards goals; (iii) Capacity building, including model policies and training programs for other regions, development of templates, case studies analysis, tool and resource sharing, and analysis of governance structures in specific regions (c) As part of this collaboration, the Parties will, from the outset, work in partnership with the Under 2 Coalition and its Secretariat and the Climate Group, and seek other partnerships as appropriate. (d) The Parties will periodically evaluate the effectiveness of working in collaboration, with reference to their respective mandates and priorities. C. Contacts Each party hereby designates and appoints below its representative with overall responsibility for implementing this Memorandum. The Parties may, by written notice to the other. Party, designate additional or different persons as points of contact but the Parties expect to have only one person at a time designated as the person with overall responsibility for all activities undertaken pursuant to this Memorandum. Memorandum of Understanding On Friendly Exchanges and Cooperation Between The State of California, United States of America And Osaka Prefecture, Japan At the invitation ofMr. Edmund G. Brown Jr., Governor of California, Mr. Ichiro Matsui, Governor of Osaka Prefecture led an official delegation to visit Sacramento, California on June 11, 2013. During this visit, Governor Matsui and Governor Brown held friendly talks and reviewed the cooperation between the two sides since the establishment of the sister-state relationship in 1994. Both agreed that Osaka Prefecture and California are economically complementary and that there exists significant potential to advance and strengthen economic and social ties. California has the highest Gross State Product in the United States of America and is the ninth largest economy in the world. Osaka Prefecture has a population of 8.8 million and is the 29th largest economy in the world. Accordingly, both governments agree: I. To support and encourage economic and trade cooperation between California and Osaka Prefecture in the following key areas: clean energy environmental protection information technology bio-tech manufacturing tourism II. To support and encourage cooperation on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and promoting low carbon development. III. To: support and encourage their people and governments to further develop interpersonal contacts and exchanges, and to promote mutual understanding and friendship. IV. To promote exchange programs between universities and other educational institutions. V. That California will designate the Governor's Office off Business and Economic Development and that Osaka Prefecture will designate the International Affairs Division to coordinate trade and investment relations between Osaka Prefecture and California. This Memorandum of Understanding was signed in Sacramento on June 11", 2013 in the languages of English and Japanese in duplicate, each party holding one; both textsl being equally authentic. Apel EDMUND G. BROWN. JR. ICHIRO MATSUI Governor of California State Governor of Osaka Prefecture

The Participants intend to support and encourage the strengthening of sister city programs between Israeli and California cities, which are designed to enhance opportunities for cultural and educational exchanges, economic partnerships and social entrepreneurship on the local level. 6. The Participants intend to encourage collaboration between Californian and Israeli universities, public and private research institutions. This Memorandum ofUnderstanding is intended to become effective on the date it is signed and does not create any legally binding rights or obligations for either Participant. This Memorandum ofUnderstanding was signed in Mountain View, California, United States, on the sth day of March 2014, corresponding to the 3rd day of Adar II of 5774 in the Hebrew calendar. EDMUND G. THEREFORE, IT IS DECLARED AS FOLLOWS: The Participants hereby sign this Memorandum ofUnderstanding for the purposes of establishing a formal relationship between them to foster economic cooperation and economic development, facilitate joint industrial research and development and enhance business relationships and educational opportunities to foster job creation and incubate global solutions from joint California-Israel innovation initiatives. To achieve these aims: 1. The Participants intend to seek to convene bilateral, interagency and inter- ministerial working groups with international expertise to coordinate initiatives. 2. The Participants plan to facilitate collaborations between Israeli and Californian entrepreneurs and researchers through (though not exclusively limited to) the California innovation hub (iHub) network I a network consisting of self-funded, collaborative regional innovation clusters, uniting government, universities, foundations, national labs and the private sector. 3. The Participants intend to support and encourage their people and competent authorities to further develop interpersonal contacts and exchanges and to promote mutual cooperation, understanding and friendship by encouraging ad hoc task forces, trade delegations and professional exchanges between Israel and California in key sectors including, but not limited to: a. Water Conservation and Management b. Alternative Energy and related Clean Technologies C. Health and Biotechnology Solutions d. CyberSecurity e. Arts & Culture f. Education g. Agricultural Technologies

Memorandum of Understanding On the Establishment of a Strategic Partnership for Joint Innovation, Exchanges and Cooperation Between The Government of the State of California, United States of America And The Government of the State of Israel THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF ISRAEL AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA (hereinafter "the Participants") RECOGNIZE THAT: WHEREAS two-way tradel between Israel and California totaled over $4 billion in 2013 - one oft the largest two-way trade relationships between Israel and a U.S. State; and WHEREAS the State of California and the State of Israel share close ties and are global leaders in the alternative energy, environmental technology and other technology-based industry sectors; and WHEREAS the State of California is home to the largest in-state innovation network in the United States, which offers technology-commercialization opportunities for the State of Israel; and WHEREAS the Participants seek to expand the current. level of cooperation between Israel and California in, but not limited to, alternative energy, environmental technology, health, food and agriculture and other technology based industry sectors, business innovation, research and development.

4. Exchange of Information i)The Participants do not expect to exchange any information that is considered business-confidential. If this expectation changes, the Participants intend to enter into a written non-disclosure agreement. ii) The Participants intend that nothing in this MOU should be interpreted to restrict their rights to make public any information or results of their collaboration and cooperation hereunder. 5. Designated Representatives To administer the implementation of this MOU, each Participant should designate one principal coordinator, through whom all requests and plans of that Participant are to be made. The designated representatives may hold meetings when necessary to discuss matters related to cooperation under this MOU. iii) The designated representative for LBNL is Ashok Gadgil, the Environmental Energy Technologies Division (EETD) Director, or another designated LBNL principal coordinator. Dr. Jayant Sathaye, Senior Scientist and Strategic Advisor, International Energy Studies Group (IES), and Dr. Amol Phadke, Deputy Leader, International Energy Studies Group (IES), are to assist the above EETD Senior Scientists in this role. The designated representatives for the CEC is Brenda Sturdivant, Associate Energy Specialist; for the CPUC Carol Brown, Chief of Staff; and for the FOR, Sushanta K. Chatterjee, HoD. 6. General Considerations Each Participant should conduct the activities contemplated by this MOU in accordance with all applicable laws, regulations and other requirements to which it is subject, including, without limitation, export control laws and environment, health and safety laws and regulations. ii) The conduct of cooperative activities contemplated by this MOU is subject to the availability of funding, personnel, and other resources. iii) Each Participant is to be responsible for the costs it incurs in participating in cooperative activities under this MOU. 4

U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE Certification Regarding Debarment, Suspension, and Other Responsibility Matters - Primary Covered Transactions This certification is required by the regulations implementing Executive Order 12549, Debarment and Suspension, 7 CFR Part 3017, Section 3017.510, Participants' responsibilities. The regulations vere publi ished as Part IV of the January 30, 1989, Federal Register (pages 4722-4733). Copies of the regulations may be obtained by contacting the Department of Agriculture agency offering the proposed covered transaction. (BEFORE COMPLETING CERTIFICATION, READ INSTRUCTIONS ON REVERSE) (1) The prospective primary participant certifies to the best of its knowledge and belief, that it and its principals: (a) are not presently debarred, suspended, proposed for debarment, declared ineligible, or voluntarily excluded from covered transactions by any Federal department or agency; (b) have not within a three-year period preceding this proposal been convicted of or had a civil judgment rendered against them for commission of fraud or a criminal offense in connection with obtaining, attempting to obtain, or performing a public (Federal, State or local) transaction or contract under a public transaction; violation of Federal or State antitrust statutes or commission of embezzlement, theft, forgery, bribery, falsification or destruction of records, making false statements, or receiving stolen property; (c) are not presently indicted for or othervise criminally or civilly charged by a governmental entity (Federal, State or local) with commission of any of the offenses enumerated in paragraph (1)(b) of this certification; and (d) have not within a three-year period preceding this application/proposal had one or more public transactions (Federal, State or local) terminated for cause or default. (2) Where the prospective primary participant is unable to certify to any of the statements in this certification, such prospective participant shall attach an explanation to this proposal. III. COORDINATORS / STEERING COMMITTEE A. Definition - The Governor of each Member State and the Premier of each Member Province shall designate a Southeastern United States-Canadian Provinces Alliance Coordinator for his/her respective jurisdiction. The State and Provincial Coordinators shall serve as the liaison between his or her signatory state/province and the other members. Coordinators shall act upon business matters affecting the annual event and the Alliance on whole. The coordinator may appoint a designate to fill his/her role. B. Responsibilities - The coordinator is responsible for adhering to the deadline dates issued by the host jurisdiction. See section VI A for the definition of "host jurisdiction." 1. Of primary importance, the coordinator must ensure that all information is submitted to the host in a timely manner. Such information includes, but is not limited to: delegation leader biographies and photographs, speaker biographies, and any information related to the annual event as requested by the host. 2. The coordinator is responsible for designating and supervising a business- to- business meeting liaison for the purpose of facilitating recruitment and qualifying delegates. 3. The coordinators shall serve as the Steering Committee for the Alliance and meet as needed and determined by the coordinator for the host jurisdiction. Date, time and location of such meetings shall be coordinated and set by the coordinator of the host jurisdiction. C. Recording Secretary l A recording secretary shall be named by the host coordinator for purposes of taking minutes at the annual and steering committee meetings, housing minutes and archives of past meetings, housing meeting histories, and assisting in the writing of any official statement or communiqué, should there be one. IV. VOTING PROCEDURES A. Voting Process - A quorum is required to transact any official business. A quorum is defined as two-thirds of the membership of the Alliance from the Southeastern United States and two-thirds of the membership of the Alliance from the Canadian Provinces. Should an insufficient number of members be present to achieve quorum, quorum may be achieved through virtual means = e.g., video teleconference or electronic communications. B. Items Requiring a Unanimous Consensus - Items that require a unanimous consent of a voting quorum are amendments to the bylaws, addition of new Alliance Members, and amendments to a Joint Declaration. Additionally, if the Governors, Premiers, or their designated Heads of Delegation deem it necessary to issue resolutions, joint statements, and/or communiqués, such items must be adopted or amended by unanimous consent of a voting quorum. Proposals for such changes or adoptions shall be presented in timely manner so as to allow for absentee balloting. 3

C. Items Requiring a Majority Vote - Items that require the majority vote by the voting quorum include but are not limited to rotational changes in hosts. D. Authority to Vote - Only Governors or Premiers, or their designees, may cast votes on the addition of new Alliance Members, amendments to the Joint Declaration, and amendments to the bylaws. Other issues requiring votes may be decided by the State and Provincial Coordinators through the Steering Committee. V. STATE/PROVINCIAL ASSESSMENT In order to ensure that the annual event participation fee is as low as possible, an annual non- refundable assessment of $2,500 per member jurisdiction will be assessed. The current year host jurisdiction shall be exempt from the annual membership assessment. The current year host jurisdiction shall invoice the alliance members in the second or third quarter of the calendar year. The fee will be payable to the host jurisdiction in the currency of the host jurisdiction. VI. ANNUAL ALLIANCE EVENT The Alliance shall convene once per year. The time, date, and location of the annual event shall be set by the host jurisdiction, in consultation with the other members, and should ideally occur each year in the spring.. The Governor of a State or the Premier of a Province or his/her designee shall lead that delegation to the annual event of the Alliance. Each Head of Delegation is encouraged to bring one or more CEOS to the annual meeting of the Alliance. The Host jurisdiction shall provide an opportunity for the Head of Delegations and CEOS to interact. A. Host State or Province 1. Order of Rotation - The annual event shall alternate locations between the Southeastern states and the Canadian provinces. Any Member may elect to change its order in the rotation by first finding another member state or province that is willing to switch and then securing a majority vote of the steering committee. The rotation order is set as follows: Québec Georgia (2008) Newfoundland and Labrador (2009) Mississippi (2010) New Brunswick (2011) South Carolina (2012) Nova Scotia (2013) North Carolina (2014) Prince Edward Island (2015) Tennessee (2016) Ontario (2017) Alabama (2018) Québec (2019) Georgia (2020) 4

Newfoundland and Labrador (2021) Mississippi (2022) New Brunswick (2023) South Carolina (2024) Nova Scotia (2025) North Carolina (2026) Prince Edward Island (2027) Tennessee (2028) Ontario (2029) Alabama (2030) 2. Role of the Host Jurisdiction - The host for the annual event shall accept its responsibility for up to two years. In the first year, there will be the option to host an activity at the event with the goal of promoting the event the following year andin the second year the jurisdiction shall serve as host of the event. The host government is the primary logistical and programmatic organizer for the event. a. Chair of Steering Committee - The host coordinator shall chair each meeting of the coordinators. The host coordinator shall be the liaison among the members. b. Coordination = The host shall coordinate all aspects of planning the annual event; such as selecting the venue, blocking hotel rooms, activities such as a welcome reception, meal functions, entertainment, arranging for simultaneous translation (if necessary), and the printing of event materials, all at the discretion of the host jurisdiction. C. Gifts - Any gifts are at the discretion of the host jurisdiction. d. Administrative Duties - The host shall be responsible for all administration duties relevant to the event. e. Program - The host shall be the primary organizers of the event agenda and theme. f. Media - The host shall coordinate all access for press who wish to attend and cover the annual event. g. Logo and Branding - In order to establish a recognized brand for the annual event, the Coordinators shall select a common logo and each host jurisdiction shall use this logo on event materials. Each Alliance member's logo also may be used in addition to the common logo. h. Registration - The host shall set all policies and procedures governing regular delegate registration, late and on-site registration, applicable registration fees, cancellation of registration, spouse/guest registration, and the issuance and collection ofi invoices. 5

B. Annual Event Logistics 1. Delegation Size and Fees a. Delegation Size - The total delegation number from each state or province shall not exceed forty (40). An exception is made for the host, which may add up to an additional forty (40) delegates without approval from the steering committee. Spouses, dependents, and security are not included in the delegate limit. A state or province may request permission from the host to bring additional delegates but the decision is at the sole discretion of the host. b. Delegate Fees - In an effort to defray the costs of the annual event, the host state or province may assess a per participant fee to be collected at the time of registration. The amount of the fee and the acceptable manner(s) of payment shall be determined by the host. The fee also applies to spouses and/or guests of delegates, although the amount may be modified. A tiered pricing structure for conference participants is encouraged (conference attendee, conference attendee with matchmaking appointments, spouse program). The registration fee shall be waived for Heads of Delegation, his/her spouse, security traveling with the Heads of Delegation and Ambassadors. C. Event Program The host jurisdiction should provide a SEUS-CP branded event that presents opportunities for business-to-business exchanges which enhance existing relationships and develop new ones. Economic development organizations are encouraged to attend the event, especially for networking purposes. However, meetings between private sector entities will be the focus of pre-arranged business exchanges. Delegates should be presented a high-quality program that allows for the exchange of information with a view to identifying areas of potential collaboration. 1. Annual Event Dates = Unless otherwise approved by the steering committee, the annual event date should ideally fall in the spring between April1 and June 30 each calendar year. 2. Format - The format and content of each event is at the sole discretion and direction of the host jurisdiction. One function at the event may be sponsored by the next year's host jurisdiction. If a business matchmaking component is included, it will be open only to private sector companies located within SEUS- CP Alliance member jurisdictions. 3. Special Program for Heads of Delegations - Participation at the annual SEUS-CP event not only allows the Heads of Delegation to support their 6

jurisdiction's business leaders' engagement within the Alliance, but also facilitates leader to leader interactions. The host jurisdiction will organize a special and exclusive program for the Governors, Premiers, and their designated Heads of Delegation, for part of the event. A private program provides an effective platform for the Heads of Delegation to discuss challenges and opportunities, share ideas and examine issues of common interest. In the formative years of the Alliance, this meeting occurred during a private breakfast where Heads of Delegation discussed current issues. The Ambassadors of Canada and the United States may be invited to participate. 4. Non-delegate Program - At the sole discretion of the host, the event may offer a separate program for spouses and guests of delegates. Participation in this alternate program may be assessed a fee. 5. Event Attendance Eligibility - SEUS-CP event attendance is open only to companies, organizations, and government agencies located within SEUS-CP member jurisdictions unless an invitation is extended by the host jurisdiction. VII. HOST JURISDICTION ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES 1. Hotel Selection and Assignment - The host shall select a venue and hotel(s) suitable for hosting the annual event of the Alliance. When possible the selected venue should have a hotel that is able to accommodate all delegations. A sufficient number of suites must be reserved for each Head of Delegation, Ambassadors (if in attendance), and other attending dignitaries. However, jurisdictions are not required to utilize a suite. 2. Coordinators Working Room - The host is responsible for arranging a workroom during the annual meeting with access to business equipment. 3. Simultaneous Interpretation = Simultaneous interpretation in both English and French is not mandatory when events are hosted in the United States. When events are hosted in Canada, simultaneous interpretation is at the discretion of the host jurisdiction. 4. Transportation - When attending the annual event of the Alliance, the Head of Delegation and his/her security detail shall be provided appropriate transportation from the airport to the event site and throughout the event. The drivers of these vehicles should be law enforcement officers or drivers with law enforcement training. 5. Coordinator's Meeting - The host jurisdiction shall organize and host a coordinators steering committee for the primary purposes of conducting a walk- through of the facilities and finalizing the agenda for the annual event. Date, time and location of such meeting shall be coordinated and set by the host jurisdiction. Ideally the Coordinators meeting should take place approximately six months prior to the annual event. The Coordinator's meeting will be open to voting Alliance members only unless invited by the host jurisdiction to discuss specific agenda items. 7

6. Post - Event Debrief Meeting i At the discretion of the upcoming host jurisdiction, a post-event meeting may be held with the Coordinators to discuss best practices and lessons learned from the previous annual event and to coordinate opportunities for collaboration between the annual events. The ideal timing for this meeting is no later than two months after the conclusion of the annual event. Should such a meeting occur, participants may be assessed a fee to cover the cost of the meeting. 8

This Letter of Intent is not legally binding and does not give rise to any rights or obligations under international law. Signed on June 02, 2022, in duplicate, in the English and Spanish languages. FOR THE MINISTRY OF ENVIRONMENT FOR THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE AND NATURAL RESOURCES OF THE SERVICE OF THE UNITED STATES OF UNITED MEXICAN STATES AMERICA MMA Wull HUMBERTO ADAN PENA FUENTES, MARTHA WILLIAMS, NATIONAL COMMISSIONER OF NATURAL DIRECTOR PROTECTED AREAS  FOR THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT hysl TY GRAY, DIREÇTOR FOR THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH MICHAEL SLOANE, DIRECTOR 3

RECOGNIZING that, while the Mexican wolf wild and captive populations are larger now, there are new ecological, social and financial challenges that must be addressed through renewed and strengthened inter-institutional strategies that assure the successful recovery of the Mexican wolf; HIGHLIGHTING the value and importance of the Mexican wolf to the environment and the residents oft both countries, Mexico and the United States have been working jointly, and individually, to recover and conserve native species, particularly the Mexican wolf, within its historical distribution on both sides of the border; HIGHLIGHTING the value of collaboration to achieve shared goals, "The Participants" have been working together to manage the binational Mexican WolfSpecies Survival Plan (SSP) Captive Breeding Program to provide Mexican wolves for release in both countries and to collaborate on the release of wolves in the United States and Mexico; TAKING INTO ACCOUNT the provisions and guidelines stated in the Memorandum of Understanding to establish the Canada/Mexico/United States/ Trilateral Committee for Wildlife and Ecosystem Conservation and Management, signed on April 09, 1996; "The Participants" have reached the below understandings and intend to cooperate, in accordance with their areas of responsibility, current legal mandates, plans and programs of each country: "The Participants" will elaborate an annual joint Work Plan aimed to carry on specific activities for the conservation, management and recovery of the Mexican wolf on both sides of the border and foster long- term partnerships, as well as to strengthen the existing collaboration between Mexico and the United States in recovering the Mexican wolf. "The Participants" and their responsible agencies for recovering the Mexican wolf will follow-up the activities decided upon during the development of the annual Trilateral Committee Meeting for Management and Conservation of Wildlife and its Ecosystems, and will report the progress and success of this collaboration at the Shared Species of Common Conservation Concern Working Table of the Trilateral Committee. 2

LETTER OF INTENT AMONG THE MINISTRY OF ENVIRONMENT AND NATURAL RESOURCES OF THE UNITED MEXICAN STATES, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT AND THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH, FOR THE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY OF THE MEXICAN WOLF (Canis lupus baileyi) The Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources ofthe United Mexican States, through the National Commission for Natural Protected Areas, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service of the United States of America, the Arizona Game and Fish Department and the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish, hereinafter referred to as "The Participants", KNOWING that in the early 1970s, the Mexican wolf (Canis lupus baileyi) was extirpated in the United States, and considered extinct in Mexico a decade later, eventually leading to the development of the Mexican Wolf Recovery Plan in 1982; CONSIDERING that between 2015 and 2017, the Mexican Wolf Recovery Plan was revised following a series of binational workshops to update and analyze the biological information supporting the full recovery of the Mexican wolfby maintaining a captive breeding program and reestablishing viable, self- sustaining populations of at least 320 and 200 individuals with appropriate gene diversity, within historical range in the United States and the United Mexican States, respectively; CONSIDERING that the goals and objectives of Mexico's Action Program for the Conservation of Species: Mexican Wolf (PACE Lobo Mexicano) which seeks the establishment of actions for the conservation and management of Mexican wolf populations and habitat within its historical range that ensure the success of the species and its self-sustainability within the ecosystem, as well as the compliance to the commitments established under the Mexican Wolf Recovery Plan taking into account its genetic and demographic goals for the subspecies; 1

EXHIBIT B CERTIFICATION OF NONSECRECATED FACILITIES This clause shall be applicable as required by rules, regulations, and rel- evant orders of the Secretary of Labor (41 CFR, ch. 60). By the exccution of this Agreement, the Institution certifics that it docs not maintain or provide for its employecs any segregated facilities at any of its cstablish- ments, and that it docs not permi t its employces to perform their services at any location, under its control, where segregated facilities are main- tained. It certifies further that it will not maintain or provide for its employees any sezregated facilities at any of its establishments, and that iL will not permit its enpluyees to perform their services at any location, under its control, where segregated facilities arc.maintained. The Institution agrecs that a breach of this certification is a violation of the Foual Oppor- tunity clause in this Agreement. As used in this certification, the term "segregated facilitics" means any waiting rooms, work arcas, rest rooms and wash rooas, restaurants and other cating areas, time clocks, locker rooms and other storage or dressing areas, parking lots, drinking fountains, recre- ation or entertainment areas, transportation, and housing facilities provided for employecs which are segregat ted by explicit directive or in fact segregal tcd sarthe basis of tace, creed, color, or national origin, because of habit, Lal custom, or otherwise. It further agrecs that (except where it has ob- tained identical certifications from proposed subcontractors for specific time periods) it will obtain identical certifications froa proposcd subcon- tractors prior to the laward of subcontracts exc.ceding $10,000 which arc not excmpt froa the provisions of the Equal Opportunity clause; that it will re- tain such certifications in its files; and that it will forward the following notice to such proposed subcontractors (exccpt where the proposed subcontractors have subaitted identical certifications for specific time periods: NOTICE TO PROSPECTIVE SUBCONTRACTOKS OF REQUIREMENT FOR CERTIFICATION OF NONSEGRECATED FACILITIES A certifica tion of Nonsegregat ted Facilities, as required by the May 9, 1967, order (32 F.R. 7439, Hay 19, 1967) on Elimination of Segregated Facilities, by the Secretary of Labor, must he submi tted prior to the award of A suh- contract exceeding $10,000 which is not exempt from the provisions of the Equal Opportunity clause. The certification may be submitted either for each subcontract or for all subcontracts during a period (i.c., quarterly, semi- annually, or annually).

Article XII - Severability This arrangement is construed So as to effectuate the purposes stated in Article I. If any provision of this arrangement is declared unconstitutional or invalid or inapplicable to any person or circumstances, the validity of the remainder of this arrangement to that person or circumstances and the applicability of the arrangement to other persons and circumstances are not affected. Article XIII - Inconsistency of Language The validity of the arrangements and agreements consented to in this arrangement shall not be affected by any insubstantial difference in form or language as may be adopted by the various states, provinces and territories. MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING between the PANAMA CANAL AUTHORITY and the TENNESSEE-TOMBIGBEE WATERWAY DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is entered between the Panama Canal Authority (ACP), an autonomous legal entity established by the Constitution of the Republic of Panama under public law and having its main offices in Balboa, Panama in the Republic of Panama and the Tennesse-Tombigbee Waterway Development Authority (TTW), a four-member interstate compact consisting of the States of Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi, and Tennessee established by U.S. Public Law 85-653 and based in Columbus, Mississippi (hereinafter collectively referred to as the "parties"). WHEREAS, The parties hereto believe it is in their mutual interest to establish an alliance of cooperation aimed at generating new business by promoting the all water route between Asia and the United States mid-southern states via the Panama Canal and the inland navigable waterway system known as the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway consisting of the States of Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi, and Tennessee and its connecting waterways; Both parties recognize the potential economic and environmental benefits of an all water route including the use of the inland waterway system. Such new business would help to increase the present level of economic growth by increasing job opportunities and revenues within the Tennessee Tombigbee Waterway region and increasing revenues at the Panama Canal; The parties are constantly undertaking a series of activities aimed at improving customer service; and, The parties desire to cooperate in improving their business practices and in increasing their level of services available.

6. It is the intention of this document to set forth the general intentions of the parties, and not to set forth any legally binding rights or obligations. This MOU will be effective upon signature by the authorized representative of each of the parties. Panama Canal Authority Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway Development Authority Alberto Alemân Zubieta Michael D. Tagert Administrator/CEO Administrator Date: Date:

Southeastern United States - Canadian Provinces Alliance (SEUS = CP) BYLAWS Amended 5 June 2017

The SEUS-Canadian Provinces Alliance will function within the framework of the general relations between the Governments of Canada and the United States of America and by the proper observation of corresponding laws and policies of both countries, Provinces and States. We the undersigned do hereby support the establishment the SEUS-Canadian Provinces Alliance and do pledge the best efforts of our respective Governments to ensure the mutual benefits and practical results cited herein. Done at Montréal, this 16th day of November 2007, in thirteen copies, in the English and French languages.

JOINT DECLARATION FOR THE PURPOSE OF ESTABLISHING THE SEUS-CANADIAN PROVINCES ALLIANCE This Joint Declaration affirms and announces our intention, by and on behalf of our respective jurisdictions, to establish the Southeastern United States- Central and Eastern Canadian Provinces Alliance, hereinafter called "SEUS- Canadian Provinces Alliance". The relationship between Canada and the United States of America is marked by generations of peaceful coexistence and extensive economic interaction across the longest shared border of any two countries in the world. In this cooperative spirit, the undersigned representatives of the Central and Eastern Canadian Provinces and the Southeastern United States recognize and believe that the establishment of the SEUS-Canadian Provinces Alliance will be in the best interests of our citizens and economies. The SEUS-Canadian Provinces Alliance will present the opportunity for businesses to enhance commercial exchanges, promote two-way investment and encourage technological and scientific exchanges between Provinces and States. For the designated Southeastern United States, the Canadian market is already of primary international importance. For the Central and Eastern Canadian Provinces, the Southeast constitutes one of the fastest growing regions in the United States and presents opportunities to enhance existing business relationships and to develop new ones. The SEUS-Canadian Provinces Alliance promises to bring focus to these relationships and to expand opportunities in underdeveloped sectors and markets through new partnerships. Through this Joint Declaration, we signal our desire to sustain and improve our long-standing friendship and to pursue mutually beneficial economic outcomes. THEREFORE, we endorse the establishment of the SEUS-Canadian Provinces Alliance, the focus on which shall be on strengthening existing economic ties while creating a fertile environment for businesses of all sizes to succeed, and fostering opportunities for technological collaboration. It is intended that the SEUS-Canadian Provinces Alliance will meet annually hu 1 ne c lea d ars ltern atino venues

Southeastern United States = Canadian Provinces Alliance Bylaws I. GOALS The goals of the Alliance are to present opportunities for participating members which will enhance trade, promote business alliances, and encourage technological and scientific exchanges between and among the States and Provinces. The Alliance seeks to bring focus to these relationships and to expand opportunities in industry-specific sectors and markets through new partnerships The Alliance also seeks to provide a forum for Governors and Premiers to share their views on ways to expand commerce between members of the Alliance and exchange on other subjects of common interest. II. MEMBERSHIP A. States (Southeastern United States) - Members of the Southeastern United States - Canadian Provinces Alliance (hereinafter called "the Alliance") shall consist of the states that signed the Alliance Joint Declaration in Montréal on November 16, 2007. Charter signatories were Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee. B. Provinces (Canadian Provinces) I Members of the Alliance shall consist of the provinces that signed the Alliance Joint Declaration in Montréal on November 16, 2007. Charter signatories were Manitoba, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Prince Edward Island, and Québec. Manitoba subsequently withdrew from the Alliance in 2016. C. Federal Governments - The Federal Governments of the United States of America, as represented by a designated official of the Embassy of the United States of the America in Ottawa, and Canada, as represented by a designated official of the Consulate General of Canada in Atlanta, are invited by the Alliance to assume an observer role during the annual event but do not have membership rights, including that of voting. D. Addition of New Members I Addition of new member states or provinces is subject to a vote by current member states and provinces per the voting rules and procedures outlined in Section III of the Bylaws. Members must be a state from the Southeastern United States or a Canadian province. E. Resignation of Members = Members of the Alliance may revoke their membership by submission of an email to the SEUS Alliance Coordinators followed by a resignation letter to the Governors and/or Premiers representing each jurisdiction in the Alliance. Such resignation will be accepted without penalty provided that the resigning member is not scheduled to host the event within three years of their withdrawal. If the resignation is within three years of hosting the event, the resigning member shall be required to pay a penalty fee of $2,000 per jurisdiction payable to the next hosting jurisdiction. 2

Article XII 12.1 This Agreement shall continue in force and remain binding on each Member until such Member takes action to withdraw therefrom. Such action shall not be effec- tive until sixty (60) days after notice thereof has been sent to all other Members. 12.2 In the event of termination of this Agreement, any property acquired as the result of this Agreement which is held jointly by the Members shall become the property of the Member where the property is located at the time of termination upon payment by that Member to the other Member of the fair market value of the other Member's ownership in the property. In the event the Member where the property is located does not desire to acquire sole ownership of the property, the property shall be disposed of as provided by the laws of the State or Prov- ince where the property is located and any proceeds shall be returned to the Members in proportion to their ownership in the property. 12.3 Should there be any surplus moneys at the time of termination, those moneys shall be returned to the Members in proportion to the contributions of the Members. Article XIII 13.1 Nothing in this Agreement shall obligate the funds of any Member beyond those approved by appropriate legislative action. Page 4 of 5

PGR PROCURADURIAGEMURAL DLIAR REPOMICA LETTER OF INTENT BETWEEN THE OFFICE OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL OF THE REPUBLIC OF THE UNITED MEXICAN STATES AND THE OFFICE OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL OF THE STATE OF ARIZONA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA The Office of the Attorney General of the Republic of the United Mexican States and the Office of the Attorney General of the State of Arizona of the United States of America, hereinafter referred as the Participants",and CONSIDERING That the Office of the Attorney General of the Republic of the United Mexican States and the Office of the Attorney General of the State of Arizona of the United States of America share common values and a vision of prosperity and security; That the Participants seek to create and keep strategic and collaboration links; That the collaboration between the Participants has as purpose to join efforts for increasing the efficiency of the investigation and prosecution of crimes; That the effective collaboration between law enforcement institutions is essential for fighting transnational criminal organizations; That the current international conditions and the challenges to fight organized crime, have widened the Participants' role, whose primary objective is to guarantee justice, security, respect to human rights and freedom for all their nationals within their jurisdictions; That the crimes off trafficking and smuggling of persons, trafficking in firearms, money laundering or operations with resources of illicit proceeding, drug trafficking or crimes against health, and child pornography crimes committed in the Internet, transcend international borders, thus an effective cooperation between the Participants is required; That the Participants are dedicated to enhance binational cooperation, as expressed in the International Border Conference, celebrated in Scottsdale, Arizona, United States of America, on March 1st, 2016, organized by the Office of the Attorney General of Arizona, the Southwest Border Anti-Money Laundering Alliance and the Conference of Western Attorneys General of the United States (CWAG); That the Office of the Attorney General of the Republic of the United Mexican States and the Office of the Attorney General of Arizona of the United States of America wish to make joint efforts and projects that will improve the bilateral cooperation and the exchange of practices for optimizing the investigation and prosecution of crimes; 1

PGR PROCURADURIAC DEL LAI KETUBLICA GENERAL The Attorney General of Arizona has the intention to: I. Promote academic activities for the benefit of the personnel of both Participants, such as: training programs, continuous education, specialization, seminars, workshops, meetings, workshops and other academic activities that can developed in a presential manner or via videoconference; II. Allow Arizona prosecutors to provide training in the United Mexican States, related to the investigation and prosecution of criminal cases, as well as for the preparation for the criminal trial; III. Train public prosecutors of the Federation of the United Mexican States, in the investigation of pornography crimes, committed against persons under eighteen years old or those that do not have the capacity to understand the meaning of the act, or those that do not have the capacity to resist them, and crimes committed against the free development of personality, particularly those perpetrated through the Internet; IV. Allow Arizona prosecutors to train, in the United Mexican States, Mexican public prosecutors of the Federation, on preparation of criminal investigations, cross- examinations, legal argumentation and interviews with victims and witnesses; V. Share information, investigation tactics and techniques, on cases of trafficking and smuggling of persons; This Letter of Intent is signed on May 16th, 2016, in Mexico City, in two originals, in English and Spanish, both texts being equally authentic, and will end on March 1st, 2021. C Salvador Sandoval Silva Mark Brnovich Deputy Attorney General for Legal and Attorney General of the State of Arizona International Affairs 3

PGR PROCURADUNAGEMIRAI DEIAR RIPOBLICA That the law enforcement authorities of the United Mexican States are in transition from a mixed inquisitorial and written system, towards an oral and accusatory system, that will enhance the use of scientific evidence in criminal prosecutions; That the criminal adjudication process in the United States of America is based on an accusatory criminal procedural system, that bases its criminal investigations on scientific evidence; That a strong relationship between both institutions benefits the actions that promote the Rule of Law and the mutual cooperation; That the collaboration between the Participants shall be in accordance with its laws, international legal instruments and domestic regulations. As aforementioned, the Participants intend to: I. Share legal and technical knowledge through workshops, seminars and study tours; II. Exchange information on best practices in the area of criminal investigations; III. Offer training exchange programs between the Participants, that operate the criminal justice system; IV. Share information and new technologies, about equipment, software and hardware programs on law enforcement matters; V. Exchange information, knowledge and provide training for investigating and prosecuting trafficking and smuggling of persons, trafficking in firearms, drug trafficking or crimes against health, money laundering or operations with resources of illicit proceedings, and Internet crimes, especially the ones committed against children; VI. Work towards the establishment of a cooperation for learning investigation techniques with regard to the criminal act or findings, procedures, protocols and strategies; VII. Facilitate the exchange of personnel between the Participants, to promote the continuous training; VIII. Cooperate in all reasonable and necessary ways as permitted by the regulations of each of the Participants. 2
