On behalf of the signatories, the legally designated official who is assigned responsibility for emergency management is responsible for formulation of the appropriate inter-signatory mutual aid plans and procedures necessary to implement this arrangement and for recommendations to the signatories concerned with respect to the amendment of any statutes, regulations or ordinances for that purpose. Article III - Signatory Responsibilities 1. Formulate plans and programs. Each signatory will formulate procedural plans and programs for each inter-signatory cooperation areas listed in this section. In formulating and implementing such plans and programs the signatories, to the extent practical, shall: A. Review individual signatory hazards analyses that are available and, to the extent reasonably possible, determine all those potential emergencies the signatories might jointly suffer, whether due to a natural disaster, an accidental or intentional event or the emergency aspects of resource shortages; B. Initiate a process to review the signatories' individual emergency plans and develop a plan that will determine the mechanism for the inter-signatory cooperation; C. Develop inter-signatory procedures to fill any identified gaps and to resolve any identified inconsistencies or overlaps in existing or developed plans; D. Assist in warning communities adjacent to or crossing signatory boundaries; E. Protect and ensure delivery of services, medicines, water, food, energy and fuel, search and rescue and critical lifeline equipment, services and resources, both human and material to the extent authorized by law; F. Inventory and agree upon procedures for the inter-signatory loan and delivery of human and material resources, together with procedures for reimbursement or forgiveness; and G. Provide, to the extent authorized by law, for temporary suspension of any statutes or ordinances that impede the implementation of the responsibilities described in this subsection. 2. Request for assistance. The authorized representative of a signatory may request assistance of another signatory by contacting its authorized representative. These provisions only apply to requests for assistance made by and to authorized representatives. Requests may be verbal or in writing. The authorized representative of signatories will confirm their verbal request in writing within 15 days. Requests must provide the following information: 3 MK-00033 ELARM - Sept. 30, 2008 PRR-2020-0119

A. A description of the emergency service function for which assistance is needed and of the mission or missions, including but not limited to fire services, emergency medical, transportation, communications, public works and engineering, building inspection, planning and information assistance, mass care, resource support, health and medical services and search and rescue; B. The amount and type of personnel, equipment, materials and supplies needed and a reasonable estimate of the length of time they will be needed; and C. The specific place and time for staging of the assisting party's response and a point of contact at the location. 3. Consultation among signatory officials. There will be frequent consultation among the signatory officials who have assigned emergency management responsibilities, such officials collectively known hereinafter as the International Emergency Management Group, and other appropriate representatives of the signatory with free exchange of information, plans and resource records relating to emergency capabilities to the extent authorized by law. Article IV- Limitation Any signatory requested to render mutual aid or conduct exercises and training for mutual aid will respond as soon as possible, except that it is understood that the signatory rendering aid may withhold or recall resources to the extent necessary to provide reasonable protection for itself. To the extent authorized by law, each signatory will afford to the personnel of the emergency forces of any other signatory while operating within its signatory limits under the terms and conditions of this arrangement and under the operational control of an officer of the requesting signatory the same treatment as is afforded similar or like forces of the signatory in which they are performing emergency services. Emergency forces continue under the command and control of their regular leaders, but the organizational units come under the operational control of the emergency services authorities of the signatory receiving assistance. These conditions may be activated, as needed, by the signatory that is to receive assistance or upon commencement of exercises or training for mutual aid and continue as long as the exercises or training for mutual aid are in progress, the emergency or disaster remains in effect or loaned resources remain in the receiving signatory or signatories, whichever is longer. The receiving signatory is responsible for informing the assisting signatory when services will no longer be required. 4 MK-00034 ELARM - Sept. 30, 2008 PRR-2020-0119

h) The authority of any Signatory conducting an exercise will ensure that all other signatories are provided an opportunity to observe, and/or participate in such exercises. Comprehensive Nature 4. This document is a comprehensive arrangement on civil emergency planning and management. To this end and from time to time as necessary, all Signatories shall: a) review and exchange their respective contact lists, warning and notification plans, and selected emergency plans. b) as appropriate, provide such plans and procedures to local governments, and other emergency agencies within their respective territories. Arrangement Not Exclusive 5. This is not an exclusive arrangement and shall not prevent or limit other civil emergency arrangements of any nature between Signatories to this arrangement. a) In the event of any conflicts between the provisions of this arrangement and any other arrangement regarding emergency service entered into by two or more States of the United States who are Signatories to this arrangement, the provisions of that other arrangement shall apply, with respect to the obligations of those States to each other, and not the conflicting provisions of this arrangement. Amendments 6. This Arrangement and the Annex may be amended (and additional Annexes may be added) by arrangement of the Signatories. Cancellation or Substitution 7. Any Signatory to this Arrangement may withdraw from or cancel their participation in this Arrangement by giving sixty days written notice in advance of this effective date to all other Signatories. Pacific Northwest Emergency Management Arrangement Page 4 MK-00024 ELARM - Sept. 30, 2008 PRR-2020-0119

The purpose of this arrangement is to provide for the possibility of mutual assistance among the signatories entering into this arrangement in managing any emergency or disaster when the affected signatory or signatories ask for assistance, whether arising from a natural disaster, accidental or intentional events or the civil emergency aspects of resources shortages. This arrangement also provides for the process of planning mechanisms among the agencies responsible and for mutual cooperation, including, if need be, emergency-related exercises, testing, or other training activities using equipment and personnel simulating performance of any aspect of the giving and receiving of aid by signatories or subdivisions of signatories during emergencies, with such actions occurring outside actual declared emergency periods. Mutual assistance in this arrangement may include the use of emergency forces' by mutual agreement among signatories. The purpose of these implementing procedures is to provide specific procedures, agreed to by the signatories, for implementing PNEMA. The signatories acknowledge that the signatory states of the United States (Alaska, Idaho, Oregon, and Washington) have adopted the Emergency Management Assistance Compact (EMAC). Nothing in the arrangement or these implementing procedures shall supersede EMAC. Article II- General Implementation Each signatory entering into this arrangement recognizes that emergencies may exceed the capability of a signatory and that intergovernmental cooperation is essential in such circumstances. Each signatory further recognizes that there may be emergencies that require immediate access to outside resources and that procedures need to be in place to request outside resources to make a prompt and effective response to such an emergency because few, if any, individual signatories have all the resources they need in all types of emergencies or the capability of delivering resources to areas where emergencies exist. The prompt, full and effective utilization of resources of the signatories, including any resources on hand or available from any other source that are essential to the safety, care and welfare of the people in the event of any emergency or disaster, will be the underlying principle on which all articles of this arrangement are understood 1 Emergency forces include but are not limited to: police/security forces; and fire-rescue (Hazmat/USAR): emergency medical and emergency management services. 2 MK-00032 ELARM - Sept. 30, 2008 PRR-2020-0119

Limitation - Article IV Any party. jurisdiction requested to render mutual aid or conduct exercises and training for mutual aid shall undertake to respond as soon as possible, except that it is understood that the jurisdiction rendering aid may withhold or recall resources to the extent necessary to provide reasonable protection for that jurisdiction. Each party jurisdiction shall afford to the personnel of the emergency forces of any party jurisdiction, while operating within its jurisdictional limits under the terms and conditions of this compact and under the operational control of an officer of the requesting party, the same powers, duties, rights, privileges and immunities as are afforded similar or like forces of the jurisdiction in which they are performing emergency services. Emergency forces continue under the command and control of their regular leaders, butt the organizational units come under the operational control of the emergency services authorities of the jurisdiction receiving assistance. These conditions may be activated, as needed, by the jurisdiction thati is to receive assistance or upon commencement of exercises or training for mutual aid and continue as long as the exercises or training for mutual aid are in progress, the emergency or disaster remains in effect or loaned resources remain in the receiving jurisdiction or jurisdictions, whicheveri is longer. The receiving jurisdiction is responsible for informing the assisting jurisdictions of the specific moment when services will no longer be required. Licenses and Permits - Article V Whenever a person holds a license, certificate or other permit issued by any. jurisdiction party to the compact evidencing the meeting of qualifications for professional, mechanical or other skills, and when such assistance is requested by the receiving party. jurisdiction, such person is deemed to be licensed, certified or permitted by the jurisdiction requesting assistance to render aid involving such skill to meet an emergency or disaster, subject to such limitations and conditions as the requesting jurisdiction prescribes by executive order or otherwise. Liability - Article VI Any person or entity of a party jurisdiction rendering aid in another jurisdiction pursuant to this compact: are considered agents of the requesting, jurisdiction for tort liability and immunity purposes.. Any person or entity rendering aid in another jurisdiction pursuant to this compact are notl liable on account of any act or omission in good faith on the part of such forces while so engaged or on account of the maintenance or use of any equipment or supplies in connection therewith. Good faith in this article does noti include willful misconduct, gross negligence or recklessness.

PES URGENCES Supplementary Agreements - Article VII Because iti is probable that the pattern and detail of the machinery for mutual aid among two or more jurisdictions may differ from that among thej jurisdictions that are party to this compact, this compact contains elements of al broad base common to all jurisdictions, and nothing in this compact precludes any jurisdiction from entering into supplementary agreements with another jurisdiction or affects any other agreements already in force among jurisdictions. Supplementary agreements may include, but are not limited to, provisions for evacuation and reception of injured and other persons and the exchange of medical, fire, public utility, reconnaissance, welfare, transportation and communications personnel, equipment and supplies. Workers' Compensation and Death Benefits - Article VIII Each party jurisdiction shall provide, in accordance with its own laws, for the payment of workers' compensation and death benefits to injured members of the emergency forces of that jurisdiction and to representatives of deceased members of those forces if the members sustain injuries or are killed while rendering aid pursuant to this compact, in the same manner and on the same terms as if the injury or death were sustained within their own jurisdiction. Reimbursement - Article IX Any party jurisdiction rendering aid in another jurisdiction pursuant to this compact shall, if requested, be reimbursed by thej party. jurisdiction receiving such aid for any loss or damage to or expense incurred in the operation of any equipment and the provision of any service in answering a request for aid and for the costs incurred in connection with those requests. An aiding party jurisdiction may assume in whole or in part any such loss, damage, expense or other cost or may loan such equipment or donate such services to the receiving party jurisdiction without charge or cost. Any two or more party. jurisdictions may enter into supplementary agreements establishing a different allocation of costs among those jurisdictions. Expenses under article VIII are not reimbursable under this section. Evacuation - Article X Each party. jurisdiction shall initiate a process to prepare and maintain plans to facilitate the movement of and reception of evacuees into its territory or across its territory, according to its capabilities and powers. The party jurisdiction from which the evacuees came shall assume the ultimate responsibility for the support of the evacuees, and after the termination of the emergency or disaster, for the repatriation of such evacuees. Implementation - Article XI 1. This compact is effective upon its execution or adoption by any twoj jurisdictions, and is effective as to any other jurisdiction upon its execution or adoption thereby: subject to approval or authorization by the U.S. Congress, if required, and subject to enactment of provincial or state legislation that may be required for the effectiveness of the Memorandum of Understanding. 2. Any party. jurisdiction may withdraw from this compact, butt the withdrawal does not take effect until 30 days after the governor or premier of the withdrawing jurisdiction has given notice in writing of such withdrawal to the governors or premiers of all other party. jurisdictions. Article I, Section 10 of the Constitution. The MOU describes itself as a "compact," and although the parties use the term "Memorandum of Understanding" in the title, that choice is unlikely to affect categorization for constitutional purposes. See U.S. Steel Corp. V. Multistate Tax Comm'n, 434 U.S. 452, 470-71 (1978) (explaining that a commitment's formalities are irrelevant to whether it falls within the scope of the Compact Clause). Second, the MOU is atypical in the sense that it received congressional consent. See Pub. L. Twenty-fifth Annual Conference Vingt-cinquieme conférence annuelle of the New England Governors des Gouvemeurs de la Nouvelle- and the Angleterre et des Premiers ministres Eastern Canadian Premiers de I'Est du Canada L Halifax, Nova Scotia. Halifax (Nouvelle Écosse) July 16. 17 & 18, 2000 Les 16, 17 et 18 juillet 2000 IEMAMOU. Letter of Intent WHEREAS, the Conference ofNew England Governors and Eastern Canadian Premiers is committed to providing the possibility of mutual assistance among the states and provinces in managing any emergency or disaster that calls for such mutual assistance; and WHEREAS, there presently exists a single, standardized, national compact called the Emergency Management Assistance Compact (EMAC) in the United States to provide for mutual assistance among the states that can be used as a model for the Conference of New England Governors and Eastern Canadian Premiers; and WHEREAS, the New England Governors have adopted a similar resolution and a number ofNcw England states have enacted necessary legislation to ratify an Emergency Management Assistance Compact (EMAC) between the New England states; and WHEREAS, agreements between certain individual states and provinces already exist including the Atlantic Provinces' Agreement on Cooperation in Emergencies; and WHEREAS, an International Emergency Management Assistance Memorandum of Understanding (IEMAMOU) is desirabie because few, if any, individual states or provinces have all the resources needed to respond to all types of disasters and large scale emergencies; and WHEREAS, an IEMAMOU allows for swift response when reacting to thc safety, care and welfare of the public in time of disaster; THEREFORE, on behalfof the State ofl Rhode Island, this letter expresses our intent to fully participate in the Memorandum ofUnderstanding, to introduce legislation necessary for the State to join, and to become a party when such legisiation is enacted. 11 Signed this d day ofJuly, 2000 at Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada. Governor Lincoln Almond State ofRhode Island

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING among The Regents of the University of California, The California Energy Commission, The California Public Utilities Commission, and The Forum of Regulators, India Concerning Collaborations in the Areas of Electricity Demand and Supply and Efficiency Improvement This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is among The Regents of the University of California, in its capacity as the manager and operator of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (hereinafter referred to as "LBNL"), the California Energy Commission, the California Public Utilities Commission, and the Forum of Regulators, India. LBNL is a U.S. Department of Energy National Laboratory managed and operated by The Regents of the University of California pursuant to Contract No. DE-AC02-05CH11231 (Contract 31). The California Energy Commission is a California Government entity, having its office at Sacramento, California (hereinafter referred to as "CEC"). The California Public Utilities Commission is also a California Government entity, having its office at San Francisco, California (hereinafter referred to as "CPUC). The Forum of Regulators, India is a Government of India entity, having its office at New Delhi, India (hereinafter referred to as "FOR"). For purposes of this MOU, LBNL, CEC, CPUC and FOR are collectively herein referred to as "Participants" or separately as "Participant". Have reached the following understanding: 1. Objective The objective of this MOU is to explore potential future collaboration among the Participants in the field of energy sector planning from various perspectives, including but not limited to providing energy access to all, ensuring affordability, enhancing energy security, and meeting environmental goals. 2

iv) This MOU does not create any legally binding obligations. Signed at) pleu on 28 2014 in four (4) original in the English language. For Armenia: Advisor to the Minister of Economy Nothing in this Framework Agreement limits the right of either Party to establish similar agreements with other entities, nor does cooperation pursuant to this Framework Agreement affect the rights and/or obligations of the Parties under other international agreements. Article 5 Final Provisions This Framework Agreement shall become effective upon its signature, and shall remain in effect for an indefinite duration, subject to the provisions below. This Framework Agreement may be modified at any time by mutual consent of the Parties. Any modification shall be made in writing and specify the date on which such modification is to become effective. Either Party may withdraw from this Framework Agreement at any time by providing thirty (30) days advance written notice to the other Party. Signed in New York on September 24th, 2019, in two original copies, each in the Armenian and English languages. Both texts are equally authentic. ON BEHALF OF THE GOVERNMENT ON BEHALF OF THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA OF THE REPUBLIC OF ARMENIA Governor Minister of Foreign Affairs Gavin Néwsom Zohrab Mnatsakanyan

would serve as a platform to provide information and contacts for entrepreneurs from both California and Armenia who wish to connect with counterparts in order to engage in trade and/or commercial activities in either goods and/or services or both. The Parties intend to encourage the work of non-governmental organizations in Armenia and will seek to help them to develop capabilities and build support through exchanges with similarly oriented non-governmental organizations in California. Article 4 Interpretation and Implementation This Framework Agreement serves only as a record of the Parties' intentions and does not constitute or create any legally binding or enforceable rights or obligations, implied or expressed. This Framework Agreement does not involve the exchange of funds, nor does it represent any obligation of funds by the Parties. All costs that may be undertaken pursuant to this Framework Agreement will be assumed by the Parties that incurs them, unless otherwise agreed by future written agreement. All activities referenced in this Framework Agreement are subject to the availability of the required resources on the part of Parties, and may be subject to appropriation by the relevant legislative body of the respective Party. Any personnel designated or assigned to implement activities referenced in this Framework Agreement shall work under the direction and responsibility of the organization or institution by whom they are employed or contractually retained and will at all times maintain their employment or contractual relationship with that organization or institution. Their work on activities to implement this Framework Agreement will not create an employer-employee relationship with any other organization or institution or with the Parties, and in no case shall any other organization or institution be considered as a substitute or joint employer of the designated or assigned personnel. All activities undertaken pursuant to this Framework Agreement, and all personnel designated or assigned to implement activities referenced in this Framework Agreement are subject to the applicable laws of the receiving country. The respective Points of Contact for each Party concerning all communications or information exchanges for this Framework Agreement shall be the following: For California: Senior Advisor for International Affairs and Trade Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development

State of Washington 2 Province of British Columbia Forest Memorandum oflnderstanding The State of Washington and the Province of British Columbia share similar benefits, challenges, and opportunities associated with a large amount of our lands in forested ecosystems. In the spirit of mutually improving our forest health conditions, adapting to climate change, increasing capacity and effectiveness for wildfire protection, and producing bio-energy from forest products, the signatories agree to: Work cooperatively with Washington and British Columbia counterparts to share research, data and information on how climate change will likely affect forest health, and share strategies to achieve healthy forest ecosystems in the future. Through aj joint meeting this fall, this cooperative work willa lalso explore opportunities for cross-border demonstration projects, and share approaches on carbon life-cycle modeling and carbon sequestration accounting. Under existing cooperative agreements on cross-border fire protection, recognize that declining forest health and climate change likely will lead to larger and more frequent wildfires. We wills seek opportunities to share strategic outlooks, fire prevention plans and complementary expertise on forest fuels management, prevention, pre-suppression, and suppression actions. Seek opportunities to share data, technical approaches and joint research projects to produce renewable energy andj fuel products from the large amounts of woody biomass now found in many of our forests. The production of renewable energy from low-value wood can also contribute to rural economic development, reduced wildfire risk and improved forest health. AGREED as to form and content and signed and dated in two (2) duplicate originals in Seattle, Washington, this day of June, 2007 Douglas Sutherland Rich Coleman Commissioner of Public Lands Minister of Forests and Range State of Washington Province of British Columbia

THEREFORE, THE PARTNERS PLEDGE THEIR INTENTION TO: 1. Share and explore innovations in fuel management methods, including prescribed and managed fire, pre-fire management, post-fire restoration, post-treatment monitoring and evaluation, tools and equipment, best practices, and technology to mitigate and lessen the negative effects of increased wildfires and tree mortality. 2. Share and explore innovations in climate-informed reforestation, including strategies for climate- adapted species, genotypes, planting techniques, and ongoing management needs. 3. Share and explore approaches to evaluate and account: for changes in forest carbon over time. 4. Share and explore advances in forest-related science and data collection to better understand how forests are responding to changes in climatic conditions. 5. Share and explore innovations in low-carbon emitting, or carbon sequestering, utilization ofl harvested wood products removed from the forest through forest management or restoration activities. 6. Share and explore incentive mechanisms to reduce conversion of forestland to non-forest uses, establish afforestation projects, increase carbon sequestration and storage in urban forests, and promote carbon-rich, climate resilient forests. 7. Share and explore opportunities for investments in natural and working lands that increase carbon sequestration, enhance forest resilience, encourage multi-benefit forest uses, and support natural resource dependent communities. Date 12/18/18 Hilary Franz Comnissioner of Public Lands Washington State Department of Natural Resources The State of Washington UA Date_ 12/18/18 John Laird, Secretary California Natural Resources The State of California Date_ 12/18/18 Doug Donaldson, Minister British Columbia Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development The Province of British Columbia Date_ 11/05/19 Petér Daugherty, Oregon State Forester Oregon Department of Forestry The State of Oregon

PE RE A#F# PIndiana Ministry of Education DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AT Republic of China (Taiwan) Memorandum of Agreement between The Indiana Department of Education, USA and The Department of International and Cross-Strait Education, Ministry of Education, Republic of China (Taiwan) The Indiana Department of Education, United States of America and the Department of International and Cross-Strait Education, Ministry of Education, Republic of China (Taiwan), hereinafter referred to as "the Parties", agree to enter into a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) on education, in order to strengthen education linkages between Indiana and Taiwan. The Parties have: reached the following Agreement: Article 1: Purposes The Parties will pursue the formulation and implementation of work plans through which they may achieve the following purposes: to maintain and enhance bilateral co-operation in educational matters; to promote mutual understanding; and to realize common benefits and collaboration. Article 2: Activities The Parties agree to pursue, through this MOA, these activities: (1) The promotion ofj joint projects between educators in Indiana and educators in Taiwan. (2) The encouragement of joint and collaborative efforts in the language teaching field. These efforts may include assistance with the recruitment of language teachers, exchange of curricular materials, and technical assistance. 1

(3) Encouragement of educational and academic exchanges between individuals and educational institutions in the State of Indiana and in Taiwan. Article 3: Coordination and Implementation (1) Officials Responsible for Implementation Responsibility for coordinating activities and communication concerning this MOA will lie with the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State of Indiana, and with the Director General ofthe Department of International and Cross-Strait Education of the Ministry of Education in Taiwan, and their designated representatives. (2) Working Groups Each of the Parties will form a non-official Working Group for implementing this MOA. The Working Groups will communicate with each other, as needed, to implement work plans and will meet with each other in person or using online electronic media at least once a year. (3) Work Plans Each of the Parties will formulate an annual work plan to coordinate the work it is undertaking pursuant to this MOA. The nature and priority status of specific areas of cooperation, the types of activities, and the facilitation and promotion of the annual work plans being implemented under this MOA will be determined by the Working Groups. (4) Involvement of Other Organizations The Parties will promote, facilitate, and encourage, as appropriate, the development of direct contacts with and between related organizations, in association with co-operative language teaching projects. Article 4: Costs Any questions regarding the expenses associated with any activity under this MOA will be settled by negotiation between the participants involved prior to the start oft that activity. Unless otherwise agreed between the Parties, each 2

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING (MOU) FOR ESTABLISHING AN AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE ARKANSAS AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENT, USA AND GHANA MINISTRY OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE, THE REPUBLIC OF GHANA The Arkansas Agriculture Department, State of Arkansas of the United States of America and the Ghana Ministry of Food and Agriculture of the Republic of Ghana have agreed, on the basis of friendly cooperation, equality and mutual benefit, to continue to develop relationships to promote and broaden agricultural development, cooperation, and cultural exchanges between the two sides. The two sides will identify themes, common to both, that can generate new initiatives to foster and encourage science and technological innovation, agriculture, trade, commerce, cultural, and environmental activities between the parties. The long-term goal is to strengthen the bond for agricultural development and to enhance partnership between the government of Arkansas and Ghana. Regular contacts shall be maintained between the leaders of the two sides to facilitate consultations on the exchanges and cooperation as well as matters of common concern. This Agreement shall be officially established and shall become effective from the date of signature. This Agreement shall be in full force and effective for a period of 5 years. However, the Republic of Ghana and the State of Arkansas may terminate this Agreement at any time during the Agreement period by providing 30 days' written notice.

DG Missouril Department of Commerce & Insurance Confidentiality Agreement for the 2020 meetings of the College of Supervisors of Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporated The Missouri Department of Commerce and Insurance (DCI) and the Authorities listed in Schedule A attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference (herein referred to collectively as the "Authorities") enter into this agreement for the purpose of exchanging confidential supervisory information pertaining to the Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporated (RGA), and its regulated/non-regulated affiliates, for any telephone conference call(s) or meeting of the College of RGA Supervisors during 2020. This agreement also applies to confidential supervisory information shared in preparation for, or as an immediate result of, all 2020 telephone conference call(s) and the 2020 meeting of the College of RGA Supervisors. Confidential supervisory information in connection with the 2020 meeting of the College of RGA Supervisors means any supervisory information whether written or spoken, and regardless of its format. All confidential supervisory information furnished under this agreement remains the property of the party that provided the information. The sharing of confidential supervisory information in connection with the Supervisory College shall not be deemed a waiver of any privilege or claim of confidentiality by any party to this agreement. Authorities listed in Schedule A who are signatories to the IAIS MMOU on Cooperation and Information Exchange will share information obtained in connection with the 2020 meeting of the College of RGA Supervisors pursuant to the terms of the IAIS MMOU. The Authorities who sign Schedule A (herein referred to as "Signatory Authorities") each confirm: (1) their agreement to use any confidential supervisory information received in connection with the Supervisory College only for lawful supervisory purposes; (2) their authority and intent, under the relevant laws, rules and regulations of their respective jurisdiction, to protect from disclosure and otherwise preserve the confidential and/or privileged nature of any confidential supervisory information received in connection with the Supervisory College; and (3) their authority to share confidential supervisory information pertaining to Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporated with each of the Supervisors of the Group. The Signatory Authorities shall not disclose confidential supervisory information obtained in connection with the 2020 meeting of the College of RGA Supervisors unless required to do so by applicable law. Prior to disclosing any information, the Signatory Authority will notify the Authority that provided the information of the request for disclosure. If the Authority that provided the information does not consent to disclosure of the information, the Signatory Authority will use all reasonable legal means to protect the confidentiality of the information, and will consent to an application by the Authority that provided the information to intervene in any action for the purpose of asserting a claim of confidentiality.

GOBIERNO MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING DELI ESTADO A between THE STATE OF TEXAS and THE FREE AND SOVEREIGN STATE OF TAMAULIPAS MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING made by and between the State of Texas and the Free and Sovereign State of Tamaulipas ("Memorandum"). The State of Texas is referred to as "Texas"; the Free and Sovereign State of Tamaulipas is referred to as "Tamaulipas"; individually, each party may be referred to as a "State"; and collectively, the parties are referred to as' "States." WHEREAS, the States have a mutual interest in ensuring that their shared border is secure; and WHEREAS, Texas anticipates a significant rise in cartel-facilitated smuggling through the use of unsafe vehicles due to President Biden's decision to end Title 42 expulsions; and WHEREAS, Texas has implemented enhanced safety inspections of vehicles as they cross international ports of entry to reduce the number of unsafe vehicles that enter Texas; and WHEREAS, these inspections which have revealed that almost 25% of the commercial vehicles that crossed into Texas were unsafe have slowed border crossings for commercial vehicles; and WHEREAS, given the importance of trade between Texas and Tamaulipas, it is in the best interests ofthe States to enter into this Memorandum; NOW, THEREFORE, be it resolved that Texas and Tamaulipas will reduce the number ofunsafe vehicles approaching the border, and the corresponding need for enhanced safety inspections, by using their best efforts as follows: 1. The States will work cooperatively to ensure that vehicles crossing an international port of entry meet the safety standards applicable in each State. 2. The States will work cooperatively to reduce the cartels' human trafficking and smuggling of deadly fentanyl and other drugs across and between ports ofentry. 3. The States will work cooperatively to stop the flow of migrants who illegally enter Texas through Tamaulipas. 4. Tamaulipas will enhance border security enforcement measures on the Tamaulipas side ofthe border, both at points of entry and along the Rio Grande, to prevent illegal immigration from Tamaulipas into Texas by committing to the following:

a. Operate checkpoints already established in different parts of the State in order to detect the arrival of immigrants before they enter Tamaulipas. Once migrants are detected at these checkpoints they will be returned to the federal immigration authorities. b. At the Municipal level, in both borders, special teams of personnel and motor equipment will be designated to prevent the crossing ofimmigrants arriving at the ports ofl Nuevo Laredo, Miguel Alemân, Camargo, Reynosa, Nuevo Progreso, and Matamoros, in order to ensure that no migrant shall cross the border at those locations - including providing resources to respond to hot spot areas as identified by the Texas Department of Public Safety. C. In particular, Tamaulipas will devote the resources, personnel and tactics necessary to prevent and disrupt illegal crossings in low water areas, into Hidalgo County and Starr County. 5. In particular, Tamaulipas will enhance existing checkpoints in Tula (on the border with the State of San Luis Potosi), Moralillo (border with the State of Veracruz), Periquitos (Police Station, road leading to Reynosa), Gonzâlez Villarreal (Police Station, leading to Matamoros) and in Ciudad Victoria (Police Station near the Airport). 6. In addition, the establishment ofjoint and recurrent river operations along the Rio Grande from Hidalgo County to Starr County in an effort to curb illegal activities including human trafficking, and drug smuggling while disrupting organized crime activities. 7. Tamaulipas will use its newly inaugurated C5 (command, control, computers, communications, cyber-defense) facility in Reynosa to surveille crossing points and high traffic areas along the Rio Grande and share information with the Texas Department of Public Safety as appropriate to use as a first alert system. 8. The States will work cooperatively to restore the border-crossing inspections process to allow crossings at a faster pace. This Memorandum may be modified by mutual consent ofthe States in writing. Notwithstanding any other provision in this Memorandum, the Memorandum may be terminated by either State upon written notice thirty days before the date of termination. FOR THE STATE OF TEXAS FOR THE STATED DF - Aegptkn GOVERNOR GREG ABBOTT GOI RNOR FRANCISCOGARCIA CABEZA PA VACA

4. Chihuahua has begun and will continue enhanced border security enforcement measures on the Chihuahua side of the border, both at ports ofentry and along the Rio Grande River, to prevent illegal immigration from Chihuahua into Texas. These measures will include the Sentinel Platform, which is a technological investment of approximately $200,000,000.00 US that will allow Chihuahua State Police to track vehicles from the moment they leave an industrial park in Juarez until they cross the border into Texas. In addition, the State of Chihuahua is incorporating technologies such as drones to patrol the border, AI databases connected to the driver license registry, and biometric filters to assist in the capture of cartel leaders. 5. The States will work cooperatively to restore the border-crossing inspections process to allow crossings at a faster pace. This Memorandum may be modified by mutual consent of the States in writing. Notwithstanding any other provision in this Memorandum, the Memorandum may be terminated by either State upon written notice thirty days before the date of termination. FOR THE STATE OF TEXAS FOR THE STATE OF CHIHUAHUA GOVERNOR GFEG ABBOTT GOVERNOR MARU CAMPOS

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING between THE STATE OF TEXAS and THE FREE AND SOVEREIGN STATE OF COAHUILA DE ZARAGOZA MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING made by and between the State of Texas and the Free and Sovereign State of Coahuila de Zaragoza ("Memorandum"). The State of Texas is referred to as "Texas"; the Free and Sovereign State of Coahuila de Zaragoza is referred to as "Coahuila"; individually, each party may be referred to as a "State"; and collectively, the parties are referred to as "States." WHEREAS, the States have a mutual interest in ensuring that their shared border is secure; and WHEREAS, Texas anticipates a significant rise in cartel-facilitated smuggling through the use of unsafe vehicles due to President Biden's decision to end Title 42 expulsions; and WHEREAS, Texas has implemented enhanced safety inspections of vehicles as they cross international ports of entry to reduce the number of unsafe vehicles that enter Texas; and WHEREAS, these inspections- - which have revealed that almost 25% of the commercial vehicles that crossed into Texas were unsafe have slowed border crossings for commercial vehicles; and WHEREAS, given the importance of trade between Texas and Coahuila, it is in the best interests of the States to enter into this Memorandum; NOW, THEREFORE, be it resolved that Texas and Coahuila will reduce the number of unsafe vehicles approaching the border, and the corresponding need for enhanced safety inspections, by using their best efforts as follows: 1. The States will work cooperatively to ensure that vehicles crossing an international port of entry meet the safety standards applicable in each State. 2. The States will work cooperatively to reduce the cartels' human trafficking and smuggling of deadly fentanyl and other drugs across and between ports of entry. 3. The States will work cooperatively to stop the flow of migrants who illegally enter Texas through Coahuila. 4. Coahuila will enhance border security enforcement measures on the Coahuila side of the border, both at ports of entry and along the Rio Grande River, to prevent illegal immigration from Coahuila into Texas by committing to the following:

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING CHIHUAHUA GOBIERNO o DEL ESTA * between Juntos sipodemos THE STATE OF TEXAS and THE FREE AND SOVEREIGN STATE OF CHIHUAHUA MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING made by and between the State of Texas and the Free and Sovereign State of Chihuahua ("Memorandum"). The State of Texas is referred to as "Texas;" the Free and Sovereign State of Chihuahua is referred to as "Chihuahua," individually, each party may be referred to as a "State," and collectively, the parties are referred to as "States.' 17 WHEREAS, the States have a mutual interest in ensuring that their shared border is secure; and WHEREAS, Texas anticipates a significant rise in cartel-facilitated smuggling through the use of unsafe vehicles due to federal government's decision to end Title 42 expulsions; and WHEREAS, Texas has implemented enhanced safety inspections of vehicles as they cross international ports of entry to reduce the number of unsafe vehicles that enter Texas; WHEREAS, Texas recognizes the leadership and unparalleled efforts of the Governor and the State of Chihuahua to improve and ensure security along the border of Chihuahua and Texas, as evidenced by attachments A and B; WHEREAS, This agreement and the efforts of Chihuahua and Texas represent a new era in our relationship as border states; and WHEREAS, these inspections- which have revealed that almost 25% of the commercial vehicles that crossed into Texas were unsafe- have slowed border crossings for commercial vehicles; and WHEREAS, given the importance of trade between Texas and Chihuahua, it is in the best interests of the States to enter into this Memorandum; NOW, THEREFORE, be it resolved that Texas and Chihuahua will reduce the number of unsafe vehicles approaching the border, and the corresponding need for enhanced safety inspections, by using their best efforts as follows: 1. The States will work cooperatively to ensure that vehicles crossing an international port of entry meet the safety standards applicable in each State. 2. The States will work cooperatively to reduce the cartels' human trafficking and smuggling of deadly fentanyl and other drugs across and between ports of entry. 3. The States will work cooperatively to stop the flow of migrants from over 100 countries who illegally enter Texas through Chihuahua - including providing resources to respond to hot spot areas as identified by the Texas Department of Public Safety.

EL GOMIERNO DEL NUEVO NUEVOLEON MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING between THE STATE OF TEXAS and THE FREE AND SOVEREIGN STATE OF NUEVO LEON MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING made by and between the State of Texas and thel Free and Sovereign State of Nuevo Leon ("Memorandum"). The State of Texas is referred to as "Texas"; thel Freea and SovereignState of Nuevo Leon is referredtoas' "Nuevo Leon' , individually, each party may be referred to as a "State' "; and collectively, the parties are referred to as "States." WHEREAS, the States have a mutual interest in ensuring that their shared border is secure; and WHEREAS, Texas anticipates a significant rise in cartel-facilitated smuggling through the use of unsafe vehicles due to President Biden's decision to end Title 42 expulsions; and WHEREAS, Texas has implemented enhanced safety inspections of vehicles as they cross international ports of entry to reduce the number of unsafe vehicles that enter Texas; and WHEREAS, these inspections-which have revealed that almost 25% of the vehicles that crossed into Texas were unsafe- have slowed border crossings for commercial vehicles: and WHEREAS, given the importance of trade between Texas and Nuevo Leon, it is in the best interests of the: States to enter into this Memorandum; NOW,THEREFORE, be it resolved that Texas and Nuevo Leôn will reduce the number of threats to the public by vehicles approaching the border, and the corresponding need for enhanced safety inspections, by using their best efforts as follows: 1. The States will work cooperatively to ensure that vehicles crossing an international port of entry meet the safety standards applicable in cach State. 2. The States will work cooperatively to reduce the cartels' human trafficking and smuggling of deadly fentanyl and other drugs across and between ports of entry. 3. The States will work cooperatively to stem the flow of migrants from over 100 countries who illegally enter Texas through Nuevol Leon. 4. Nuevo Leôn has begun and will continue enhanced border security enforcement measures

a. Operate checkpoints already established in different parts of the State in order to detect the arrival of immigrants before they enter Coahuila. Once migrants are detected at these checkpoints they will be returned to a designated place in Mexico. b. At the Municipal level, in both borders, special teams of personnel and motor equipment will be designated to prevent the crossing of immigrants arriving at the ports of Ciudad Acuna and/or Piedras Negras, in order to ensure that no migrant shall cross the border at those locations - including providing resources to respond to hot spot areas as identified by the Texas Department of Public Safety. This effort includes using helicopters and all terrain vehicles to patrol the border. 5. The States will work cooperatively to restore the border-crossing inspections process to allow crossings at a faster pace. This Memorandum may be modified by mutual consent of the States in writing. Notwithstanding any other provision in this Memorandum, the Memorandum may be terminated by either State upon written notice thirty days before the date of termination. FRAMEWORK AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF ARMENIA THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF ARMENIA (hereinafter "the Parties") RECOGNIZE THAT: WHEREAS, the Republic of Armenia and the State of California share close ties and California is home to the largest Armenian Community in the United States; and WHEREAS, the Parties seek to expand the current level of cooperation between Armenia and California in, but not limited to, the fields of trade and commerce, alternative energy, environmental technology, information technologies, health, food and agriculture, tourism, higher education and science and other technology-based industry sectors, business innovation, research and development; and WHEREAS, the State of California's University of California was instrumental in the founding of the American University of Armenia and has had an ongoing, longstanding, deep and beneficial relationship with the American University of Armenia since its earliest days; and WHEREAS, the State of California is home to the largest public university system in the United States and the largest in-state innovation network in the United States, which offer educational templates and technology-commercialization opportunities for the Republic of Armenia. Have agreed upon the following: Article 1 Objective The Parties hereby sign this Framework Agreement for the purposes of fostering economic cooperation and development, facilitating joint research and development, and enhancing business relationships and educational opportunities that will, in turn, foster job creation and incubate global solutions from joint Armenia-California innovation initiatives. 1 The factors that drive states to enter into commitments with particular foreign jurisdictions are not entirely clear, but the preamble of this commitment suggests that ethnic ties exert influence in some cases.

Article 2 Areas of Cooperation The Parties plan to facilitate collaborations between Armenian and Californian educators, entrepreneurs and researchers through the encouragement of exhibitions, seminars and visits. The Parties intend to support and encourage further development of interpersonal contacts and exchanges, and promotion of mutual cooperation, understanding, and friendship through ad hoc academic collaboration, trade delegations, and professional exchanges between Armenia and California in key sectors including, but not limited to: a.) Water Conservation and Management b.) Alternative Energy and Related Clean Technologies c.) Health and Biotechnology d.) Information Technologies e.) Trade and Commerce f.) Arts and Culture g.) Higher Education h.) Agricultural Technologies i.) Tourism j.) Emergency Preparedness and Response Article 3 Specific Activities The Parties intend to encourage the creation of public-private partnerships between Armenian and Californian entities in the areas of higher education, economic development, social entrepreneurship, or academic research related to the above activities. The Parties intend to encourage the strengthening of sister city programs between Armenia and California cities, which are designed to enhance opportunities for people-to- people cultural and educational exchanges, economic partnerships, and social entrepreneurship on the local level. The Parties intend to encourage continued collaboration between Armenia and California universities, public and private research institutions. The Parties intend to welcome trade and tourism promotion officials and delegations. To this end, the State of California intends to establish a Trade and Services Desk in Armenia to be utilized on an as-needed basis by California's trade representative for Europe and Eurasia to promote and encourage two-way trade and investment by Californian and Armenian businesses and enterprises. The Trade and Services desk

MEMORANDUM OF INTENT BETWEEN THE STATE OF ALABAMA AND THE MINISTRY OF INDUSTRY AND TRADE OF THE STATE OF ISRAEL WHEREAS the prospects for expanded economic cooperation between the two States are excellent and, as a result, their economic structures will mutually benefit; WHEREAS the State of Alabama and the State of Israel each have important responsibilities for encouraging the growth of trade and investment relations within the framework of a free enterprise economy; THEREFORE, IT IS AGREED between the State of Alabama through the Alabama Development Office and the State of Israel through the Ministry of Industry and Trade: 1. To improve trade relationships between companies in Alabama and those in Israel. 2. To encourage and facilitate cooperation between companies in each of the two States. 3. To encourage investments between Alabama and Israel for their mutual benefit. 4. To encourage and expand the transfer oftechnology between Alabama and Israel. 5. To promote the exchange of ideas between various businesses, trade associations, business agencies and commercial institutions within the two States. 6. To notify each other of trade fairs and exhibitions, investment seminars, and other business-related conferences to be held in Israel and Alabama. 7. To promote the exchange of visits of company representatives, engineers, scientists and other specialists.

Whereas: It is agreed by and between the Alabama Development Office (hereinafter referred to as ADO) and the WirtschaftsfOrderung Brandenburg GmbH (hereinafter referred to as WFB), the parties hereto, that the prospects for expanded ecenomic cooperation between Brandenburg and Alabama are excellent and give promise of yielding substantial mutual benefits based on the complentary economic structure of the two states; and Whereas: the ADO and the WFB each bear important responsibilities for encouraging the growth of trade and investment relations within the frameworks of a free enterprise economy; Now, Therefore, It is agreed between ADO and WFB that each will take necessary steps to: 1. Promote mutual understanding and cooperation between the respective private sector business communities of Alabama and Brandenburg in the fields of trade, technology transfer and investment relations. 2. Exchange and disseminate relevant business and economic information, on goods and services that are available from the other country to businessmen of their respective countries. 3. Notify each other of trade exhibitions and investment seminars to be held in each party's respective state, and render appropriate and timely assistance when requested.

Partnership Agreement Between the State of Alabama and Abia State, Nigeria Based on the bonds of friendship that are shared between the states in Nigeria and the United States, and considering the opportunity and desire to forge relations between the States of Alabama and Abia, and considering that both states are capable of strengthening further the bonds off fraternity and experience. The States of Abia and Alabama hereby subscribe to an Alliance'to serve as a guide for establishing a mutually beneficial relationship that will succeed in areas where common interest ares shared. The goals ofthe agreement are asi follows: 1. To declare an Alliance between Alabama and Abia, that will further strengthen the friendship betweent the two: states. 2. To promote exchanges ofi information and to foster the exchanges oft the culture, history and traditions and business exchanges between thet two states. 3. To support the expansion of commerce relations through promoting economic development and encouraging new business transactions within our two respective regions. 4. To offer supportt toi investors within the two states, to promote more prosperous business relationships and to advocate and facilitate meetings and exchanges between the business sectors within both states toj provide them with a competitive edgei in the global economy. 5. To promote exchanges in the areas of human resources, programs of economic development, social welfare sectors, heightening informational exchanges between both communities regarding themes surrounding education, health, sports, ecology, the environment and the general planning and development of the needs surrounding the urban infrastructure: and technology. 6. Collaborated programs and projects that are established within the different limits of action will servet to complement this agreement. The State of Alabama and. Abia State, through their respective governments, have executed this agreement with their signature on the date written below. GIVEN UNDER OUR HANDS and the Great Seal of the a Governor's Office at the State Capitol in the City of Montgomery on the 9t day ofMay. 2000. Don Siegelmarl Orji Uzor Kalu, M.O.N. Governor Governor State ofAlabama Abia State 1 Article I, Section 10 of the U.S. Constitution prohibits states from entering into any "Treaty, Alliance, or Confederation." To prevent uncertainty about compliance with this provision, states should generally avoid characterizing any relationship with a foreign government as an "alliance."

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING STATE OF ALABAMA, THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA AND JIANGSU PROVINCE, THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA Background Based on the bonds of friendship and in the spirit of common development, the State of Alabama and Jiangsu Province have henceforth agreed to enter into the Memorandum of Understanding. This document serves to promote and expand effective and mutually beneficial cooperation and exchanges between the two territories. Objective The goals of the agreement are as follows: 1. To facilitate trade between the industrial and services sectors of Alabama and Jiangsu, promote investments, expand technology transfers, and advance research and development; 2. To advocate the exchange of ideas between various businesses, trade associations, business agencies, and commercial institutions by maintaining information channels between. Alabama and Jiangsu; 3. To gain reciprocal understanding of emerging industries in Alabama and Jiangsu, such as biotechnology, agricultural technology, information technologies, etc.; 4. To identify economic needs in both territories and how these needs can be met through bilateral cooperation. Agreed Areas of Cooperation Both parties agree to advance cooperation in the following key fields 1. Advanced manufacturing, especially auto 2. Life sciences, including biotechnology, bio medicine and research 3. High technology, including information technology 4. Higher education, including, joint training and degree programs 5. Energy 1 In recent decades, U.S. states have entered into a collection of well over a dozen commitments with China for the express purpose of facilitating technology transfer, including in strategically sensitive areas such as biotechnology, nanotechnology, information technology, aerospace, and semiconductors. Alabama's pledge to "expand technology transfers" in the fields of biotechnology

To improve the trade relationships of the entrepreneurs of each of the two states. 2. To support and facilitate cooperation between entrepreneurs of the two states. 3. To facilitate investment of entrepreneurs of the two states for the mutual benefit of both states. 4. To encourage and expand the transfer of technology between the two states to the mutual benefit of both states. 5. To promote tourism and travel opportunities for and between the peoples of both states. 6. To promote the exchange of ideas between various businesses, trade associations, business agencies, and commercial institutions within both states. 7. To cooperate in the fields of post-secondary education and industrial training. 8. Confidentiality Agreement College of Supervisors of The Travelers Companies, Inc. The Connecticut Insurance Department ("CID"), as lead regulator ofThe Travelers Companies, Inc. ("The Travelers") insurance holding company system and other regulators of The Travelers and its regulated affiliates (collectively "The Travelers Regulators"; each "The Travelers Regulator") enter into this Confidentiality Agreement ("Agreement") for exchanging confidential information pertaining to The Travelers and its regulated and non-regulated affiliates on a reciprocal basis within the framework ofthe Supervisory College of The Travelers. This Agreement applies to confidential information shared in preparation for the meetings ofthe Supervisory College of The Travelers or as a result of such meetings. For the purpose ofthis Agreement, confidential information means any information regarded as confidential, privileged or otherwise protected from disclosure under the laws applicable to the insurance regulator that is the source of the documents, materials or information. The CID and The Travelers Regulators who are parties to this Agreement acknowledge that this Agreement does not create any legally binding obligations, confer any rights, modify, or supersede any domestic laws or regulatory requirements in force in, or applying to, their respective jurisdiction and does not confer upon any person the right or ability, directly or indirectly, to obtain, suppress or exclude any information. This Agreement is not intended to affect any arrangements under any other agreements or memoranda of understanding in existence to which any ofThe Travelers Regulators is a party. All confidential information, in whatever form, furnished under this Agreement remains the property ofthe party that provided the information. By signing below the CID and each The Travelers Regulator confirm (1) their agreement to use any confidential supervisory information received in connection with the Supervisory College of The Travelers only for lawful supervisory purposes, (2) their authority and intent, under the laws oftheir respective jurisdiction, to protect from disclosure and otherwise preserve the confidential and/or privileged nature of any confidential supervisory information received in connection with the Supervisory College of The Travelers and (3) their authority to share confidential information relating to The Travelers and its affiliates with each The Travelers Regulator. The copy ofthe law establishing such authority for each signatory is attached hereto as Exhibit A. Before a party to this Agreement discloses confidential information obtained under this Agreement, the party disclosing the information will seek to obtain prior consent from the party that provided the information. Confidentiality Agreement College of Supervisors of The Travelers Companies, Inc. The Connecticut Insurance Department ("CID"), as lead regulator ofThe Travelers Companies, Inc. ("The Travelers") insurance holding company system and other regulators of The Travelers and its regulated affiliates (collectively "The Travelers Regulators"; each "The Travelers Regulator") enter into this Confidentiality Agreement ("Agreement") for exchanging confidential information pertaining to The Travelers and its regulated and non-regulated affiliates on a reciprocal basis within the framework ofthe Supervisory College of The Travelers. This Agreement applies to confidential information shared in preparation for the meetings ofthe Supervisory College of The Travelers or as a result of such meetings. The CID and The Travelers Regulators who are parties to this Agreement acknowledge that this Agreement does not create any legally binding obligations, confer any rights, modify, or supersede any domestic laws or regulatory requirements in force in, or applying to, their respective jurisdiction and does not confer upon any person the right or ability, directly or indirectly, to obtain, suppress or exclude any information. This Agreement is not intended to affect any arrangements under any other agreements or memoranda of understanding in existence to which any ofThe Travelers Regulators is a party. All confidential information, in whatever form, furnished under this Agreement remains the property ofthe party that provided the information. By signing below the CID and each The Travelers Regulator confirm (1) their agreement to use any confidential supervisory information received in connection with the Supervisory College of The Travelers only for lawful supervisory purposes, (2) their authority and intent, under the laws oftheir respective jurisdiction, to protect from disclosure and otherwise preserve the confidential and/or privileged nature of any confidential supervisory information received in connection with the Supervisory College of The Travelers and (3) their authority to share confidential information relating to The Travelers and its affiliates with each The Travelers Regulator. ARTICLE 12 COORDINATED ADMINISTRATIVE AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT The Parties shall continue coordinating administrative and technical support through the WCI, Inc., an entity which was created to perform such services, including for the Parties. If one of the Parties wishes to consider approaches other than WCI, Inc. for coordinating any of the administrative and technical program support, it shall consult the other Parties with the objective ofjointly developing a harmonized approach. If one of the Parties wishes to use the services of a party other than WCI, Inc. for technical or administrative support, or services of another nature required for the development or the operation of common program registry and auction platforms, it shall consult the other Parties with the objective of jointly developing a harmonized approach. ARTICLE 13 CONSULTATION COMMITTEE To facilitate the harmonization and integration process of the programs and the operation of the Agreement, the Parties shall create a Consultation Committee composed of one representative from each of the Parties. This Consultation Committee shall meet as needed to ensure timely and effective consultation in support of the objectives of this Agreement. The representatives of each Party on the consultation committee are presented in Annex 1. The Consultation Committee shall: a) monitor the implementation of all measures that are required for the effective harmonization and integration of the Parties' programs; b) recommend measures to improve the harmonization and integration of the Parties' programs, when needed; and c) address any other issues at the request of the Parties. The Consultation Committee shall receive and review updates from the Parties on each area of activity as needed under this Agreement in a timely manner. If the Consultation Committee identifies or becomes aware of differences between the Parties regarding how to maintain the harmonization and integration of their programs, the Consultation Committee shall undertake to resolve the differences in accordance with Article 20.

used. Once the Parties have signed an Accession Amending Agreement, the candidate Party shall sign an Instrument of Accession. ARTICLE 20 RESOLUTION OF DIFFERENCES The Parties shall consult each other constructively to resolve differences that may arise regarding how to achieve the objective of harmonizing and integrating their programs. The Parties shall resolve differences by using and building on established working relationships, including enabling staff to work jointly through workgroups to develop proposed harmonized and integrated approaches for consideration by each Party. If approaches for resolving differences that are acceptable to the Parties cannot be developed in a timely manner through staff workgroups, the Parties shall constructively engage through the Consultation Committee, and if needed with additional officials of the Parties, or their designees. The Parties will endeavor to resolve differences in a timely manner, so that the harmonization and integration oft the programs can be maintained. ARTICLE 21 COMMUNICATIONS The Parties agree to communicate on matters regarding this Agreement in writing and hand delivered or transmitted by telegram, fax, e-mail, messenger, courier or registered mail to the contact of the Party concerned (see Annex 1 for contacts). Any change of address of one of the Parties or of the representatives designated in Annex 1 shall be notified to the other Parties. Each Party shall designate a contact to facilitate communications between the Parties on any matter covered by this Agreement. On the request of any Party, the contact shall identify the office or official responsible for the matter and assist, as necessary, in facilitating communication between the office or official and the requesting Party. ARTICLE 22 COMING INTO FORCE AND DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT Each of the Parties shall notify all the other Parties as soon as possible after the Party has completed any procedures required for the Agreement's entry into force. The Agreement shall enter into full force and effect on the first day of the month following the date of receipt of notification from the last of the Parties informing the other Parties that any legally required measures have been completed.

STATEMENT OF MUTUAL COOPERATION between the Texas Economic Development and Tourism Office, Office of the Texas Governor, United States of America, and the Bureau ofIndustrial and Labor Affairs, Tokyo Metropolitan Government, Japan The Texas Economic Development and Tourism Office, Office ofthe Texas Governor, and the Bureau of Industrial and Labor Affairs, Tokyo Metropolitan Government, will strive to engage in the following activities under this Statement ofMutual Cooperation (SMC) for the purpose ofhelping small and medium- sized enterprises (SMES) expand into each party's market, promote innovation through collaboration and joint research, and facilitate the creation ofjobs through direct investment. 1. ACTIVITIES 1) Providing foreign SMES with information about, and introduce them to, agencies and institutions and persons who can provide support; 2) Disseminating program information among relevant local and regional stakeholders; 3) Supporting foreign SMES on administrative procedures in thel host market including providing information about the necessary paperwork for establishing a company or developing sales channels; Sharing information about scheduled business matchmaking events, trade fairs ofrelated industries, and space to exhibit commercial products/services in the host region; 5) Supporting foreign SMES in building relationships with local companies , start-ups, investors and universities to foster their integration in the local ecosystem; Providing information to the employees of foreign SMES and their families on matters concerning daily life including procedures related to healthcare, education, and residence. 2. DURATION OF OPERATION This SMC will come into operation on the date of signature and will initially be applied until March 31, 2023, and may be renewed by the parties. 3. FINAL PROVISIONS 1) This SMC is subject to the prevailing laws and regulations of the State of Texas, the United States ofAmerica, and Tokyo, Japan. 2) This SMC is solely an expression of the parties' desire to establish a mutually beneficial relationship and creates no legally binding rights or obligations and does not constitute any financial commitment by either party.

ACTIVITIES 1) Providing foreign SMES with information about, and introduce them to, agencies and institutions and persons who can provide support; 2) Disseminating program information among relevant local and regional stakeholders; 3) Supporting foreign SMES on administrative procedures in thel host market including providing information about the necessary paperwork for establishing a company or developing sales channels; Sharing information about scheduled business matchmaking events, trade fairs of related industries, and space to exhibit commercial products/services in the host region; 5) Supporting foreign SMES in building relationships with local companies, start-ups, investors and universities to foster their integration in the local ecosystem; 6) Providing information to the employees of foreign SMES and their families on matters concerning daily life including procedures related to healthcare, education, and residence. 2.
