6. Information that Supervisors may exchange between themselves include (but is not limited to): (1) any granting or withdrawal of authorisations; (2) changes in the membership of the board of directors; (3) solvency concerns or problems concerning a member in the Group (including financial problems which could lead to the drafting of financing schemes or the winding-up of an Insurer of the Group, the declaration of emergency settlements, the freezing of assets); (4) the granting of approvals or licenses to an Insurer in order to allow a major acquisition leading to a qualified participation in another insurer or financial entity; (5) any major acquisition by an Insurer in the Group; and (6) any enforcement action taken by a Supervisor against an Insurer in the Group. 7. Confidential Information will be shared via secure communication channels available. 7.3 Task sharing, delegation, joint activities, specialised group, joint on-site inspections 1. The BMA may share or delegate tasks to the Supervisors who, with thel knowledge of the BMA and subject to their mutual consent, may share and delegate tasks to one another in compliance with their respective national laws and regulatory requirements. 2. Joint activities between Supervisors may be organised on a voluntary basis, in order for the BMA or a Supervisor to comply with applicable national laws and regulatory requirements. 3. The BMA and the Supervisors may establish working groups or execute joint on-site inspections, as permitted by national laws and regulatory requirements, comprising various Supervisors, working on a voluntary basis to review specific matters of interest relating to an Insurer or to the Group. 8. Cooperation in emergency and systemic crisis situations 1. The Supervisors are responsible for assessing whether a crisis situation is affecting the Insurers under their supervision. 2. The Crisis Management Plan, added as Appendix 2 to the MMOU, provides a definition of a crisis situation, as well as the required cooperation in the case of a crisis. The Supervisors shall follow the principles and procedures stipulated in the Crisis Management Plan. 3. The Supervisors will endeavour to cooperate closely, whenever necessary and in accordance with their national law, with other relevant authorities (e.g. central banks) involved in the crisis management process. 9. Final provisions 1. The Supervisors will make their best efforts to guarantee the security of the information transmitted byi implementing secured and quick means of transmission (e.g. through a secured sharing platform). All Confidential Information shared under this MMOU will be stored in secure communication channels.

Nothing in this MOU limits the right of each of the Participants to establish similar agreements with other institutions. Cooperation under this MOU does not affect the rights and obligations acquired by the Participants in other international agreements. Paragraph 8 EFFECT OF MOU This MOU serves only as a record of the Participants' intentions and does not constitute or create any legally binding or enforceable rights or obligations, expressed or implied. Paragraph 9 NOTICES Any notice or other communication between the Participants under this MOU will be in writing in the English language and shall be addressed to: For the California Energy Commission: Mr. Drew Bohan Address: 1516 9th Street, Sacramento, CA 95814, USA E-mail: Drew.Bohan@energy.ca.gov For the State of Aguascalientes Name: Mr. Julio Cesar Medina Delgado, Environment Secretary Address: Av. Jose Maria Chavez 1917, Aguascalientes, CP 20280 E-mail: julio.medina@aguascalientes.gob.mx Paragraph 10 FINAL PROVISIONS This MOU is neither a contract nor a treaty. This MOU will be effective upon the date of its signature by both participants, will remain in force for two years thereafter, and may be renewed for equal periods by mutual consent of the Participants until terminated through written notice. This MOU may be amended or modified by mutual written consent of the Participants. Either Participant may terminate this MOU by providing the other with 30 days written notice.

Section 6 NO IMPLIED LIABILITY Thel Participants understand that cooperative efforts and activities under this MOU are considered by thel Participants to be facilitated exchange of information only, and not advice or consultancy. Section 7 MODIFICATION PROCEDURE This MOU may be modified at any timel by the mutual written consent of the Participants. Section 8 INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION OF MOU This MOU serves only as a record of the Participants intentions and does not constitute or create any legally binding or enforceable rights or obligations, expressed or implied. This MOU is intended to be effective upon signature, and in effect for three years from the date of final execution. Discontinuation should take effect three months following the date of notification, and should not affect activities already under implementation. Manitoba Industry, Trade and Mines Letter of Intentto sign a memorandum of understanding on Trade, Tourism, and Mutual Economic Cooperation between the State of Texas, as represented by the Texas Department of Economic Development and the Province of Manitoba, as represented by the Manitoba Department of Industry, Trade and Mines. Whereas Texas and Manitoba, in recognition of sharing the Mid-Continent and Transportation Corridor, extending border-to-bordertoborder in the Trade Continent of North America, Texas Department of Economic Development and Manitoba Department of Industry, Trade, and Mines have established an enduring and positive relationship based on many mutual interests; and Whereas Texas and Manitoba wish to build on the experience of the trade relationship initiated by their participation in the Team Canada West Trade Mission to Texas on November 28, 2001, and Whereas Texas and Manitoba recognize: the dramatic increase in value of trade between all Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor partners; the growing overall importance of The Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor trading relationships between Canada and the United States, and between Texas and Manitoba; the increasing need for interrelationships between all Mid-Continent trading partners; the advantages to be derived from the strengthening and broadening of mutually beneficial Mid-Continent trade and investment relations; the value of close consultations and co-operation on Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor issues and the need to ensure open lines of communication and sharing of publicly available information; and the importance of working together and in concert with their respective federal governments in matters of international and Mid-Continent Corridor trade and transportation significance. Therefore, in a spirit of promoting closer relations, Texas and Manitoba intend to work co-operatively to the fullest possible extent consistent with law, existing treaties, and privacy requirements of their respective state or province and nation.

WHEREAS the State of Texas and the Province of Manitoba, in recognition of sharing the Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor, extending border-to-border-to-border in the Continent of North America, have established an enduring and positive relationship based on mutual interests; and WHEREAS Texas and Manitoba have a strong and growing trade relationship and wish to build upon the experience of their participation in the Team Canada West Trade Mission to Texas on November 27-29, 2001; and WHEREAS Texas and Manitoba recognize: the dramatic increase in the value of trade between all Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor partners and the significant 78 percent increase in trade between the state and the province over the last five years; the growing overall importance of the Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor trade relationships between Canada, the United States and Mexico and between Texas and Manitoba; the increasing need for interrelationships between all Mid-Continent trading partners; the advantages to be derived from strengthening and broadening of mutually beneficial Mid-Continent trade and investment relations; the value of close consultations and cooperation on Mid-Continent Trade Corridor issues and the need to ensure open lines of communication and sharing of publidy available information; and the importance of working together and in concert with their respective federal governments in matters of international and Mid-Continent corridor trade significance. Now, therefore, in the spirit of promoting closer relationships, the State of Texas and the Province ofl Manitoba intend to work co-operatively to the fullest possible extent consistent with the law and existing treaties between their respective nations to: 1. Promote and Facilitate Bilateral Trade Bilateral trade between Texas and Manitoba now approaches US $480 million annually. The Governments of Texas and Manitoba share a strong interest in expanding this economic partnership and building on the shared potential of emerging export opportunities within the Americas and across the globe. The Governments of Texas and Manitoba, co-ordinated by Texas Economic Development and the Department of Industry, Trade and Mines in Manitoba, therefore propose to: 1.1. work together to identify target sectors for joint initiatives including but not limited to agribusiness, aerospace, component manufacturing, film, energy, biotechnology and information and communication technologies;

2 c) To encourage innovation, economic and business development in technology-related sectors by fostering joint industrial research and development (R&D) activities, enhancing business relationships, and facilitating collaboration between Mexican and Californian entrepreneurs; d) To share good practices relating to technological innovation; e) To build upon the principles of a mutually beneficial trade and investment relationship recognizing the importance of strengthening the Participants' capacity to protect the environment and promote sustainable development while remaining vigilant of labor rights. SECTION II Areas of Cooperation The Participants intend to strengthen and facilitate trade and investment cooperation through initiatives focused particularly on, but not limited to, the following areas of cooperation: a) Creative industries b) Digital economy and Industry 4.0 c) Micro, small and medium enterprises d) Alternative and Renewable Energy e) Environmental Protection. and Other Related Clean Technologies f) Agriculture and Agricultural Technologies g) Workforce development h) Infrastructure for cross-border goods movement and trade facilitation SECTION III Coordination The Participants respectively designate the General Direction for North American Affairs of the Ministry of Economy and the Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development to establish a bilateral Working Group to coordinate the creation of an action plan to implement the objectives of this Memorandum of Understanding.

a) To engage in mutually beneficial economic, commercial and innovation activities; b) To promote the organization of trade and investment missions, and facilitating the identification of economic opportunities; c) To encourage innovation, economic and business development in new and technology-related sectors by fostering joint industrial R&D, enhancing business relationships, and facilitating collaboration between Mexican and Californian entrepreneurs through (but not limited to) California's innovation hub (iHub) network, trade delegations, and public-private partnerships; To build upon the principles of NAFTA in recognizing the importance of strengthening the Participants' capacity to protect the environment and of promoting sustainable development in concert with enhancing their trade and investment relations. ARTICLE II Areas of Cooperation The Participants intend to strengthen and facilitate trade and investment cooperation through initiatives focused particularly on, but not limited to, the following sectors: a) Advanced Manufacturing. b) Alternative and Renewable Energy. c) Environmental Protection and Other Related Clean Technologies. d) Biotechnology. e) Medical Devices. f) Information Technologies. g) Agriculture and Agricultural Technologies. h) Education. i) Tourism. j) Cross-Border Goods Movement Infrastructure. ARTICLE III Working Group The Participants respectively designate the General Direction for North America of the Ministry of Economy and the Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development to establish a bilateral Working Group to oversee the implementation of the objectives of this MOU. 2

The Working Group shall meet either in person or via video conference on a regular, periodic basis and at least once a year. The time and place of each meeting shall be mutually decided upon by the Participant designees through consultation. Other government agencies, chambers of commerce or business associations may be invited to participate in the Working Group and/or other initiatives undertaken pursuant to this MOU. ARTICLE IV Specific Activities The Participants have decided that specific activities to achieve the objectives of this MOU for the key sectors identified in Article II may include: a) Exchanging information on trade and investment projects and exhibitions related to the identified sectors on a regular basis; b) Encouraging the organization of joint trade-promotion activities and business missions to both Participants; c) Providing information to companies, including small and medium- sized enterprises to facilitate trade and investment opportunities, and providing relevant connections to the extent it is reasonable possible to do so; d) Fostering collaboration between the Participants' universities, organizations, research centers, California's iHubs, and companies to develop science and technology programs that support business development and create jobs; e) Welcoming trade and tourism promotion officials and delegations, and facilitating appropriate introductions. ARTICLE V Contact Points The General Direction for North America of the Ministry of Economy and the Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development shall also serve as the respective contact points for communication and information exchange, as well as any notice required to be submitted under this MOU. 3

3 The Working Group will meet on a regular, periodic basis in order to follow up on the Memorandum of Understanding's implementation. The Ministry of Economy and the relevant agencies of the Government of California will be in charge of carrying out the actions within the scope of their competence and may invite other agencies, Chambers of Commerce or Business Associations to participate in initiatives undertaken pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding. The Working Group must present a mid-term and a final report on the results of the implementation of the action plan. SECTION IV Specific Activities Specific activities to achieve the objectives of this Memorandum of Understanding for the key sectors identified in Article II may include: a) Exchanging information on good practices relating to specific projects regarding the identified areas of cooperation; b) Organizing at least one trade mission every two years to focus on the exchange of information about options of trade and investment, the development of commercial contacts and the exploration of areas for potential cooperation; c) Providing information to companies, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMES), in order to facilitate trade and investment opportunities, and providing relevant connections to the extent it is reasonably possible to do so; d) Fostering collaboration between the Participants' universities, organizations, research centers, California's iHubs, and companies to develop science and technology programs that allows for concrete business development; e) Undertaking exchanges between. entrepreneurs and innovators in order to share good practices and success stories from Silicon Valley and other innovation centers in California; f) Establishing links with the Mexican Association of Economic Development Secretaries (Asociacion Mexicana de Secretarios de Desarrollo Economico, AMSDE) and California counterparts to identify areas for collaboration at the local level, particularly in the California-Baja California border region; g) Identifying collaboration projects pertaining to border infrastructure in order to establish cooperation pilot programs on this subject;

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING This Memorandum of Understanding is effective as of June 12, 2018 ("effective date") BETWEEN: THE DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND TRADE THE GOVERNMENT OF ALBERTA ("ALBERTA") And OFFICE OF THE TEXAS SECRETARY OF STATE ("TEXAS") Alberta and Texas (collectively, the "Participants") seek to facilitate and implement opportunities for a long term collaborative relationship to advance the export development, investment attraction, solution oriented research, commercialization and global competitiveness of the energy sector, advanced technologies, and trade and investment in each respective jurisdiction. Thel Participants share a common commitment to the pursuit of economic progress and prosperity. The Participants are both recognized as centers of excellence and innovation in research and development, agriculture, and energy within their respective countries. The Participants are economically interdependent, share integrated supply chains, and enjoy al bilateral trading relationship in excess of C$13.81 billion and US$10.6 billion (2017). The Participants recognize the wish to enhance and strengthen their efforts to pursue common goals and objectives in relation to stimulating economic growth. This Memorandum of Understanding ("MOU") sets out the intentions and understandings of the Participants: as follows: 1. Scope of Collaboration The Participants, each working with other appropriate departments and agencies in their respective governments, commit to ongoing dialogue and agree to work together to: Endeavor to develop a mutual understanding of shared challenges and opportunities as they relate to commercial and economic development; ii. Explore potential areas of collaboration that enhance prospects for economic development and job growth in Alberta and Texas; iii. Seek opportunities to enhance trade and investment and to undertake collaborative innovations and research and development around emerging technologies between. Alberta and Texas; iv. Work with their respective federal governments to enhance regional and bi-national competitiveness through the promotion of open trade practices and through the prevention and elimination of tradel barriers; V. Demonstrate sub-national leadership by jointly identifying areas of common interest that either Party may! bring forward to the attention of the respective federal governments. 2. MOU Management Committee Thel Participants will appoint an MOU Management Committee consisting of two senior officials from each jurisdiction to oversee the implementation of the MOU. Thel Management Committee may consider opportunities in the following sectors: Oil and gas Renewable energy Agriculture and Agri-food Life Sciences Digital technology Emerging technology 3. Costs Each Participant will bear its own costs resulting from its participation in activities undertaken in the furtherance of the objectives of this MOU.

Therefore Texas' and Manitoba's primary objectives guiding their respective activities are: A. the commercial promotion, on an international level, of products, services and technologies of Texas and Manitoba; and B. The development and delivery of international projects and initiatives for exporters and companies ready for export. Whereas to carry out these objectives the parties agree to promote the expansion of trade and business relations between Texas and Manitoba. The parties will work together to identify target sectors for joint initiatives, including but not limited to agribusiness, aerospace, component manufacturers, film, energy, biotechnology, and information and communication technologies. The mode of this cooperation will be set forth in the terms of a Memorandum of Understanding to be signed at a future date. It is the intention of parties signing below to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding between Texas and Manitoba. This Letter of Intent is issued pending the development and execution of a final Memorandum of Understanding between the two parties and does not represent a commitment by either party to any terms, conditions and obligations, but does represent a willingness to work together toward mutually beneficial trade, transportation and economic, development endeavors. The parties do agree to discuss the terms of a Memorandum of Understanding within 60 days of the date of this letter to explore and further define specific steps toward carrying out the objectives of this Letter of Agreement. Executed in Dallas, Texas this 28th day of November 2001. Jeff Moselèy Robert Dilay Executive Director Executive Director Texas Department of Economic Trade & Investment Division Development Manitoba Department of Industry, Trade, and Mines Witness Witness The Honorable Geoffrey Connor The Honourable Gary Doer Acting Secretary of State Premier State of Texas Province of Manitoba

1.2. work together to identify opportunities for strategic partnerships and alliances between private sector companies in Texas and Manitoba which will strengthen their capabilities to compete in international markets; 1.3. explore opportunities for joint trade promotions, beginning with the sharing of publicly available information on priority markets and planned promotional activities, followed by the identification of possible joint trade missions to targeted markets; 1.4. support regional and federal initiatives to facilitate the border-to-border-to-border movement of goods and people; 1.5. share publicly available information on and learn from each other's best practices and the world-class expertise found in both jurisdictions; and promote common goals by encouraging co-operation and understanding between business, municipal, state/provincial and federal governments, and citizens of' Texas and Manitoba. 2. Promote and Encourage Co-operation in Tourism The Governments of Texas and Manitoba intend to work together to expand bilateral tourism opportunities. The Governments senior tourism officials, who will operate under the direction oft the Executive Director of Texas Economic Development and the Minister ofCulture, Heritage and' Tourism in Manitoba, will explore a tourism strategy that will include: 2.1. the identification and sharing of mutually beneficial tourism marketing initiatives; 2.2. the facilitation of the development of travel packages that promote the advantages of each jurisdiction. 3. Promote the Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor Texas and Manitoba share the Mid-Continent Trade and Transportation Corridor which extends border-to-border-to-border in the North American continent. Officials from Texas and Manitoba will work together to: 3.1. establish a seamless transportation infrastructure which includes the harmonization of regulations along the corridor and more efficient and effective border crossings; and, 3.2. asa result of the improvements made in the transportation infrastructure along the corridor, create a more competitive environment for private sector companies in both Texas and Manitoba and create an inducement to attract new inward investment to the state and the province. 4. Coordinate Activities in International Development/Co-operation Agreements The Governments of Texas and Manitoba agree to explore opportunities to co-ordinate their efforts in furthering the goals and objectives of their respective co-operative agreements aimed at strengthening trade and investment links and improving the effectiveness of government services.

Memorandum of Understanding between the Film & Digital Media Program of the State of Arizona (the "AZFDMP") through the Arizona Commerce Authority, and the Film Office of the State of Sonora, through Sonora Tourism, to join efforts in marketing Film & Digital Media Production in the Arizona-Sonora region. RECITALS WHEREAS the states of Arizona and Sonora share an innovative, exemplary bilateral relationship. This relationship and partnership are made possible thanks to a history of trust and collaboration between Arizona and Sonora that has developed solid results; and, WHEREAS the states of Arizona and Sonora share a goal of expanding film & digital media production and increasing related jobs and industry activity through promotion and development; and, WHEREAS in August 2017, the AZFDMP offered to list Sonoran beaches and resorts on its website; and, WHEREAS in November 2017, images of Sonoran beaches and resorts became universally accessible on the AZFDMP website; and, WHEREAS in May 2019, the AZFDMP added the category of Associated Film Offices" on the AZFDMP website, which included the State of Sonora Film Office; and, WHEREAS the foregoing evidence a consistent and continually improving relationship of collaboration, cooperation, and support between the AZFDMP and the Film Office of the State of Sonora; NOW, THEREFORE, THE FILM & DIGITAL MEDIA PROGRAM OF THE STATE OF ARIZONA AND FILM OFFICE OF THE STATE OF SONORA RESOLVE AS FOLLOWS: 1. The Film & Digital Media Program of the State of Arizona and the Film Office of the State of Sonora will collaboratively promote strategies aimed at increasing film & digital media production in the Arizona-Sonora Region. 2. The Film & Digital Media Program of the State of Arizona and the Film Office of the State of Sonora will mutually identify current and future marketing activities that will promote binational film & digital media production. This may include but may not be limited to advertising opportunities, participation in trade shows, and engagement with broader stakeholder groups through familiarization trips.

Memorandum of Understanding between the Film & Digital Media Program of the State of Arizona (the "AZFDMP") through the Arizona Commerce Authority, and the Film Office of the State of Sonora, through Sonora Tourism, to join efforts in marketing Film & Digital Media Production in the Arizona-Sonora region. RECITALS WHEREAS the states of Arizona and Sonora share an innovative, exemplary bilateral relationship. This relationship and partnership are made possible thanks to a history of trust and collaboration between Arizona and Sonora that has developed solid results; and, WHEREAS the states of Arizona and Sonora share a goal of expanding film & digital media production and increasing related jobs and industry activity through promotion and development; and, WHEREAS in August 2017, the AZFDMP offered to list Sonoran beaches and resorts on its website; and, WHEREAS in November 2017, images of Sonoran beaches and resorts became universally accessible on the AZFDMP website; and, WHEREAS in May 2019, the AZFDMP added the category of Associated Film Offices" on the AZFDMP website, which included the State of Sonora Film Office; and, WHEREAS the foregoing evidence a consistent and continually improving relationship of collaboration, cooperation, and support between the AZFDMP and the Film Office of the State of Sonora; NOW, THEREFORE, THE FILM & DIGITAL MEDIA PROGRAM OF THE STATE OF ARIZONA AND FILM OFFICE OF THE STATE OF SONORA RESOLVE AS FOLLOWS: 1. The Film & Digital Media Program of the State of Arizona and the Film Office of the State of Sonora will collaboratively promote strategies aimed at increasing film & digital media production in the Arizona-Sonora Region. 2. The Film & Digital Media Program of the State of Arizona and the Film Office of the State of Sonora will mutually identify current and future marketing activities that will promote binational film & digital media production. This may include but may not be limited to advertising opportunities, participation in trade shows, and engagement with broader stakeholder groups through familiarization trips.

3. The Film & Digital Media Program of the State of Arizona and the Film Office of the State of Sonora will work together to develop a mutually agreeable and mutually beneficial public relations campaign, which will be presented to media outlets in Mexico, the U.S., and around the world, highlighting opportunities and successes in cross border film & digital media production. 4. The Arizona Commerce Authority and the Sonora Tourism will support efforts from the film commissions in Arizona and Sonora to promote bi- national film, TV, and digital media productions. This Memorandum of Understanding is intended to memorialize the participants' commitment to explore ways to promote collaboration, but it is nonbinding and creates no present or future legal obligation among any of the participants, Nothing in this Memorandum of Understanding should be read to conflict with the laws and regulations of the United States of America or the United Mexican States (or any state or local jurisdiction), or with any relevant international agreements. There are no third-party beneficiaries to this Memorandum of Understanding. This Memorandum of Understanding will be effective on the date of its signature and will be valid for 5 years. Either the Arizona Commerce Authority or Sonora Tourism may terminate its participation under this Memorandum of Understanding at any time; provided, however, that the terminating party should endeavor to give the other party 30 days' notice ofi its intention to terminate this Memorandum of Understanding. The termination should not preclude the completion of any cooperative activities agreed upon while the Memorandum of Understanding was valid. Each state will be responsible for its own expenses in the implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding. This Memorandum of Understanding is signed on Wednesday, June 26, 2019, within the framework of the Panel Discussion on Bi-National Film Marketing, held at the Arizona-Mexico Commission 60th Anniversary Summit, held in Phoenix, Arizona. Global Soil Health Challenge o 2018 SOILHEALTH GLOBAL CHALLENGE Consistent with the Under2 MOU, and the "4 per 1000" Initiative goals and building on it, Seeking to strengthen the global response to the threat of climate change and the Paris Agreement target of holding the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels, Acknowledging that even ift the world reaches an emissions trajectory of 80 to 95 percent below 1990 levels by 2050 we will still need to remove carbon from the atmosphere, Asserting that early adopter public and private stakeholders I including nations, provinces, states, cities, NGOS, and corporations - have led the world in setting ambitious climate targets and taking actions to reduce emissions and protect against climate impacts, Recognizing that climate change responses and solutions can create economic opportunities and benefits through sustainable development, Noting the multiple co-benefits of healthy soils and agro-ecology for agricultural yields, food security, farm income, water management, climate resilience, biodiversity, healthy food, and rural community development, Pledging to share best practices in designing and deploying healthy soils solutions that maximize ecological benefits while providing other co-benefits, Now at the Global Climate. Action Summit in September 2018, We pledge to work together to: (1) Call on and support nations and sub nations in including ambitious programs of action on soil health in their Nationally Determined Contributions submitted to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change for the 2020 Conference of the Parties and in sub-national climate initiatives as part of broader climate action plans; (2) Enact incentives and programs to promote healthy soils, soil carbon sequestration and enhancement of biodiversity in agricultural areas through a range of actions including policies, supply chain initiatives, regulations, updated farmer education and extension programs, online platforms and in-person events for sharing knowledge and practices, to create an enabling environment for farmers, ranchers and those working to restore degraded lands through agriculture; (3) Promote widespread adoption of sustainable farming systems, including agro-ecological and carbon farming practices for agriculture appropriate to diverse geographies and landscapes, based on emerging soil science - including planting cover crops, adopting low- or no-till farming practices, rotational grazing, generation and use of safe compost and/or biochar, crop rotations, nutrient management, silvopasture, agroforestry and other practices - to improve the health and productivity of soils, including their organic carbon content, water retention rate, biological activity, and biological diversity; (4) Encourage funders multilateral, bilateral, public, private, philanthropic, etc., to support projects in the field, promotion of good practices, and elaboration and implementation of policies at all level; and (5) Report back on our progress at the 2019 Climate Summit at the United Nations in New York. O Global Soil Health Challenge 2018 O 0008

Global Soil Health Challenge o 2018 SOULHFALTA GLOBAL CHALLENGE The Global Climate Action Summit in September will bring leaders and people together from around the world to "Take Ambition to the Next Level." It will be a moment to celebrate the extraordinary achievements of states, regions, cities, companies, investors and citizens with respect to climate action. It will also be a launchpad for deeper worldwide commitments and accelerated action from countries- supported by all sectors of society - that can put the globe on track to prevent dangerous climate change and realize the historic Paris Agreement. Underscoring that fact that we need to continue and strengthen all efforts to reduce all GHG emissions, there is growing global recognition that carbon sequestration in natural and working lands is necessary to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement. It is well known that changes in agricultural practices can increase the amount of carbon in the soil, improving its fertility and resilience to drought and flood, while raising food production and farm income. France called attention to this opportunity at the Paris climate conference in 2015 with its "4 per 1000" initiative, and California led the way in the U.S. with its Healthy Soils Initiative. Yet the benefit of rebuilding soil carbon remains little understood by policy makers around the world, and the uptake and replication of these efforts could be greatly improved. The Soil Health Challenge, to be announced at the San Francisco summit by the Secretary off the California Department of Food and Agriculture, Karen Ross, and diverse representatives from other state and national jurisdictions, will call on national and sub-national governments to promote the development ofl healthy soils within their own geographies and report back on their progress a year from now at the 2019 UN Climate Summit in New York. The timeliness and urgency of this challenge could not be clearer: The oceans and atmosphere have become overloaded with carbon dioxide, but the terrestrial ecosystem could absorb much more carbon and benefit from it. In the race to constrain the level of carbon in the atmosphere and hold the rise in global temperatures' to well below 2 degrees C, carbon absorption ("negative emissions") will be required at an unprecedented scale. Agricultural soils could annually take up hundreds of millions of tons of carbon dioxide more than they do today, reducing the level and impact of atmospheric carbon and buying additional time to make the transition to low-carbon solutions throughout the global economy. Across the globe farmers are beginning to recognize the direct and indirect benefits of climate-smart practices in agriculture, forestry, and grazing. Sustainable farming systems, including agro-ecology practices, that rebuild and protect soil carbon and enhance the vitality of the subsurface microbiome (often recalling traditional practices) - such as minimum or no tillage, rotating crops, keeping the ground covered year-round, agroforestry, etc.-r make the land more productive, increase its capacity to absorb and retain water, and thus build resilience to increasingly frequent drought and flood. By restoring degraded lands and increasing crop yields, farmers can increase their incomes, produce the food needed for a growing world population, and eliminate the need to expand into previously protected ecosystems for agriculture. As governments consider whether - and how - they might strengthen their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCS) under the Paris Agreement on Climate Change at the 2020 Conference of the Parties, restoring soil health presents a relatively unknown and untapped opportunity. The Soil Health Challenge seeks to raise the visibility of that opportunity and encourage public officials to pursue it. o Global Soil Health Challenge 2018 O 0007

CONSIDERATIONS 1.- The State of Sonora's Development Plan 2016-2021 states the following in Challenge 12: "Encourage the improvement of environmental management foreseen in Strategy 12.1. Line of action 12.1.2; Generate, in coordination with the municipalities, an environmental planning system based on reliable environmental parameters, allowing the generation of joint strategies to improve air quality, water quality, solid waste management, green area expansion, among others. 2.- The objectives of "CEDES" include formulating, implementing and evaluating the environmental policy of the state, creating efforts for joint and coordinated implementation of actions to improve and protect the environment, and to disseminate and promote culture and ecological values, as the actions that will be implemented by both parties, in accordance with the bases of this collaboration agreement. It also has among its responsibilities the freedom to agree with Federal Government agencies, Federal Entities and State Municipalities, as well as with the social and private sectors, joint and coordinated implementation of environmental protection actions; in accordance with Article 3, Section X of Law No. 162, which creates the Comision de Ecologia y Desarrollo Sustentable del Estado de Sonora (Commission on Ecology and Sustainable Development of the State of Sonora/CEDES). 3.- "ADEQ" wishes to establish a temporary air quality monitoring system in the municipality of San Luis Rio Colorado, in the State of Sonora, an activity that it wishes to develop in conjunction with "CEDES" and "THE MUNICIPALITY". 4.- The ozone (03), nitrogen oxides (NOy) and carbon monoxide (CO) monitoring equipment is designed to facilitate accomplishment of the following objectives: A. Provide information to elected officials and the general public regarding 03, NOy and CO pollution; B. Track short-term and long-term trends; C. Assess source contributions to 03, NOy and CO pollution; D. Evaluate the effectiveness of air pollution control strategies; E. Monitor both the diurnal and nocturnal concentrations of ozone. F. Evaluate NOy and CO pollutants as 03 precursors to understand 03 formation in the San Luis and Yuma Basin 5.- "ADEQ" maintains a network of ambient air monitors throughout the state of Arizona to characterize and quantify air pollutants. That Arizona and Sonora share a number of environmental issues related to water, air, solid waste, and wildlife which do not conform to political boundaries along their 362 miles of shared border, necessitating that the environmental, water, and wildlife agencies of both states work together and with their federal and binational counterparts to achieve sustainable solutions in the region. That the development of the Arizona-Sonora Environmental Strategic Plan (ASESP) emerged from a long history of cross-border cooperation involving local, state, federal, binational, and non-govemnmental organizations and the private sector in Arizona and Sonora. That in June of 2016, in order to improve cooperation and maximize the effective use of resources, the Arizona-Mexico Commission's Environment and Water Committee committed to working on a ASESP for the period of 2017-2021. That ADEQ, CEDES, and CEA requested support for the coordination of this endeavor from the Border Environment Cooperation Commission (BECC), and that other state agencies, such as AZGFD and the Arizona Department of Water Resources (ADWR), collaborated on specific issues. That binational organizations such as the North American Development Bank (NADB) and federal agencies such as the Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources of Mexico (SEMARNAT) and the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) were also asked to participate. That the plan was designed to incorporate elements of economic and social development in accordance with the priorities of both states' administrations, for which the North American Research Partnership (NARP), an independent, non- profit research organization, contributed its knowledge on economic competitiveness and the environment in the Arizona-Sonora megaregion (in addition to organizing, editing, and publishing the ASESP itself).

A M X C a o d a O ARIZONA-MEXICO K Gobiernoidel COMMISSION Estado de Sonara SONOT RA That this plan was developed through a series of teleconferences, workshops, and individual consultations, including two multi-agency workshops that were held in Tucson, Arizona on September 13 and 14, 2016, and in Hermosillo, Sonora on November 1, 2016. That the purpose of these workshops was to discuss a) the development and selection of primary projects, b) the criteria for evaluating these projects, and c) their prioritization, and that this final point was refined over the course of several teleconferences and meetings between experts from the participating organizations. That the ASESP includes background information on: environmental issues in the Arizona-Sonora megaregion, economic competitiveness and the environment, priority strategic projects, additional projects should funding sources become available, and potential partners. That 15 priority strategic projects were selected that address a number of public issues related to the areas of water quality, air quality, waste management, and wildlife management. Another 15 additional projects were selected by participating agencies as worthy of future consideration as funding and staffing resources become available. That the 15 priority strategic projects the agencies commit to further developing and implementing within the framework of this Memorandum of Understanding are: Water Quality: Stormwater Control in Nogales, Sonora for the Protection of Binational Infrastructure and Public Health Infrastructure for Metals and E. coli Attenuation in the San Pedro River Implementation of Green Infrastructure in Nogales, Sonora for the Protection of Binational Stormwater Quality Industrial Pretreatment Support in Nogales, Sonora for the Protection of Binational Water Quality

information, track short and long-term trends, assess source contributions, and better evaluate the effectiveness of air pollution control strategies. DECLARATIONS I.- "CEDES" DECLARES THAT: A.- It is a Decentralized Public Organization, with legal personality and its own patrimony, created on October 13, 2005 through Law no. 162, which created a decentralized public organization called Comision de Ecologia y Desarrollo Sustentable del Estado de Sonora, published in the Official Newsletter of the Government of the State of Sonora, which was amended by Decree No. 180, published in the Official Newsletter of the State of Sonora - B.- Its purpose is to formulate, implement and evaluate the State's ecological policy, promote the participation and responsibility of the different sectors; social and proven in the formulation of ecological policy, the application of its instruments, information and surveillance actions and, in general, in the ecological actions undertaken by the State; also, to carry out and promote studies and research of a scientific and technological nature on ecology and the environment, as well as to disseminate and promote culture and ecological values in the State of Sonora. C.- Luis Carlos Romo Salazar was appointed by the Governor of the State of Sonora, C. Lic. Claudia A. Pavlovich Arellano, on September 23, 2015, as Executive Commissioner of Comision de Ecologia y Desarrollo Sustentable del Estado de Sonora and has extensive powers to sign contracts and agreements, in accordance with Article 10 Fractions I, XII and XIII of the Decree of Creation, published on October 13, 2005, whose article of application in this agreement was amended by Decree No. 180, which amends various provisions of the Law, creating a decentralized public organization called Comision de Ecologia y Desarrollo Sustentable del Estado de Sonora, published in the Official Newsletter of the Government of the State of Sonora on June 18, 2009, as well as established in article 14, sections XXXVII and XXXVIII of the Internal Regulations of Comision de Ecologia y Desarrollo Sustentable del Estado de Sonora, published in the Official Newsletter of the Government of the State of Sonora on October 2, 2014. D.- For the legal effects of this contract, it indicates as its legal address the one located at the corner of Reyes with Aguascalientes, without a specific number, Colonia San Benito, in the City of Hermosillo, Sonora. II.- "THE MUNICIPALITY" DECLARES THAT: A.- It is a public entity which is invested with legal personality and its own patrimony, as provided by Article 115 of the Political Constitution of the United Mexican States, Articles 128 and 129 of the Political Constitution for the Free and Sovereign State of Sonora, and articles 2 and 3 of the Law of Government and Municipal Administration. B.- For the legal effects of this agreement, "THE MUNICIPALITY" identifies the following as its legal address: Av. Juârez and Calle Cuarta. S/N Colonia Comercial. C.P. 83449 San Luis Rio Colorado, Sonora.

A M E X C O X 4, C C ARIZONA-MEXICO X Gobiemo del COMMISSION Estado de Sonora SONORA MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF ARIZONA THROUGH THE ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (ADEQ) AND THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT (AZGFD), AND THE STATE OF SONORA THROUGH THE ECOLOGY AND SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION (CEDES IN SPANISH) AND THE STATE OF SONORA WATER COMMISION (CEA IN SPANISH), FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF AN ENVIRONMENTAL STRATEGIC PLAN IN THE ARIZONA-SONORA MEGAREGION. The following is a Memorandum of Understanding between ADEQ, AZGFD, CEDES, and CEA (hereafter referred to as "THE PARTICIPANTS") for the development and implementation of an environmental strategic plan in the Arizona- Sonora megaregion. THE PARTICIPANTS are committed to the following: CONSIDERATIONS That ADEQ's mission is to protect and enhance public health and the environment in the State of Arizona by administering its environmental laws and delegated federal programs to prevent air, water and land pollution and ensure cleanup. That AZGFD's mission is to conserve the State of Arizona's diverse wildlife resources and manage them for safe, compatible outdoor recreation opportunities for current and future generations. That CEDES aims to develop, implement, and evaluate the State of Sonora's environmental policies, promote the participation and responsibility of public and private sectors in the formulation of environmental policies, their application, information sharing and monitoring, and, in general, the environmental actions undertaken by the State of Sonora. CEDES also conducts and promotes scientific and technological research in the fields of ecology and the environment to encourage and disseminate environmental values and culture in the State of Sonora. That CEA aims to participate in the planning, financing, budgeting, and sustainable development of the State of Sonora's water sector, implementing policies and actions that establish a holistic water system, advising and assisting water user

IV. Non-discrimination The MOU for State-to-State recognition of the requirements for "2015: Arizona and Sonora's New Border" is subject to State and Federal laws and is terminable by either party with 30 days written notice. Having read the present Memorandum of Understanding, the parties hereby agree to its terms and sign it, in the city of Phoenix, Arizona on 2 June of 2008. MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING (MOU) EXECUTED BY THE ARIZONA - MEXICO COMMISSION AND THE COMISION SONORA ARIZONA FOR THE PURPOSE OF MUTUALLY RECOGNIZING THE CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS TO EXECUTE THE "2015: ARIZONA AND SONORA'S NEW BORDER" PLAN REGARDING ARIZONA AND SONORA'S BORDER INFRASTRUCTURE TIMELINE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FOLLOWING: WHEREAS, Arizona's border ports of entry are critical components of the economic and physical security of both states; and WHEREAS, studies by the University of Arizona have indicated that Arizona has lost a substantial portion of cross-border trade for at least five years; and WHEREAS, Customs and Border Protection (CBP) data confirms that between 2002 and 2007 car traffic dropped by 17% (one million fewer cars) and car passenger traffic decreased by 20% (four million fewer car passengers) and that pedestrian traffic increased by 25% (more than two million more pedestrians) during that same time period; and WHEREAS, commercial traffic has grown by 17% (more than 55,000 more trucks) over the same time frame and is expected to double or? triple in the next 15 to 20 years; and WHEREAS, Arizona's and Sonora's ports of entry are on average more than 30 years old and are extremely overburdened and outdated; and WHEREAS, the federal government has imposed numerous new and more intense inspection procedures and protocols that are contributing to the congestion and delays at the border; and - WHEREAS, border wait times have more than doubled since 2001 and can easily exceed more than two hours at anyone of the ports of entry on the Arizona border with Mexico; and WHEREAS, port of entry projects can take between seven and 15 years from concept to completion; and WHEREAS, Arizona is committed to implementing a plan to at least double the throughput capacity at all its major ports of entry by 2015; and WHEREAS, much work remains to be done in order to bring the various projects to fruition and to secure the necessary funding to pay for each project; and WHEREAS, Arizona is committed to working with all relevant local, state and federal partners and in full coordination and collaboration with the state of Sonora and the federal government of Mexico; and 1 Among the collected commitments, this is the only one that explicitly critiques a federal law or policy.

WHEREAS, "2015: Arizona and Sonora's New Border" offers a valuable tool for the information of decision makers, dissemination of information and coordination of efforts for stakeholders; and WHEREAS, failure to implement a focused and long-term initiative to address the border and the ports of entry stands to negatively impact the economic future and the physical security of the state and the nation. NOW THEREFORE, the parties agree as follows: I. Understanding of the parties 1. This MOU sets forth the basis of coordination for all border infrastructure projects affecting the border region between both states. 2. The parties acknowledge that this MOU does not contain all matters, terms, conditions, upon which an agreement can be reached to meet legal requirements that may pertain to final approval. 3. All terms and conditions pertaining to the preparation and signing of a formal agreement shall be subject to full legal review by mutual legal counsels. 4. The MOU is effective as of the date set forth above. II. Intent of the Memorandum of Understanding for State-to-State recognition of border infrastructure needs 1. It is the intent of the Arizona - Mexico Commission from the Arizona Governor's Office to facilitate the State of Sonora's process in generating a similar resolution to coordinate Sonora's border infrastructure needs. 2. It is the intent of the Arizona-Mexico Commission for the State of Sonora to develop joint timelines for developing border infrastructure with the State of Arizona to accomplish the much-needed port of entry projects within the Arizona-Sonora region. 3. It is the intent that once the State of Sonora presents a similar resolution, the port of entry projects within Arizona and Sonora will be executed simultaneously in a timely manner. III. Status of the parties Nothing in this MOU shall be construed so as to create a partnership or agency agreement of reciprocity. The Governor's Office in each state must meet all federal and state requirements to utilize this resolution as a tool to give knowledge to decision makers and the dissemination of information to stakeholders.

USBE Agreement Number: USBE180083MOU Parties to further the development of mutual understanding and to support the linguistic and academic development of Chinese-speaking students. It will also support the shared belief that the next generation of Utah citizens would benefit from developing deep knowledge of the Chinese language and culture to increase their opportunities in the growing global economy, through educational collaboration. The cooperative programs which will be supported under this MOU are intended to facilitate the improvement of the quality and extent of the teaching of the Chinese language immersion program in the State of Utah, in order to: Cultivate intercultural competence through global educational experience; Promote mutual understanding and mutual respect between the two cultures; Provide students who enroll in these programs with a high level of bilingual and multicultural education for the student's personal, academic and professional success in the future; Offer professional growth opportunities to teachers of the State of Utah and of The People's Republic of China; and Advance the scholarship of teaching and learning in Chinese language immersion language programs through intellectual discussions, conferences, practicum, and teaching resources development efforts. ARTICLE II Program Components The basic means of cooperation between Hanban and the BOARD OF EDUCATION will be implemented through the following possible programs upon further negotiations on each: 1) Establishing Confucius Institutes and Classrooms; 2 Selecting and inviting qualified visiting teachers, and volunteer teaching assistants from China; - Developing and acquiring teaching materials suitable for Chinese language immersion teaching in Utah; 4 Offering scholarships for students with high academic achievements in Chinese language learning; 5) Providing student immersive summer camp experiences in China; 6) Facilitating educators and school administrators' visiting professional development programs in Utah and China; 7) Conducting educator professional learning under the direction of Utah State Board of Education; 8) Organizing Chinese language immersion conference to advance the scholarship of teaching and learning; 9) Collaborating on exchanges with visiting Chinese students and educators; 10) Coordinating efforts on additional initiatives as mutually agreed upon. Page 2 of 4

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE STATE OF ARIZONA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA AND THE MINISTRY OF COMMUNICATIONS AND TRANSPORT OF THE UNITED MEXICAN STATES ON THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A JOINT PLANNING COMMITTEE ON THE BINATIONAL TRADE CORRIDOR CONSISTING OF MEXICO HIGHWAY 15 AND THE PORT OF ENTRY SYSTEM IN ARIZONA AND THE STATE AND FEDERAL HIGHWAYS THAT LINK THE PORTS TO THE FEDERAL HIGHWAY SYSTEM

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE STATE OF ARIZONA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA AND THE MINISTRY OF COMMUNICATIONS AND TRANSPORT OF THE UNITED MEXICAN STATES ON THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A JOINT PLANNING COMMITTEE ON THE BINATIONAL TRADE CORRIDOR CONSISTING OF MEXICO HIGHWAY 15 AND THE PORT OF ENTRY SYSTEM IN ARIZONA AND THE STATE AND FEDERAL HIGHWAYS THAT LINK THE PORTS TO THE FEDERAL HIGHWAY SYSTEM The Ministry of Communications and Transport of the United Mexican States and the State of Arizona of the United States of America (the State or Arizona), hereinafter referred to as "the Participants"; WHEREAS: I. The governments of the State of Arizona and the United Mexican States have a history of friendship and excellent cooperation, including on issues related to infrastructure and commerce. II. The Ports of Entry between the United Mexican States and the United States of America represent an important economic factor that requires adequate land connections in order to exchange goods. III. Ongoing bi-national cooperation between the United States of America and the United Mexican States to construct and maintain infrastructure at the Ports of Entry and along important international trade routes is critical for the safe and efficient flow of people and goods. IV. On May 2, 2013, President Barack Obama and President Enrique Pena Nieto agreed to establish a High Level Economic Dialogue, to advance strategic economic and commercial priorities central to promoting mutual economic growth, job creation, and competitiveness. V. Both Presidents reaffirmed the importance of the 21st Century Border Management Initiative, in which the United States of America and the United Mexican States agreed to support key projects and initiatives that improve infrastructure, facilitate the secure flow of legitimate commerce and travel, and enhance law enforcement cooperation along the border. VI. The United Mexican States' National Development Plan 2013-2018 outlines its main administration goals and policy actions. The "Prosperous Mexico" section focuses on modernizing, expanding and maintaining the infrastructure for all modes of transportation as well as improving its connectivity through the use of strategic criteria and efficiency. This approach will allow for a transportation infrastructure that promotes economic development at a lower cost. The "Prosperous Mexico" promotes the development of new infrastructure that in turn promotes competition, innovation and growth in strategic sectors, and also assesses the long-term infrastructure needs for 2

economic growth considering regional development, demographic trends, and international connectivity, among others. VII. The State of Arizona is committed to fostering global trade and established the Transportation and Trade Corridor Alliance to promote the development of transportation infrastructure that facilitates global trade and tourism and fosters job creation, with a particular focus on trade with the United Mexican States, Arizona's largest trading partner. VIII. Mexico Highway 15 is the most important corridor in western United Mexican States and the primary corridor providing access to Arizona, California and the inter-mountain west of the United States. IX. The United States of America and the State of Arizona have made a significant investment into the corridor's major commercial point of entry into the United States, the Mariposa Port of Entry (known in Mexico as Nogales II), totaling more than $250 million in combined investments between the United States of America federal government and the Arizona Department of Transportation. X. The SCT has also made a significant investment into Highway 15, which connects central Mexico and the states of Mexico, Jalisco, Nayarit, Sinaloa and Sonora to the border with Arizona. These improvements include the construction of bypasses around major cities, such as Guadalajara, Tepic, Culiacan, Ciudad Obregon and Hermosillo, in order to improve the efficiency of the corridor and the safety of the traveling public. XI. Major challenges remain in the corridor, including inadequate infrastructure, insufficient personnel, bottlenecks, concerns about security, and the need to modernize the corridor to include technology improvements and intelligent transportation systems. Have reached the following understanding: Paragraph 1 Objective The Participants intend to create a Joint Planning Committee ("Committee") with representatives from the SCT, and the State of Arizona. The understanding for the Committee is the following: the Committee should collaborate to improve the Binational Corridor that is comprised of Interstate 19 (1-19) in Arizona and Highway 15 (MX-15) in Mexico. This corridor is the primary north-south corridor in Western United Mexican States and the Western United States of America and critically important to the overall economic development and trade of both countries. The Committee should establish a working plan to improve the physical infrastructure and policies that should enable this corridor to become more efficient. 3

WHEREAS the Secretariat of the Economy of the State of Sonora is a state public administration department in charge of economic development, and the Secretariat of the Economy of the State ofSonora is committed to the promotion of innovation in strategic sectors that creates new jobs and stimulates economic vibrancy; WHEREAS the Participants have demonstrated their commitment to develop a dynamic platform for businesses of all sizes in key sectors through joint marketing and communications, supplier development and Business to Business B2B forums; WHEREAS the two states recognize the importance of deeper cross-border collaborations to produce a robust and highly performing ecosystem geared toward a global knowledge-based economy and to ensure economic competitiveness, quality jobs and a high standard ofliving; WHEREAS promoting the development, transfer and commercialization of technology will yield significant regional economic benefits and spill-over effects; WHEREAS global capital investments in early stage technology firms exceeded $140 billion in 2017; WHEREAS research indicates that increased global connectedness helps startups acquire critical knowledge, develop effective business models, increase their performance level and grow their revenues twice as fast; Declaration of Cooperation between the State of Sonora of the United Mexican States, through the Department of the Economy, the Department of Infrastructure and Urban Development, and the Tourism Development Commission, and the State of Arizona of the United States of America, through the Arizona Commerce Authority, the Department of Transportation, and the Arizona Office of Tourism (collectively "Participants"), to Catalyze and Promote the Cruise Ship Port, also known as the "Home Port" of Puerto Penasco, Sonora. RECITALS WHEREAS the States of Sonora and Arizona share a strong relationship of binational cooperation in various economic and social areas through the mechanisms of the Sonora-Arizona Commission and the Arizona-Mexico Commission; the States of Sonora and Arizona share an innovative, exemplary bilateral relationship, thanks to a history of trust and collaboration that has developed tangible results, strengthened both states in accordance with their mission to improve the quality of life in the region, and led to the development of actions and programs of mutual interest. WHEREAS there is great interest by the States of Sonora and Arizona in promoting economic development and tourism, as well as taking advantage of the geographic location and the existing connectivity in the region with the objective of improving quality of life in the region; WHEREAS currently under construction is a maritime cruise ship terminal, named Home Port of Puerto Penasco, Sonora, located in the northwestern part of the State of Sonora, at a distance of 100 kilometers (62 miles) from Sonoyta-Lukville Port of Entry; WHEREAS Puerto Penasco is a tourism destination for many Arizonans; WHEREAS the Lukeville-Sonoyta Port of Entry is the principal border crossing for Arizona visitors to Puerto Penasco; WHEREAS Arizona, in a unique partnership with the Puerto Penasco Visitors and Conventions Bureau, and its federal partners, have invested $2.5 million to construct two additional inspection lanes at the Sonoyta-Lukeville Port of Entry; WHEREAS, in two-way traffic, more than 1.8 million people crossed at the Sonoyta-Lukeville port of entry in 2016; WHEREAS Puerto Penasco has an international airport, 340 kilometers (215 miles) away from Sky Harbor Airport in Phoenix, with an influx of more than 40 million passengers per year; WHEREAS the construction of the Home Port is over 50% complete, and this is a priority project for the government of the State of Sonora because of the economic impact it will have on the Sonora-Arizona region; WHEREAS in 2015, more than 474 thousand Arizonans took cruises, while in California the total for the same year and mode of transportation reached approximately 1.24 million; 2

Declaration of Cooperation between the Government of the State of Sonora, through the Department of Infrastructure and Urban Development (SIDUR), and the Government of the State of Arizona, though the Arizona Department Transportation (ADOT), for the establishment of a cooperative and collaborative economic development initiative and participation in the development of a Safety Commercial Logistical Corridor Program. SIDUR and ADOT are collectively the "Participants." RECITALS WHEREAS, the States of Arizona and Sonora share a border of 568 kilometers (353 miles) and have 6 ports of entry that connect the two states; WHEREAS, the States of Arizona and Sonora have a long history of collaboration in cultural, social, entrepreneurial and shared history, founded on a common entrepreneurial spirit; WHEREAS, the Arizona-Sonora region is a vibrant binational economy that has experienced significant growth and diversification; WHEREAS, Arizona and Sonora are strategically situated as ideal gateways for their respective domestic markets; WHEREAS, both states are working together to create the Arizona-Mexico Corridor, a state- of-the-art binational infrastructure corridor that is an ideal location for investment, job creation and tourism; WHEREAS, both states are committed to enhancing the safety of the traveling public; WHEREAS, both states are committed to fostering a corridor that contributes to the safe and secure movement of people and goods and enhances the competitiveness of companies that invest in the region; WHEREAS, both states recognize the intrinsic relationship between modern transportation infrastructure systems and regional economic development; WHEREAS, the advancement and development of innovative transport mechanisms facilitate supply chain mobility and enhance the competitiveness of the region; WHEREAS, Arizona and Sonora have jointly worked to promote and implement truck driver training programs that have positively impacted compliance with safety requirements and enhanced the safety of roads and highways in the region; WHEREAS, Sonora and Arizona have advocated for and worked together to establish the Safety Corridor between Lukeville and Puerto Penasco, Sonora with great results for the safety of the traveling public; CONSEJERIA JURIDICA DEL PODERAECUTIVO

THE OF DITAT DEUS ESTADO DE SONORA 1912 DECLARATION OF COOPERATION BETWEEN THE STATE OF SONORA OF THE UNITED MEXICAN STATES, THROUGH THE DEPARTMENT OF THE ECONOMY, THE DEPARTMENT OF INFRASTRUCTURE AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT, AND THE TOURISM DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION, AND THE STATE OF ARIZONA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, THROUGH THE ARIZONA COMMERCE AUTHORITY, THE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION, AND THE ARIZONA OFFICE OF TOURISM, TO CATALYZE AND PROMOTE THE CRUISE SHIP PORT,ALSO KNOWN AS THE "HOME PORT" OF PUERTO PENASCO, SONORA

WHEREAS the launch of operations of the cruise terminal is necessary because it represents an important tourism and economic focal point for the development of both States; and WHEREAS currently Puerto Penasco has sustainable hotel infrastructure to host the cruise travelers and it also has capacity for expansion. Based on the aforementioned considerations, the government of the State of Sonora and the government of the State of Arizona pledge the following: ACTIONS 1. The governments of the States of Arizona and Sonora will undertake good faith efforts to exchange non-confidential information regarding the development and promotion of the "Home Port" project at Puerto Penasco, Sonora; 2. The governments of the States of Arizona and Sonora will continue their efforts to advance projects that modernize and facilitate the flow of tourism at the Sonoyta-Lukeville Port of Entry; 3. The governments of the States of Arizona and Sonora will serve as a source of information in order to educate both state and federal government agencies on the importance of the Home Port project; 4. The governments of the States of Arizona and Sonora will continue good faith efforts to encourage the participation of the private sector, where applicable, in the development of the Home Port; 5. The governments of the States of Arizona and Sonora will promote supply chain opportunities for the cruise ships, including goods and services coming from the State of Arizona; and 6. The State of Sonora will continue its efforts to complete the "Home Port" project. This statement is signed on Friday, June 2 of the year two thousand and seventeen, within the framework of the Plenary Session between the Arizona-Mexico Commission and the Sonora-Arizona Commission, held in Scottsdale, Arizona. This Declaration of Cooperation is intended to memorialize the Participants' commitment to explore ways to promote collaboration between them, but it is non-binding and does not create any legal or binding obligation between the States. Nothing in this Declaration of Cooperation should be read to conflict with the laws and regulations off the United States of America or the United Mexican States (or any state or local jurisdiction), or with any relevant international agreements. There are no third-party beneficiaries to this Declaration of Cooperation. This Declaration of Cooperation will be effective on the date of its signature and will be valid for 5 years. The State of Arizona or the State of Sonora may terminate its participation under this Declaration of Cooperation at any time through a written notice of termination. Nonetheless, the State of Arizona or the State of Sonora should endeavor to give the other party 30 days written notice of its intention to terminate this Declaration of Cooperation. The termination should not preclude the completion of any cooperative 3

Declaration of Cooperation between the Government of the State of Arizona, through the Arizona Department of' Transportation and the Government of the State of Sonora, through the Secretariat ofl Infrastructure and Urban Development, for the Arizona-Sonora Border Master Plan, which will serve as a guide to form the regional plan of Sonora and Arizona for thej promotion of trade, tourism and commerce. Whereas, through the mechanisms of the Arizona-Mexico Commission and the Comision Sonora-Arizona, the states of Arizona and Sonora share an innovative, exemplary bilateral partnership; and Whereas, this partnership is possible because of a history oft trust and collaboration between Sonora and Arizona, and has yielded tangible results; and Whereas, this collaboration strengthens both states to act. according to their commitment to improving the quality ofl life in our region; and Whereas, today, Mexico is. Arizona's largest international trading partner making up roughly 33 percent of Arizona's $6 billion in foreign exports; and Whereas, travel between the State of Arizona and the State of Sonora at the international border has increased significantly over the last 10 years, with nearly 42 million people crossing the border between Arizona and Sonora in 2011; and Whereas, nearly half of all of the winter produce consumed in the United States passes through the Arizona-Sonora land ports of entry,and Whereas, the transportation infrastructure that carries people, goods and services is a necessary foundation for continued economic development; and Whereas, the Arizona-Sonora Border Master Plan presents a comprehensive bi-national approach to coordinating the planning and delivery of projects to improve the capacity and operations oft both land ports of entry and the transportation infrastructure providing access to these ports; and Whereas, preparation of the Arizona-Sonora Border Master Plan is part of an overall effort by thel United States Federal Highway Administration and the Mexico Ministry of Communications and' Transportation to identify and implement methods to relieve congestion at border crossings.

Declaration of cooperation between the Government of the State of Sonora, through the Department of Infrastructure and Urban Development (SIDUR) and the Government of the State of Arizona, though the Department Transportation (ADOT), for the establishment of a cooperative and collaborative initiative and the participation in the Safety Corridor Program between Lukeville/Sonoyta and Puerto Penasco, Sonora. RECITALS WHEREAS, the States of Arizona and Sonora share a border of 568 kilometers (353 miles) and have 6 ports of entry that connect: the two states; WHEREAS, the States of Arizona and Sonora have a long history of collaboration in cultural, social, entrepreneurial and shared history, founded on a common entrepreneurial spirit; while the Arizona-Sonora region is a vibrant binational economy that has experienced an important level of growth and diversification; WHEREAS, Arizona and Sonora are strategically situated as ideal gateways for their respective domestic markets; WHEREAS, the tourism destination of Puerto Penasco, Sonora, has become a major destination for tourists from Arizona that want to visit Sonora beaches; WHEREAS, thousands of Arizonans travel along this corridor throughout the year and in greater numbers during key vacation periods; WHEREAS, due to increased flows there has been an increase in accidents and road safety concerns; WHEREAS, ADOT has implemented several safety programs and initiatives to enhance the safety of Arizona roads and highways; WHEREAS, Arizona and Sonora are committed to the safety of the traveling public on their respective roads and highways.

EXPRESS their willingness to cooperate, in the search of joint actions that improve environmental quality and optimize the quality of life in the State of Acre, the State of Chiapas, and the State of California. ARTICLE 1 This Memorandum of Understanding is intended to promote broader cooperation regarding environmental issues among the Parties within their respective purview and based on principles of reciprocity, information exchange and mutual benefit. ARTICLE 2 The Parties will coordinate efforts and promote collaboration for environmental management, scientific and technical investigation, and capacity building, through cooperative efforts focused particularly on: a. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation and land degradation - otherwise known as "REDD" - and sequestration of additional carbon through the restoration and reforestation of degraded lands and forests, and through improved forest management practices. b. Developing recommendations together to ensure that forest-sector emissions reductions and sequestrations, from activities undertaken at the sub-national level, will be real, additional, quantifiable, permanent, verifiable and enforceable, and capable of being recognized in compliance mechanisms of each party's state. ARTICLE 3 In furtherance of the priorities referenced in Article 2, the Parties will develop the following method of cooperation, among others: a. The states will develop a Sub-national REDD Working Group that will convene monthly between December 2010 through October 2011 to begin the process for developing a state to state sectoral REDD linkage recommendation that will provide the foundation for an eventual submittal to the California Air Resources Board, as defined in California's cap and trade program (CCR, Title 17, Sections 95991-95997) and to other necessary state entities to approve such a recommendation amongst the Parties. This group will weigh the legal, technical and economic considerations in developing sector-based credits generated by the Parties. This group should include no more than 15 representatives with experience developing sector-based REDD programs or directly involved with the states supplying the credits, or from the California state government. MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING ON ENVIRONMENTAL COOPERATION BETWEEN THE STATE OF ACRE OF THE FEDERATIVE REPUBLIC OF BRAZIL, THE STATE OF CHIAPAS OF THE UNITED MEXICAN STATES, AND THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA The State of Acre of the Federative Republic of Brazil, the State of Chiapas of the United Mexican States, and the State of California of the United States of America, hereinafter referred to as "the Parties": ACKNOWLEDGING the friendship and excellent cooperation among the governments of the Federative Republic of Brazil, the United Mexican States, and the United States of America; TAKING INTO ACCOUNT the global nature of environmental problems and the ability of joint efforts to enhance joint policies for environmental protection and sustainable natural resources, especially reducing emissions from deforestation; RATIFYING the willingness to promote new mechanisms of dialogue and agreement that lead to the strengthening of relationships and productive mutual action; CONSIDERING the opportunities for collaboration between the State of Acre, the State of Chiapas, and the State of California in combating climate change; RECOGNIZING the importance and value of implementing climate mitigation and adaptation actions at sub-national levels, both in their own right and as a means to furthering national and international efforts; Recognizing further the importance of focusing on issues of common interest between the Parties, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the forest sector by preserving standing forests and sequestering additional carbon through the restoration and reforestation of degraded lands and forest, and through improved forest management practices; Recognizing further that the Governors' Climate and Forests (GCF) Task Force is a unique subnational collaboration between 14 states and provinces from the United States, Brazil, Indonesia, Nigeria, and Mexico that seeks to integrate Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD) and other forest carbon activities into emerging greenhouse gas (GHG) compliance regimes in the United States and elsewhere. As such, the GCF represents an important foundation for identifying enhanced partnerships.
