ARTICLE I Objective The current Agreement has as its objective to continue the mutual cooperation between both Parties in order to expand the framework of knowledge of both educational systems and to support the Mexican student population and school community by means of the Visiting Teachers Program. ARTICLE II Activities of Cooperation In order to accomplish the objectives of the present Agreement, both Parties will carry out the following activities of cooperation: a. strengthen the bilateral, educative, and cultural cooperation between both educational systems, as well as the mutual understanding and respect between the communities of California and Mexico; b. promote the educational and cultural exchange with the school districts in the State of California; C. support activities that will permit participating teachers to become acquainted with pedagogic innovations and techniques that will J.0. enrich their different teaching styles; d. support projects that will benefit and enrich the cultural diversity and educational investigations in both Mexico and the State of California, and e. agree on the terms of the Request for Teacher Applications and the dates of the selection process for the Visiting Teachers Program between Mexico and California. à

ARTICLE IlI Specific Actions of Cooperation I. The Secretary of Public Education of Mexico (SEP) will carry out the following activities: a. publish the annual Request for Teacher Applications for the Visiting Teachers Program; b. evaluate the academic formation and experience of the teacher applicants; C. pre-select, notify and offer orientation to the Mexican teacher candidates that fulfill the requirements for the English exam and have the experience and the qualities to teach in the K-12 California educational system; d. provide the California Department of Education the necessary information concerning the Mexican teachers - interested in participating in the Visiting Teachers Program; e. motivate Mexican bilingual teachers to participate in California's Migrant Education summer programs that can provide them with training in teaching techniques; f. collaborate in the monitoring and evaluation of the Mexican teachers in the state of California; g. encourage the exchange of educational and cultural materials between both educational systems; J.U. h. encourage the participation of American teachers in educational and cultural activities in Mexican schools; and i. organize continuing education and training courses for teachers and specialists in areas of interest to both parties. II. The California Department of Education will carry out the following activities: a, provide the. necessary information to the Secretary of Public Education of Mexico (SEP) regarding the participating school districts and all the activities outlined in this Agreement;

OF 3 THE - CALIFORNIA Joint Declaration To Support Sustainable Economic Development, and the Exchange and Application ofMutually Beneficial Sustainable Urban Infrastructure, Water Management, Biodiversity, Transportation, Applied Science, Energy andClimate Change Technologies and Policies between The State ofCalifornia ofthe United States of America and The Government ofthe French Republic

Joint Declaration To Support Sustainable Economic Development and the Exchange and Application of Mutually Beneficial Sustainable Urban Infrastructure, Water Management, Biodiversity, Transportation, Applied Science, Energy and Climate Change Technologies and Policies Between The Government of the French Republic And The State of California of the United States of America This. Joint Declaration is entered into by the Government of the French Republic ("France") and the State of California of the United States of America ("California"). WHEREAS, France and California are world-renowned for their natural beauty, as well as their rich agricultural lands and forests; WHEREAS, these abundant natural resources have tremendous ecological value and provide numerous economic benefits; WHEREAS, France and California are global leaders in the fields of communication and innovation, and home to internationally renowned urban centers, academic institutions, and hubs for advanced technology development; WHEREAS, the impact of climate change imposes a grave danger to the natural resources in France and California, threatens human health and public safety, as well as agriculture and food security, and threatens economic prosperity; WHEREAS, France and California face similar environmental challenges from thei impact of climate change, including watershed management and supply, drought, flooding, wildfire, heat waves and coastal erosion; WHEREAS France and California seek to enhance the development and commercialization of innovation through applied-research partnerships that build on the scientific and technical expertise of French and Californian advanced research institutions in the fields of Sustainable Urban Infrastructure, Water Management, Biodiversity, Transportation, Applied Science, and Energy and Climate Technologies and Policies;

12) Cooperating in any other form that France and California consider may contribute to the goals of this. Joint Declaration. 4. FOLLOW UP France and California agree to establish a bilateral group or groups, led by officials representing France and California, to maintain coordination and communication in monitoring cooperation under this Joint Declaration. As part of their coordination, France and California intend to consider the need for in-person meetings, subject to available resources. 5. THIRD PARTY PARTICIPATION If France and California agree to deem it helpful and feasible, individuals and entities from the private, public, academic, research, and other sectors may be invited to support the cooperative activities described herein, provided that they can directly and meaningfully contribute to the objectives of this Joint Declaration. 6. ADDITIONAL COOPERATION This. Joint Declaration may: serve as reference for signing further collaborative instruments in the areas of cooperation provided in this Joint Declaration. 7. FUNDING Neither France nor California is obligated to provide or allocate funding for any of the activities referred to in this Joint Declaration. France and California may utilize resources already allocated in their respective budgets, as these resources become available and as stipulated by their own legislation. Each Participant intends to pay for expenses related to its own participation, unless alternative financial mechanisms can be used for specific activities, as appropriate and as approved by their respective authority. 8. EXCHANGE OF INFORMATION France and California agree, to the extent possible, that all useful, non-confidential information that supports the objectives of this Joint Declaration may be shared amongst them in other to achieve the objectives of this. Joint Declaration. 10. AMENDMENTS This Joint Declaration may be modified in writing by mutual consent of France and California. 11. DURATION

Unless otherwise extended in writing, this Joint Declaration is effective for a period of 4 years from the date of signing. Either France or California may discontinue its participation in this Joint Declaration, through written communication sent to the other Participant thirty (30) calendar days in advance. In this case, the ongoing cooperative activities that have been approved or initiated and that have not been concluded will continue, unless otherwise decided by France and California. 12. FINAL PROVISIONS France and California acknowledge that this Joint Declaration is only intended to provide for cooperation betweent them and does not create any legally binding rights or obligations under national or international law. To the extent that any other provision of this Joint Declaration is inconsistent with this paragraph, this paragraph shall prevail. France and California sign this Joint Declaration in good faith and declare their intention to develop cooperation to the fullest extent possible, subject to any changes in relevant policy that they may adopt. This Joint Declaration is signed in Paris, France on December 7th, 2015 in two originals, with both the English and French language originals being equally valid. For the Government of the French Republic For the State of California United States of America Ségolène Royal Minister for Ecology, Sustainable Development 7 an and Energy Edmund Gerald Brown Jr. Governor

A Participant that intends to withdraw from this MOU shall endeavor to provide notice of such withdrawal to other Participants thirty (30) days in advance. The termination of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect activities initiated during its term, unless a Participant expressly states otherwise. A Participant that intends to terminate a previously initiated activity shall endeavor to reach an understanding with the other Participant concerning such termination. COOPERATIVE PROGRAMS The cooperation between the Ministry and the Department will be demonstrated through the following programs: II.1.- California/Spain Visiting Teachers Program II.1.1.- The Department and the Ministry have been coordinating the California/Spain Visiting Teachers Program (CSVTP) since 1986. Teachers from Spain have made important contributions to the school communities and to the academic success of English learners. The purposes of the agreement for the CSVTP are to: II.1.2.- Place teachers from Spain in kindergarten through twelfth grade (K-12) public school teaching positions for one to a maximum of three years where their language skills, professional expertise, and experience can enrich the education of California's students; II.1.3.- Provide the visiting teachers, as well as California students, teachers, administrators, and the state's general public witha-cros-cultural experience-that-can fostermutual understanding and respect; and II.1.4.- Create opportunities for the visiting teachers to collaborate in professional development that improves teacher and student performance and which allows for a better understanding of the United States culture, society, and teaching practices. II.1.5.- The Department, in collaboration with the Ministry: a) Will promote the recruitment of highly qualified teachers from Spain to teach in school districts that have Spanish as a Foreign Language courses and/or bilingual programs. b) Agrees to invite school districts to take part in the program and will designate the districts that will participate each year. c) Agrees to assist school districts each year in the screening and placement of highly qualified teachers from Spain who may be contracted for classroom teaching assignments for one to three

OF GOBIERNO MINSTERIO DE ESPANA DE EDUCKOION CULTURA MDPORTE OF CALIE Ministry of Education, Culture and Sport of Spain California Department of Education In recognition of the importance that the English and Spanish languages carry as means of communication between individuals, and countries, and of the valuable role languages play in the exchange of ideas in the fields of economy, science, and culture; Driven by the desire to advance the goals of mutual understanding and mutual respect between the citizens of their respective territories and to provide the key elements of multicultural education and training to participants in California and Spain; and Conscious of the results and the experiences gained over the past 27 years of collaborative work; THEREFORE, resolve to establish a new Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). This MOU is hereby signed in due form pursuant to the following Agreements: I.- GENERAL PRINCIPLES I.1.- The Ministry and the Department have established the following objectives for the continued development and implementation of cooperative programs under this MOU for improving the quality of teaching the Spanish language and culture in California and the English language and North American culture in Spain: a) To provide professional learning opportunities to teachers and administrators in California and Spain; b) To provide students with a world-class education that trains them to be bi-literate and successful in a multilingual global economy and work force; c) To foster knowledge and appreciation of the rich cultures shared between Spain and California; and d) To promote relationships between.the citizens of California and Spain. I.2.- The MOU will cover the schools that teach Spanish and/or other subjects of the curriculum in Spanish as defined in state and federal law, and will adhere to the curriculum frameworks and common core standards developed by the Department and school districts to satisfy the demands and needs of the school population.

COPY OF  DE GOBIERNO ESPANA DE MINSTERIO EDUCACION, CULTURA a Y.DIPORTE : tAE Pr CALIE Ministry of Education, Culture and Sport of Spain California Department of Education MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE MINISTRY OF EDUCATION, CULTURE AND SPORT OF SPAIN BACKGROUND AND RESOLUTION This Memorandum of Understanding (hereafter "MOU") is entered into by the Ministry of Education of Spain (hereafter referred to as the Ministry), represented by Mr. Xavier Gisbert da Cruz, Counselor of Education of the Embassy of Spain to the United States, by approved signing on behalf of the State Secretary of Education, Vocational Training and Universities; and the California State Department of Education (hereafter referred to as the Department) represented by Tom Torlakson, State Superintendent of Public Instruction and approved signing authority on its behalf. On July. 2, 1986, the California Department of Education and the Ministry of Education of Spain, established a historic Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). The initial MOU was expanded and accepted by both parties in May 1989. In February 1993, January 1997, February 2000, and February 2005, the MOU was revised and newly signed. The Department and the Ministry recognized the benefits derived from the collaborative efforts and programs, and therefore expressed the desire to continue the collaboration. In the past years, important changes in education have taken place both in California and in Spain. This circumstance, while imposing new challenges and demanding new solutions to both the Department and the Ministry, underscores the tremendous value of international collaboration. The Department and the Ministry:

Utah State Board of Education Memorandum of Understanding between the Utah State Board of Education, USA and the Parana State for its Secretary of Science, Technology and Higher Education, Brazil BACKGROUND AND RESOLUTION The Utah State Board of Education and the Parana State for its Secretary of Science, Technology and Higher Education, Recognize the importance off the English and Portuguese languages as a means of communication between individuals as well as countries, and of the valuable role the languages play in the exchange of ideas in the fields of economy, science, history and culture; Are driven by the mutual desire to strengthen ties between the citizens of their respective communities: and to cooperate in the efforts ofl both agencies to design the educational model of this new millennium; interculturalism will be an essential element; Are conscious of the possibilities that the collaboration of both agencies offer in the field of education; Therefore: a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is hereby signed in due form and both parties accept the following Agreements: I. GENERAL PRINCIPLES The objective of this Memorandum of Understanding is to establish the terms of cooperation in the development of joint educational activities in order to: a. AMENDMENT TO THE MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND THE MINISTRY OF PUBLIC EDUCATION, BOTH OF THE UNITED MEXICAN STATES AND THE UTAH STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (SRE), through the Consulate of Mexico in Salt Lake City, Utah, and the Institute of Mexicans Abroad, and the Ministry of Public Education (SEP), all ofthe United Mexican States; and the State Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State of Utah, of the United States of America, hereinafter referred to as "the Parties"; CONSIDERING the provisions of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Public Education of the United Mexican States and the Utah State Board of Education of the United States of America, signed in Mexico City on June 28, 2007 and in Salt Lake City, on June 11 of the same year (the Memorandum); DESIRING to expand the accomplishments achieved by the Parties in the development of programs focused on the advancement and training for educational personnel from both countries who serve the needs of the Spanish-speaking population; DECLARING their desire to unify the meaning of the Memorandum, considering that, in the evaluation ofi its content, differences were observed in the Spanish and English versions, specifically with respect to its validity; Have agreed to the following: FIRST: Unify the meaning of the Memorandum in the Spanish and English written versions, in such a way that the first paragraph of ARTICLE VIII "Final Provisions" reads as follows: "The present Memorandum shall enter into force from the date of its signature and shall be valid for three (3) years, automatically renewable for periods of equal duration, unless one of the Parties decides to terminate it by written notice addressed to the Other, with one hundred and eighty (180) days in advance". SECOND: To reaffirm their interest in maintaining the operation of the Memorandum, in order to continue implementing with what is established in its and continue executing the Visiting Teacher's Program. objective The present Amendment shall become integral part of the shall enter into force from the date of its signature. MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS (SRE) AND THE MINISTRY OF PUBLIC EDUCATION (SEP) OF THE UNITED STATES OF MEXICO, AND THE UTAH STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, through, the Mexican Consulate of Mexico in Salt Lake City, Utah), the Institute of Mexicans Abroad, and the Ministry of Public Education (SEP) of the United States of Mexico, and the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, of the State of Utah, of the United States of America, are hereinafter referred to as "the Parties"; e CONSIDERING the accomplishment achieved by the Parties in the development of a series of programs focused on the advancement and training of educational personnel from both countries who serve the needs of the Spanish-speaking population; RECOGNIZING the importance of establishing collaborative programs that serve mutual needs and interests; CONSIDERING the linguistic and cultural richness of the Mexican and Hispanic heritages in the State of Utah, together with its historical ties with Mexico, which bestow a special quality upon Alternative Language Services Programs and Multicultural Education that are supported by the State of Utah; TAKING INTO ACCOUNT that this historical tradition has been reflected in the ML various bilateral agreements between the Governments of Mexico and Utah; IN ACCORDANCE WITH the precepts of Appendix VIII of the Memorandum of Understanding on Education between the Government of the United States of Mexico and the Government of the United States of America, on the 9jof November of 2004;

UTASTATE OF FICE OF MINISTERIO DE EDUCACION Y CIENCIA EDUCATIONT Ministerio de Educacion y Ciencia Utah State Office of Education I. GENERAL PRINCIPLES I.1. - The Ministry and the USOE have established as the main objectives for the cooperative programs that will be developed under this MOU the improvement of the quality and extent of the teaching of Spanish language and culture in Utah, and the English language and North American culture in Spain, in order to: a) Promote relationships between citizens ofUtah and Spain; b) Foster knowledge and appreciation oft the culture shared by the two communities; Provide students who enrol in these programs with a bilingual and multicultural education that trains them for future personal, academic and professional success; and d) Provide professional growth opportunities to teachers ofUtah and Spain. 1.2.-All plans and programs subject to this MOU will be implemented in order to obtain quality standards in English as well as Spanish. II. COOPERATIVE PROGRAMS The basic means of cooperation between the Ministry and the USOE will be implemented through the following programs: II.1.- Visiting Teachers. Each school year, the USOE and the school districts will cooperate with the Ministry in the selection of a number of qualified teachers from Spain who may be hired under local contract in elementary, middle and/or secondary classrooms in school districts in Utah. II.1.1. - The USOE, in collaboration with the Ministry, will promote the assignment of teachers from Spain who are specially qualified to teach in bilingual programs and/or teach Spanish language and culture. 2

Agreement # USBE230006MOU Utah State Board of Education GOBIERNO DEE ESPANA DEE MINISTERIO EDUCACION YFORMACIONE PROFESIONAL Both Signatories agree to sign this Memorandum, the purpose of which is to foster and consolidate a collaborative relationship between the Board and the Ministry in order to promote the Spanish language and culture, through the following objectives and activities. 1. General Objectives a. Encourage intercultural exchanges between the citizens of the State of Utah and Spain. b. Advance the understanding and appreciation of the culture of both countries. C. Strengthen bilateral ties in education and amplify the presence of the education of Spain in the United States. d. Improve the quality of education in both countries by providing bilingual and multicultural education which prepares students who participate in these programs to enable personal, academic, and professional success. e. Provide professional development opportunities to educators and other professionals in the field of education of Utah and Spain. 2. General Actions In orderto pursue the aforementioned objectives between thel Ministry and the Board, the following programs and actions will be engaged in. a. Encouraging the study of Spanish and the implementation of nigh-performance dual language programs in Spanish and English in the state of Utah. b. Facilitating the recruitment of Visiting Teachers from Spain by the schools of the state of Utah. C. Disseminating information about the multiple programs promoted by ofthe Education Office of Spain, such as the Spanish Language Assistants program and the International Spanish Academies (ISA), as appropriate. d. Offering quality professional development for educators and administrators. e. Promoting the participation in conferences or meetings of mutual interest that the Signatories could encourage. f. Developing exchanges and networks between students and educators from Spain and Utah. g. Organizing joint activities that promote the Spanish language and culture targeted at professionals, educators and students. h. Disseminating information on cultural activities, professional development, educational opportunities and other initiatives in Spain and in the State of Utah that may contribute to the goals of this Memorandum of Understanding. i. Exchanging regulations and best practices pertaining to educational leadership in administration and management and bilingual education, as well as in the research towards the development of specific programs for language educators. j. Exchanging written instructional materials related to the language and culture of Spain. 2

UTABLSTATE OFFICE OF MINISTERIO DE EDUCACION Y CIENCIA EDUCATION Ministerio de Educacion y Ciencia Utah State Office of Education II.2. - In-Service' Training Programs for Teachers and Administrators. II.2.1. - The Ministry will promote the enrolment of teachers and administrators of Utah in courses provided by Spanish universities for the teaching of Spanish as a second language. Scholarships will be offered to defray part of the costs of said courses. II.2.2. - The USOE will take steps to recognize the above cited courses taken at accredited Spanish universities. II.3. - International Spanish Academies. The USOE and the Ministry may collaborate in the creation of a network of English/Spanish bilingual schools known as International Spanish Academies. The main objective of this initiative would be to enable the implementation ofl high quality bilingual education with support from the Ministry and other Spanish institutions, such as Instituto Cervantes, dedicated to the promotion of Spanish. In addition to the participation in the programs mentioned in previous clauses of this Memorandum, the Ministry will offer to the schools integrated in this network the following: access to dual academic certification, facilitating the accreditation of their studies for their equivalent ones in the Spanish educational system, specific teacher training activities in the United States, sister schools in Spain, pedagogical guidance, development of educational projects with Spanish schools using Internet support and, when available, classroom and curricular materials and resources. II.4. -Other ongoing initiatives: II.4.1. - Internet - World Wide Web: The Ministry and the USOE agree to discuss the development of e-mail exchanges among students and educators in classrooms in Utah and Spain, along with the maintenance of a web site for the program. II.4.2. - Students/Educators Exchange Program: The Ministry and the USOE agree to discuss the establishment of exchanges between schools in Utah and Spain for groups of up to 15 students accompanied by a teacher, for a period of time of about three weeks, to occur at such time as to allow each group to attend regular school in the host country, apart from participating in other activities organized by the receiving school. 4

Have agreed to the following: itural  ARTICLE I Objectives The present Memorandum of Understanding has as its objectives the establishment of cooperation between the Parties to further the development of mutual knowledge of both educational systems; and to support the linguistic and academic development of Spanish-speaking students, including Mexican students in the state of Utah, and other students participating in the Utah Alternative Language Services Programs, through the Visiting Teacher's Program. ARTICLE II Activities of Cooperation For the attainment of the objective in the present Agreement of Collaboration, the Parties will carry out the following activities of cooperation: a. strengthen the bilateral, educational and cultural cooperation between both educational systems, as well as the mutual understanding and respect between the communities of the State of Utah and the United States of Mexico; b. promote the educational and cultural exchange of teachers with Utah school districts; C. strengthen the linguistic and academic development, the knowledge of history, culture, values and traditions for the Mexican students, Mexican-Americans, Hispanics and other participants in the Utah Alternative Language Services Programs in order to strengthen their identity and to improve their education; d. promote appropriate mechanisms for the carrying out of joint projects that will increase quality of teaching staff; -2-

e. support activities that allow the participating teachers to become aware of the pedagogical innovations and techniques that enrich different areas of teaching; f. support research projects that equally benefit and enrich the cultural diversity and educational systems of Mexico and Utah; g. foster a permanent communication between Utah and Mexican teachers. This exchange will contribute to enriching the linguistic competencies of Utah students at the preschool, elementary and secondary levels; h. reinforce the teaching/learning process in the Spanish language, which is recognized as a core curriculum course offering in Utan; i. agree to the terms of the Memorandum between Mexico and Utah and to the selection process for the Visiting Teacher's Program; j. initiate a visiting program of Mexican teachers specialized in Language Acquisition, with the capacity to teach subject areas such as mathematics, natural sciences, humanities, history, Spanish language and special education and other subjects; and k. encourage Utah school districts to participate with the Utah State Office of Education to offer to place Mexican teachers in Utah school districts to provide language acquisition at the preschool, primary and secondary levels in Utah public school districts as part of the state approved Alternative Services education programs previously designated by the Utah State Languages Office of Education. prCC ARTICLE III Specific Actions of Cooperation 1) The Ministry of Public Education of Mexico, will carry out the following activities: a. annually publish the Memorandum for the Visiting Teachers' Program; b. evaluate the academic training and educational experience of applicants; C. pre-select and provide orientation for the Mexican teachers that meet the evaluation requirements and profiles necessary to provide instruction in Utah schools; d. provide necessary information to the Utah State Office of Education regarding the Mexican teachers interested in participating in the Visiting Teacher's Program; -3-

e. Mexican federal and state educational authorities will notify the teachers who have been selected and will facilitate the hiring process; f. collaborate, when requested, in the supervision and evaluation of the performance of Mexican teachers in the State of Utah; g. promote the exchange of educational and cultural materials between both educational systems; h. oversee the timely fulfillment of the commitments established in the Memorandum; - i. grant year to year unpaid leaves for a period of up to three years, upon a commitment from participating teachers, to return to work in the Mexican educational system once their participation in the Visiting Teacher Program has ended, in accordance with laws applicable to the subject matter; and j. provide the necessary facilities for the Utah State Office of Education and school district staff to review documents, conduct interviews, and make final hiring decisions from the group of Mexican teachers pre-selected for interviews by the office of the Secretary of Public Education. 2) The Utah State Office of Education will carry out the following activities: a. facilitate Mexican teachers in attending institutions in the State of Utah in order to further their academic knowledge in studies related to education; b. provide, to the Ministry of Public Education of Mexico, information as needed about school districts and all activities subject to this Agreement; C. disseminate and provide information to school districts regarding the terms and parameters of this Agreement; d. provide support to school districts to facilitate the Mexican teachers' participation in the Visiting Teachers' Program; e. provide information on the location within the school district where the Mexican teachers are assigned to teach; f. provide the necessary assistance SO that participating teachers may obtain a J1 Visa for three years, in order to participate in the Visiting Teachers' Program in the United States of America; +

g. facilitate the licensing process so that the visiting teachers may obtain the quality and professional licenses for teaching in the State; h. participate, in conjunction with the school districts, in the selection process of visiting teachers; i. communicate the names of the selected teachers and the employing school districts to the General Direction of International Relations of the Mexican Ministry of Public Education (SEP), and the representative of the Institute of Mexicans abroad, at the Consulate of Mexico in Salt Lake City, Utah. j. work with participating Utah public school districts to accomplish the following: - 1. facilitate employment agreements between participating teachers in the Visiting Teachers' Program and employing school district, so that these individuals may provide their services to Utah school districts to which they are assigned for a period not to exceed three years; 2. beginning with the first day of work, assure that participating school districts provide salaries and salary payments for the visiting teachers that are consistent with the salary schedules of the employing school districts. 3. encourage the visiting teachers to participate in all activities for professional development that the school district offers; 4. assure that the participating school districts assign, to the selected Mexican teachers an advisor, who will help the teachers to find the proper housing and in case of relocation; 5. define and inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Mexico, the General Direction of International Relations at SEP, in a timely manner, of the criteria and requirements required of the Mexican teachers interested in participating in the Visiting Teachers' Program; 6. provide an estimate of the number positions for which Mexican teachers may qualify as well as the names of the school districts that may participate. 3) The Institute of Mexicans Abroad, via the Mexican Consulate of Salt Lake City, Utah, United State of America, will maintain a constant communication with both the selected teachers and the educational authorities of Utah, in order to evaluate and guarantee the highest fulfillment of this MOU. -5-

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE NEW ENERGY AND INDUSTRIAL TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATION OF JAPAN AND THE CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR'S OFFICE OF BUSINESS AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONCERNING THE DEMONSTRATION PROJECT FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLE DRIVING BEHAVIOR IN CALIFORNIA 1

This Memorandum of Understanding (hereinafter referred to as "MOU") has been made to set forth the agreement between the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization of Japan (hereinafter referred to as "NEDO") and the California Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development (hereinafter referred to as "GO-BIZ"), (NEDO and GO-BIZ are hereinafter referred to singularly as "PARTY" and collectively as "PARTIES"), concerning the Demonstration Project for Validation of Redox Flow Battery Performance in California (hereinafter referred to as the "PROJECT). This MOU builds upon the original framework set forth in the Memorandum of Cooperation on climate change, renewable energy, trade and investment, vehicles, high speed rail and water between the Government of Japan and the State of California of the United States of America dated September 5, 2014. The PARTIES hereby agree as follows: ARTICLE 1 OBJECTIVE AND OUTLINE OF THE PROJECT 1. The objective of the PROJECT is to demonstrate that a redox flow battery can be used for both fast response and long duration applications and would provide significant assistance for issues caused by increased use of renewable energy resources. For purposes of this MOU a redox flow battery is a megawatt scale energy storage device that acts as a grid asset by storing and disbursing electricity at optimal times. 2. The demonstration system for the PROJECT will consist of a redox flow battery system that will be provided by an entity designated by NEDO. 3. The PARTIES will make the non-proprietary results of the PROJECT publically available upon project completion. For purposes of this MOU non-proprietary results mean the type of data described in Article 5, below but does not include any CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION defined in Article 5. 4. The overall work plan and schedule for the PROJECT are set forth in Annex I, Implementation Schedule for the PROJECT." ARTICLE 2 WORK. AND COST SHARING 1. NEDO has designated Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as "DESIGNATED COMPANY") to implement the PROJECT. 2. GO-BIZ will support NEDO and the DESIGNATED COMPANY with permitting, siting, state agency coordination, and workforce connection during the 2

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE NEW ENERGY AND INDUSTRIAL TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATION OF JAPAN AND THE CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR'S OFFICE OF BUSINESS AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONCERNING THE DEMONSTRATION PROJECT FOR VALIDATION OF REDOX FLOW BATTERY IN CALIFORNIA 1

This Memorandum of Understanding (hereinafter referred to as "MOU") has been made to clarify agreements between the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization of Japan (hereinafter referred to as "NEDO") and the California Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development (hereinafter referred to as "GO-BIZ"), (NEDO and GO-BIZ are hereinafter referred to singularly as "PARTY" and collectively as "PARTIES"), concerning the Demonstration Project for Electric Vehicle Driving Behavior in California (hereinafter referred to as "PROJECT). This MOU builds upon the original framework set forth in the Memorandum of Cooperation on climate change, renewable energy, trade and investment, vehicles, high speed rail and water between the Government of Japan and the State of California of the United States of America dated September 5, 2014 and supersedes the Letter of Intent for cooperation in a feasibility study between the PARTIES concerning the demonstration project for electric vehicle (hereinafter referred to as "EV") driving behavior in California dated October 14, 2014. The PARTIES hereby agree as follows: ARTICLE 1 OBJECTIVE AND OUTLINE OF THE PROJECT 1. The objective of the PROJECT is to demonstrate that it is possible to change EV driving behavior and that EVs are suitable for long-distance trips in order to promote EV use and thereby reduce greenhouse gas emissions, criteria pollutants, and fossil fuel use. 2. The demonstration system for the PROJECT will consist of direct current fast chargers, other equipment, and system software that will be supplied by companies designated by NEDO. 3. The PARTIES will make the results of the PROJECT publically available upon project completion. Initial data will be made available to GO-BIZ after NEDO has finished analyzing data collected from EVs and charging stations. GO-BIZ will share initial and on-going data with relevant State Agencies and Universities to help inform the State's DCFC planning process. Detailed timing of the data disclosure above mentioned will be determined based on mutual discussion and agreement of the PARTIES considering the status of DCFC deployment. 4. The overall work plan and schedule for the PROJECT are set forth in Annex I, "Implementation Schedule for the PROJECT." ARTICLE 2 WORK AND COST SHARING 1. NEDO will entrust its work for implementing the PROJECT to Nissan Motor Co., Ltd., Nissan North America, Inc., and Kanematsu Corporation (hereinafter 2

ARTICLE II AREAS OF COOPERATION The Parties intend to cooperate and coordinate efforts, including and with special emphasis on, but not limited to, the following priority action areas: Trade and Investment Agriculture, Poultry and Livestock Aquaculture Science and Technology Education and Cultural Affairs Forestry ARTICLE III IMPLEMENTATION In order to facilitate the implementation of this MOU, officials from the Embassy of Peru in the United States and the Government of the State of Alabama will address periodically specific cooperation action plans in order to achieve the objectives established in this Memorandum and coordinating the involvement of their own institutions. The Parties will encourage their corresponding agencies, public and private institutions, education and research institutions, companies and citizens to actively participate in the above-mentioned areas, thus contributing toward the successful implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding. To consider opportunities for the organization of joint cultural activities; To engage in dialogue regarding tangible cultural heritage, including best practices for conservation and preventive care, as well as history of technology, academic cooperation, and scientific research; ARTICLE III IMPLEMENTATION The Parties will encourage their corresponding agencies, enterprises and educational institutions that might contribute to the successful implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding, to participate actively in the above-mentioned areas. In order to facilitate the implementation of this MOU, the Parties will set up a joint committee led by the Embassy of Peru in United States representing the Government of the Republic of Peru and a representative to be designated by the Government of the State of California, which will meet periodically to address specific cooperation action plans to achieve the objectives established in this Memorandum. All activities undertaken pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding shall be subject to the applicable laws of the Parties, as well as the availability off funds, personnel, and other resources of each Party. ARTICLE IV ENTRY INTO FORCE This Memorandum of Understanding is effective on the date it is signed and does not create any legally binding rights or obligations for either Party.

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING FOR THE STRENGTHENING OF THE COOPERATION BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF PERU AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF ALABAMA The Government of the Republic of Peru and the Government of the State of Alabama, hereinafter "the Parties"; Reaffirming the excellent relations between the Parties and being determined to establish a framework of cooperation through this Memorandum of Understanding; Acknowledging the vast opportunities to strengthen bilateral trade and investment as key components for economic and social development and in favor of all sectors of our societies; Recognizing the willingness of both Parties to develop mutually beneficial programs and projects in areas of common interest, such as agriculture and aquaculture, education and cultural affairs, research, forestry and innovation, among others; Have reached the following understandings: ARTICLEI PURPOSE This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is based on the following common objectives of the Parties: a) To engage in mutually beneficial economic, commercial, educational, research, cultural and environmental activities; b) To promote the organization of trade and investment missions; facilitating the identification of economic opportunities for the Parties; C To foster academic-to-academic partnerships among educational institutions and business-to-business activities between private entities; and d) To organize visits and exchange of experts and researchers and consider opportunities for joint projects, conferences, internships, and training.

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING FOR THE STRENGTHENING OF THE COOPERATION BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF PERU AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA The Government of the Republic of Peru and the State of California, hereinafter "the Parties"; Reaffirming the excellent relations between the Republic of Peru and the State of California and being determined to strengthen those relations by developing a framework of cooperation through this Memorandum of Understanding; Recognizing that the willingness of the Republic of Peru and the State of California will contribute to develop mutually beneficial programs 'in areas of common interest; Acknowledging the existence of opportunities to develop bilateral cooperation to improve commerce, capacity building, education and research to benefit all sectors of society; Have reached the following understandings: ARTICLEI PURPOSE This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is based on the following common objectives of the Parties: a) To engage in mutually beneficial economic, commercial, scientific, technological, cultural, environmental and educational activities; b) To promote the organization of trade and investment missions; facilitating the identification of economic opportunities;

2 SECTION II Areas of Cooperation The Participants intend to promote mutually beneficial relationships in the field of agricultural technology, on-farm resource management, and regulation, with the purpose of exploring how dairy operations can be run most efficiently and climate friendly by sharing knowledge, experiences, data, and best practices while exploring new innovative partnerships relevant to climate and environmental challenges. This will be achieved through initiatives focused particularly on, but not limited to, the following areas of cooperation: a) Exchange of information regarding policies and regulations, governance models, and documentation; b) Intergovernmental and international visits involving policymakers, regulators, academic institutions, and businesses; Joint activities such as organization of and participation in seminars, workshops, and meetings to share information and practices, educate key stakeholders, and promote ties between our two agricultural sectors twice annually; d) Facilitation of innovative partnerships, bringing together parties from public, private and academic entities, bilaterally or multilaterally, to co-develop new technologies and solutions. e) Coordinating efforts in California to co-develop testing of technologies and solutions at farm-level in collaboration with research institutes in California and Denmark, recognizing farmers as end-users and the ultimate agents of change, aiming to enable dairy farmers adapt to stricter regulation relative to environmental protection and climate emissions. SECTION III Coordination The Participants respectively designate the Embassy of Denmark in Washington, D.C. and the Office of Environmental Farming and Innovation in the California Department of Food and Agriculture to establish the creation of an action plan to implement the objectives of this Memorandum of Understanding. Each Participant intends to designate a Senior Official as "Coordinator" for a joint working group to supervise and coordinate the planning, performance, evaluation, and approval of cooperative activities carried out under this MoU.

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN MINISTRY OF FOOD, AGRICULTURE AND FISHERIES OF DENMARK AND THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA The Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Fisheries of Denmark and the California Department of Food and Agriculture hereinafter referred to as "the Participants"; WHEREAS considering the strategic role of agriculture in addressing current global, national, regional, and local food security needs and environmental challenges relating to the climate change and aspiring to show global leadership, while ensuring that local agricultural sectors stay competitive in an evolving national and international marketplace; WHEREAS recognizing that dairy operations in California and Denmark already are amongst the most efficient and innovative globally and that there are opportunities to explore and reimagine the dairy farm of the future to produce more efficiently and with a smaller environmental footprint. WHEREAS desiring to develop and promote dairy technologies in view of the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the agricultural sector to further the mitigation of and adaptation to climate change; WHEREAS wishing to develop and promote agricultural technologies in view of the need to optimize nutrient management and general on-farm resource usage to reduce environmental impacts of agriculture; Therefore, the Participants have reached the following understanding: SECTION I Objective The purpose of this Memorandum of Understanding is to establish a flexible framework between the Participants in order to permit them to promote mutually beneficial relationships between the Participants in the field of agricultural technology and on-farm resource management. This MOU will provide the foundation to further explore how dairy operations can be run most efficiently and climate friendly by sharing knowledge, regulatory pressures, experiences, data, and best practices while exploring new innovative partnerships relevant to climate and environmental challenges.
LETTER OF COOPERATION between THE GOVERNMENT OF CALIFORNIA FOUNDER OF THE Under2 MOU and THE GOVERNMENT OF SCOTLAND on Ambitious Action on Climate Change and the Low Carbon Economy April 2017 1

LETTER OF COOPERATION between THE GOVERNMENT OF CALIFORNIA Founder of the Under2 MOU and THE GOVERNMENT OF SCOTLAND on Ambitious Action on Climate Change and the Low Carbon Economy As recognized by the global community in the Paris Agreement, climate change concerns and connects all humankind. It represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, particularly the poor and the vulnerable, as well as to the environment and our global economy. There has never been a greater need for international cooperation - addressing climate change requires ambitious action by all countries. California and Scotland have set ambitious climate and clean energy goals; both jurisdictions seek to cut greenhouse gases 80% by 2050. California and Scotland both recognize that there are significant economic benefits in jobs, investment, growth and trade of clean energy and the low carbon economy from taking swift action to combat climate change, and that failing to do SO will cost future generations dearly. California and Scotland recognize the vital importance of leadership, action and cooperation by states, provinces, and other sub-national jurisdictions, and seek to capitalise on the huge potential of the Under2 MOU, the ambitious commitment to bold and decisive climate action covering over one billion people and over a third of the global economy to which both jurisdictions are signatories. In the coming years, there will be crucial opportunities for the Governments of California and Scotland to influence higher global ambition on climate change, and to work together to support concrete climate action through the opportunities set out in the Under2 MOU: 2

Scotland and California will support the efforts of other state, regional and city signatories to the Under2 MOU to share ideas and best practices on how we have reduced greenhouse gases and expanded renewable energy development, including by providing expert staff support to other jurisdictions and leading working groups within the Under2 MOU Coalition on these and related topics; Through the Under2 MOU Scotland and California will also share information and best practices with other signatories on how we have undertaken long-term, deep decarbonization planning; Scotland and California will work individually and together to raise international attention to the actions and ambitious reduction goals of climate leaders at a subnational level around the globe, including at key upcoming international climate and energy conferences and summits, in the lead-up to 2018 and beyond. California and Scotland's cooperation as outlined in this letter will firmly demonstrate the collective impact of the commitments across states, regions, cities, and countries that are signatories to the Under2 MOU. 3

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF SCOTLAND AND THE CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMMISSION hereby jointly referred to as "the Participants" WHEREAS, Climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, particularly the poor and vulnerable, as well as to the environment and our global economy; WHEREAS, Scotland and California have both committed to fighting climate change at the subnational level as part of the Under2 Coalition. The Coalition was formed in 2015 by the states of California and Baden-Wirttemberg, Germany to mobilize and galvanize bold climate action from like-minded city, state and regional governments around the globe. Coalition members pledge to limit greenhouse gas emissions to 2 tons per capita or 80 to 95 percent below 1990 levels by 2050. Scotland signed the Under2 MOU in July 2015; WHEREAS, The Government of California and Government of Scotland entered into a Letter of Cooperation on Ambitious Action on Climate Change and the Low Carbon Economy in April of 2017. The Letter ofCooperation supports the efforts of the Under2 MOU and both governments agreed to share ideas and best practices to reduce greenhouse gases, expand renewable energy development, plan for de-carbonization; and raise international attention on the action and ambitious reduction goals of climate leaders at a subnational level around the globe; WHEREAS, Scotland has experience and history in developing offshore wind energy facilities and California is exploring the feasibility, potential impacts, and appropriate locations of, and for, wind facilities offshore the California Coast; NOW THEREFORE, the Participants have reached the following understanding: SECTION 1. OBJECTIVE The objective ofthis Memorandum ofUnderstanding is to fulfill the tenets ofthe Letter of Cooperation and to share knowledge, experiences, data, and best practices relevant to the development of offshore wind energy. SECTION 2. AREAS OF COOPERATION The Participants intend to cooperate on the following priority areas: 1. Constraints and challenges of permitting and constructing offshore wind energy facilities; 2. Environmental challenges associated with offshore wind energy facilities;

MEMORANDUM OF COOPERATION ON CLIMATE CHANGE, RENEWABLE ENERGY, TRADE and INVESTMENT, VEHICLES, HIGH SPEED RAIL, AND WATER BETWEEN THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA AND THE GOVERNMENT OF JAPAN This Memorandum of Cooperation (hereinafter referred to as "MOC") is made by the State of California, United States of America, and the Government of Japan (hereinafter collectively referred to as "Both Sides" and individually as "Side"). Both Sides note their shared concern about the threat of climate change as outlined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), as well as the Scientific Consensus Statement on Maintaining Humanity's Life Support Systems in the 21st Century. Both Sides therefore share their intention to strengthen and coordinate efforts on climate change, renewable energy, trade and investment, vehicles particularly zero emission vehicles (ZEVS), high speed rail and water. Item 1 Areas of Cooperation Both Sides share the intention to cooperate on the following areas, according to the principles of equality and mutual benefit: Climate change, promoting dialogue and joint projects on climate change mitigation and adaptation, such as on short-lived climate pollutants, cleaner freight transport, and the Subnational Global Climate Leadership Memorandum of Understanding ("Under 2 MOU"); Renewable energy, notably promoting dialogue and joint projects on clean energy technology trade and deployment between California and Japan, with a particular focus on energy efficiency and renewable energy development; Energy storage, notably cooperative support for and expansion of the use of energy (electricity) storage technologies that are particularly focused on integrating higher penetrations of variable and intermittent renewable energy resources; Trade and investment, including the encouragement of economic and business development related to the clean technology sector through the fostering of joint industrial research and development (R&D), enhancement of business relationships, and the facilitation of collaboration between Californian and Japanese entrepreneurs through (but not limited to) California's innovation hub (iHub) network, trade delegations, and public-private partnerships; Vehicles, particularly zero emission vehicles (ZEVS), notably including cooperation on best practices, regulatory requirements, research, incentives and other measures to accelerate the ongoing rollout of ZEVS; cooperation on demonstration project(s) on the effectiveness of DC fast charging and enhanced EV use through EV charging infrastructure deployment in California;

MEMORANDUM OF COOPERATION ON STRENGTHENING EFFORTS' TO COMBAT CLIMATE CHANGE AND ECONOMIC AND TRADE RELATIONS BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF JAPAN AND THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA, THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA This Memorandum of Cooperation (hereinafter referred to as "MOC") is made by the Government of Japan (hereinafter referred to as "the Japanese side") and the State of California, the United States of America (hereinafter referred to as "the Californian side") (hereinafter collectively referred to as "thel Participants" and individually as "Participant"). The Participants share their intention to strengthen and coordinate efforts on combating climate change and promoting economic and trade relations through renewable energy, energy storage, business exchange, zero emission vehicles (ZEVS), public transportation, and water. SECTION I Objective The purpose of this MOC is to establish a flexible framework between the Participants in order to broaden and deepen the relationship between the two regions. In doing so, the Participants share the following common objectives: Thel Participants: sharet theiri intention to strengthen and coordinate climate-related activities including combating climate change, promoting renewable energy, and exploringi investments in clean energy: storage; and Thel Participants look to deepen theirt trade and investment relationship, including providing opportunities for business exchange and exploring investments in vehicles, particularly zero emission vehicles (ZEVS), high speed rail and other modes ofj public transport, and water conservation and management. SECTION II Areas of Cooperation The Participants share the intention to cooperate on the following areas, according to the principles of equality and mutual benefit: Climate change, includingpromoting dialogue andjointprojects: on climate change mitigation and adaptation, such as building resilience, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and short-lived climate pollutants, cleaner transport, and addressing impacts on underserved populations. In this regard, the Californian side welcomed the Japanese side's declaration that by 2050 Japan will aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net-zero;

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE MINISTRY OF INFRASTRUCTURE AND WATER MANAGEMENT OF THE NETHERLANDS AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA ON CLIMATE CHANGE PLANNING AND ACTION The Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management of the Netherlands ("Netherlands") and the Environmental Protection Agency of the State of California ("California"), hereinafter referred to as "the Participants," agree as follows; WHEREAS the Netherlands and California are equally committed to significant climate change action and share the long-term goal of becoming climate neutral societies by 2050. California aims to achieve carbon neutrality no later than 2045, and the Netherlands has a target to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. These targets have resulted in ambitious policies for zero-emission transportation on land and sea, long-term climate planning for mid-century carbon neutrality, energy innovation, clean power generation, nature based solutions, and circular economy initiatives. WHEREAS in 2017, the Netherlands and California signed a Letter of Intent (LOI) to strengthen cooperation in the areas of climate change, smart and low carbon mobility, and energy innovation, and whereas, in 2019, the Participants signed an LOI to work together towards transitioning to sustainable economies through the acceleration of zero emission transportation, energy innovation, and zero waste initiatives, and strengthening cooperation in the areas of sustainable mobility, circular economy, climate change, and resiliency. WHEREAS the Netherlands and California have a strong history of international, multilateral leadership and collaboration on zero-emissions transportation, and have been instrumental in the creation of the International Zero-Emissions Vehicle Alliance and the leadership of the Transport Decarbonization Alliance. WHEREAS the transport sector is the Netherlands' and California's largest source of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. WHEREAS the Netherlands and California are global leaders in transportation electrification and electric vehicle (EV) adoption, and are establishing electric vehicle charging equipment test laboratories to promote standards conformance, standards development, interoperability, advanced charging features, and industry support. WHEREAS the Netherlands and California are committed to the exchange of information and best practices on zero-emission vehicle (ZEV) policies, investments, promoting renewable and low-carbon fuels, EV battery recycling, and infrastructure.

LETTER OF INTENT ON ENVIRONMENTAL COOPERATION BETWEEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AND THE MINISTRY OF INFRASTRUCTURE AND THE ENVIRONMENT OF THE KINGDOM OF THE NETHERLANDS The Environmental Protection Agency ofthe State of California of the United States and the Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (hereinafter referred to as "the Two Parties"), through friendly consultation, renew their intent to cooperate in the coming two years. With great satisfaction, the Two Parties acknowledge the successful collaboration between their two governments. This collaboration has included the Letters of Intent between them signed October 30, 2013 in Sacramento, California and on March 3, 2015 in The Hague, The Netherlands; cooperation with other national and subnational jurisdictions on accelerating the electrification of transportation through the International Zero-Emission Vehicle Alliance (ZEV Alliance); and the Agreement to establish the Coast to Coast Sustainable Investment Finance Program on Smart and E- Mobility (C2C SIF). The Two Parties note that successful collaboration has also enabled the Working Agreement between the California Energy Commission and the Province of Noord- Holland, the Netherlands; and the Agreement to collaborate on knowledge exchange and implementation of SolaRoad between the California Department of Transportation and the Province of Noord-Holland. I. Sustainable Mobility and Zero-Emission Vehicles The Two Parties note opportunities to continue and expand on their collaboration, such as continued participation in and support for the ZEV Alliance; and the exchange of information and best practices on zero-emission vehicle policies, investments, and infrastructure. II. Climate Change Policies The Two Parties affirm their continued commitment to leadership in combating climate change. They will continue to exchange information through their respective government channels with regard to climate policies; and to work together to strengthen the contributions of sub-nationaljurisdictions in the context of the international climate change negotiations. Specifically, the Two Parties agree to continue to work together

CONTINUATION AND RENEWAL OF MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF OFFSHORE WIND BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF DENMARK AND THE CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMMISSION hereby jointly referred to as "the Participants" The purpose of this document is to continue and renew the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of Denmark and the California Energy Commission that was signed by the Participants on April 30, 2018. WHEREAS, The rationale expressed in the Memorandum of Understanding continues to exist and be relevant, specifically: Climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, particularly the poor and vulnerable, as well as to the environment and our global economy; Denmark and California have both committed to fighting climate change as part of the Under2 Coalition. The Coalition was formed in 2015 by the states of California and Baden-Wirttemberg, Germany to mobilize and galvanize bold climate action from like-minded city, state and regional governments around the globe. Coalition members pledge to limit greenhouse gas emissions to 2 tons per capita or 80 to 95 percent below 1990 levels by 2050. Denmark became an Endorsing Partner to the Under2 MOU in February 2017; Denmark has experience and history in developing offshore wind energy facilities and California is exploring the feasibility, potential impacts, and appropriate locations of, and for, wind facilities offshore the California Coast; WHEREAS, The Participants recognize the value of continuing and renewing the Memorandum of Understanding in order to further its objective of sharing knowledge, experiences, data, and best practices relevant to the development of offshore wind energy. NOW THEREFORE, The Participants agree to continue and renew the Memorandum of Understanding; FURTHER, Upon signature by the Participants, the Memorandum of Understanding shall continue and be renewed from its previous expiration date and shall continue until December 31, 2022; FURTHER, The Participants agree all other terms of the Memorandum of Understanding shall remain the same. CEC Agreement No. MOU-17-006

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF DENMARK AND THE CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMMISSION hereby jointly referred to as "the Participants" WHEREAS, Climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, particularly the poor and vulnerable, as well as to the environment and our global economy; WHEREAS, Denmark and California have both committed to fighting climate change as part ofthe Under2 Coalition. The Coalition was formed in 2015 by the states of California and Baden-Wirtemberg, Germany to mobilize and galvanize bold climate action from like-minded city, state and regional governments around the globe. Coalition members pledge to limit greenhouse gas emissions to 2 tons per capita or 80 to 95 percent below 1990 levels by 2050. Denmark became an Endorsing Partner to the Under2 MOU in February 2017; WHEREAS, Denmark has experience and history in developing offshore wind energy facilities and California is exploring the feasibility, potential impacts, and appropriate locations of, and for, wind facilities offshore the California Coast; NOW THEREFORE, the Participants have reached the following understanding: SECTION 1. OBJECTIVE The objective ofthis Memorandum of Understanding is to share knowledge, experiences, data, and best practices relevant to the development of offshore wind energy. SECTION 2. AREAS OF COOPERATION The Participants intend to cooperate on the following priority areas: 1. Constraints and challenges of permitting and constructing offshore wind energy facilities; 2. Environmental challenges associated with offshore wind energy facilities; 3. Best practices, regulatory approaches and scientific models with regard to protection ofthe environment, including, but not limited to, the effects of offshore wind energy facilities on fish, marine mammals, migratory birds and cultural resources; 4. Impacts to commercial and recreation fishing industries from offshore wind energy facilities; 5. Sharing data and information on mitigation measures implemented for wind projects offshore Denmark ; 6. Knowledge transfer and sharing on a wide range of offshore wind energy issues including supply chain, offtake, grid integration/interconnection to optimize offshore wind energy deployment and data on the benefits and impacts of offshore wind; and 7. Workforce development and port development requirements/management issues.

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE DANISH ENERGY AGENCY OF THE KINGDOM OF DENMARK AND THE CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMMISSION OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA The Danish Energy Agency and the California Energy Commission, hereinafter referred to as "the Participants, agree as follows: WHEREAS Climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, particularly the poor and vulnerable, as well as to the environment and global economy; WHEREAS Denmark and California have both committed to fighting climate change. The Under2 Coalition was formed in 2015 by the states of California and Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany to mobilize and galvanize bold climate action from like-minded city, state, and regional governments around the globe. Coalition members pledge to limit greenhouse gas emissions to 2 tons per capita or 80 to 95 percent below 1990 levels by 2050. Denmark became an Endorsing Partner to the Under2 Coalition Memorandum of Understanding in February, 2017; WHEREAS Denmark has experience and history in developing offshore wind energy facilities and California is assessing a range of considerations for deploying floating wind energy facilities offshore the coast of California; WHEREAS Denmark has robust policies and programs to reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions from industry and buildings, and California as the fifth largest economy in the world has significant energy consumption and emissions from the building, industrial, and agricultural sectors; WHEREAS Denmark has committed to and invested in projects developing hydrogen and carbon capture technologies that may have applications in California to reduce emissions; WHEREAS California and Denmark currently have Memoranda of Understanding on energy efficiency and the development of offshore wind that are set to expire by 2022; Therefore, the Participants have reached the following understanding:

Coalition members pledge to limit greenhouse gas emissions to 2 tons per capita or 80 to 95 percent below 1990 levels by 2050.
